name: Der Präsident. –
text: I declare the session suspended on Thursday 10 March 2016 to be resumed.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. March 22 was a black day for Belgium, a black day for Europe. Insidious murderers carried out a horrific series of terror attacks in Brussels. Thirty-two innocent people are dead, 340 innocent people are injured, some of them very serious – that is the record of this cruelty, a record of inhumanity. The criminals of ISIS, with their attacks, targeted the heart of Europe, Brussels, which offers a home to the European institutions and many other institutions, Brussels, this multilingual, cosmopolitan and tolerant city that embodies our open European society. Above all, however, the gang of murderers targeted the innocent people of Brussels. Attacks on public places such as airports or subways are targeted at innocent people – against men, against women, even against children. The cynical calculus of such assassins is to fear the whole of Brussels, the whole of Belgium, the whole of Europe, so that fear and hatred will conquer our hearts. That is why we must remain calm, not place every Muslim under general suspicion, and not equate Islam with the primitive Islamism of the murderers. That is why, in memory of the victims as Europeans, we must stand together in solidarity against this fear, not let ourselves be infected by the hatred of the assassins, not to the hatred of hatred with hatred, not to respond to violence with violence, but to combat a growing distrust, a growing fear, also by courageousness and cohesion with the aim of defending the freedom of all and our democracy and of respecting and protecting the dignity of all people on principle. We must not forget that people around the world are becoming victims of these jihadists almost every day: in Afghanistan, Pakistan, Iraq, Ivory Coast, Turkey, Tunisia, Egypt, Syria, Somalia, Nigeria. In all these countries, in recent months, innocent people have often become hundreds of victims of these terrorists, and their lives have been taken away. This list is not even complete. Let us not delude ourselves: this terror is global. And by the way, most of the victims of this terror are Muslims. This terror is a global challenge and we will not be able to respond to it through individual national measures. The fight against terrorism means that we stand together – all of them – in Europe together and in the world. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which On behalf of the European Parliament, I wish the injured a speedy recovery and express our full solidarity with the families and families of the innocently murdered people. Our deepest sympathies go out to the victims and their families. We will not forget the victims of this terror in Brussels and elsewhere in the world, we must not forget them. I would ask you to stand for a minute's silence in memory of the victims. (The House rose and observed a minute's silence) Thank you very much.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the International Roma Day (2016/2645(RSP)).

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you on behalf of the Commission for this opportunity to speak today on the occasion of International Roma Day, which we celebrated last Friday. Discrimination against Roma is still widespread across the EU. Anti-Gypsyism, a specific form of racism closely related to deep-rooted negative stereotyping and stigmatisation of Roma, is on the rise. It is linked to the rise of radicalism and extremism in general in the EU. This trend raises serious concerns. It is crucial to take a strong stand and to do our best to stop these negative phenomena, which are incompatible with the values cherished by the European Union. The Commission has put in place a solid framework of policy, legal and financial instruments which, if implemented properly, should produce results on the ground. The Commission has stepped up its efforts to ensure the correct implementation of legislation to combat discrimination against Roma. The Commission has also urged Member States to demonstrate greater political will and a long-term vision to combat discrimination and promote the inclusion of Roma people. The inclusion of minorities in education, the labour market and political life is one of the main ingredients of a healthy society. This year the Commission launched a targeted campaign to effectively tackle stereotypes and prejudices against the Roma, called ‘For Roma, with Roma’. It includes training for the media and close collaboration with municipalities in selected Member States. The fight against discrimination against Roma and anti-Gypsyism – including hate speech and hate crime targeting the Roma community – is included in the Commission’s annual reporting on the progress made in advancing Roma integration, as well as in the Council recommendations on effective Roma integration measures, the first ever EU legal instruments specifically referring to Roma. The Commission has welcomed and strongly supported the initiative of the European Parliament to designate 2 August as European Roma Holocaust Memorial Day. The Commission has also encouraged Member States to do the same. It is our duty to acknowledge and remember all those who suffered under the Nazi regime, including Roma. The suffering of Roma in concentration camps is a horrific chapter of human history that is less widely known. The Commission will support the European Parliament in its action to bring the European Parliament resolution to the Council for further discussion.

name: Preşedinte. –
text: No on-demand interventions are made in this debate and blue card is not accepted.

name: György Hölvényi
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, it is my honour and a real privilege to share my hopes regarding the International Roma Day on behalf of my Group, the European People’s Party. Roma affairs have social, human and economic aspects all at once. These affairs are not less important than they have been up to now. Not less important than they were in 2011, when – during the Hungarian Presidency – a project called Roma Strategy was launched. Hungary is proud of having called the attention of the community to those European Roma competitors who should be considered as human resources but often have no chance to prove it. Youngsters from the Roma population have to face extra difficulties if they want to break out of their cultural or material circumstances, which are ruled by the strict tradition and tight bonds of their community. Even if they manage to overcome these factors, they have to face the discriminating prejudices of society. The Roma population needs special aid in this effort to be able to overcome these disadvantages and other complexes. Our task is to form the attitude in society to be more respectful and adapting. The European Union’s main duty is to create the professional framework through special programmes focusing on this issue. That is why the Roma strategy has called on the Member States to refuse all kinds of segregation, discrimination and racism. These Roma programmes and invested resources can be refunded only if we take action together with them on the basis of common decisions. We have to bring together not only Roma but also non-Roma if we want to create sustainable projects. It is of great importance that the culture and history of Roma should be integrated in the education of the youth and that the new generation does not grow up without any knowledge or with false information concerning the 10 million Roma citizens in Europe. Europe has decided to face what it has missed so far and will pay attention to creating equal opportunities and providing early childhood aid, which is the most important action, even if the results are apparent only much later. This is how targeted school and pre-school programmes started in the Member States, and this was the way to give more and more Roma children the chance to get help from early childhood. As we open the doors for schools wider and wider, likewise we have to open the gates of the churches as well, so that a receptive and solidarity-based spirit can pervade Roma communities. Let us be proud of Roma intelligence; let us give Roma youngsters the opportunity to obtain degrees, and let us create the circumstances for them to work among us. In Europe, the unique Hungarian Roma college network serves as a good example to help hundreds of Roma students to get a degree. Among them are doctors, researchers, teachers and artists. We started this work together; let us continue together.

name: Soraya Post
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Last year, at this time, we debated a resolution on the fight against and recognition of anti-Gypsyism and the EU's recognition of the holocaust of Roma during the Second World War. Parliament adopted the resolution by a very broad majority. With this resolution, Parliament has clearly shown the way in which to work to ensure that Roma can enjoy equal rights within the EU – in short, in order for Roma to be treated as human beings. Anti-Gypsyism is a disgrace to Europe. In the debate with the Council and the Commission, everyone agreed that anti-Gypsyism should be combated by all means. Today is the time to start discussing how to do it. Social measures are not enough. We must fight against this particular form of racism. So we need to work towards the mainstream society. Parliament has asked two oral questions on which this debate is based. They deal with what the Commission and the Council should do to ensure that the Member States take concrete and effective measures to combat this particular form of racism, anti-Gypsyism. The Council and the Member States must set ambitious and concrete targets for their work which the Commission can evaluate. Otherwise, nothing will happen. The Commission must establish a High Representative against racism to ensure that work against all forms of racism is a priority in the Member States, especially since today we are seeing racism and racists entering our parliaments. Finally, I have a specific question for the Council. When will you confirm the establishment of 2 August as the European Day of Remembrance for the Holocaust of the Roma? I am thinking that Parliament has done its part, and now you too must do your part. Last week we celebrated International Roma Day all week, Roma Week, by a large majority, the broad participation of the various political groups. We had party leader debate, we had exhibitions, we had various seminars to just note that despite national strategies, the inclusion of the Roma does not work. We need to turn the pancake around a little, we also have to work against the majority society. There is a change in attitudes. Politicians and people on the bus are without shame expressing themselves negatively towards the Roma across Europe. I was in Berlin on April 8th. I had several different meetings with different participants. I watched movies. In at least a thousand camps across Europe, Roma settle without access to electricity, without access to water, without access to schools for children, without any access to medical care. The situation is catastrophic. If we do not act now, Europe will have to stand with a very long nose and receive a great deal of shame from the rest of the world. It is not acceptable for us, in a modern democratic society, to continue to have 10-12 million people living below the poverty line. It's a great shame. We have to act now, we can't wait. The far-right forces are exploiting this group to the maximum and are actually winning voters because we established political parties are not taking hold of the issue as we should. We in the Socialist Group have set up a programme. We've positioned ourselves. We will not accept this. I would also like to take this opportunity to thank the political group leaders who took part in the debate. Everyone was there except from the ALDE group, which had some kind of obstruction. However, the other parties clearly showed that they stand up to ensure that the Roma issue is on the political agenda, despite all the other difficult challenges we face. So now I would like the Commission to take this issue seriously. It is not acceptable in 2016 that we go into next year without having done anything. Now something has to be done. This is not acceptable.

name: Jana Žitňanská
text: for the ECR Group. – Slovakia is one of the European countries with a large Roma minority. It is estimated that today it accounts for about 9% of the population. A large proportion of Roma are dependent on the social system as a result of low education and unemployment, and also face difficult situations in life because of poverty, discrimination and established stereotypes. Roma children are more often than not in special schools, and Roma employment is only about 10% compared to 60% for non-Roma. Many Roma have already resigned themselves to finding a job, children are losing motivation to learn. Despite the funds available from the state budget, as well as The European Funds, it turns out that the state has long been unable to integrate the excluded Roma. I believe that civic associations, churches and, in particular, local leaders, who deserve our recognition and can inspire many others in their communities will play a fundamental role in this process. That is why it is important to create the conditions for them to work, to support them financially, but also to make them more visible. I am therefore glad that last week, in the European Parliament, they solemnly unveiled a travelling statue of a Slovak Roma and his colleagues. John onions have an incredible life story. From the settlement he developed to his own medical practice in Switzerland and was one of the nine initiators of the first Roma World Congress. On this occasion, therefore, we are already commemorating Roma World Day for the 45th year. Mr Onion was convinced that only the association of Roma elites would help to break down the barriers between Roma and non-Roma, which unfortunately still exist in society to this day. None of us have chosen whether to be born healthy or disabled, whether to come to a wealthy family or to a family living in poverty in one of the populations. However, without outside help, it will not get out of the vicious circle of poverty and exclusion. The sooner we manage to cut through this circle, the more it will benefit not only the Roma themselves, but our entire society. On the contrary, delaying the solution can have devastating consequences not only for the specific people concerned, but there is a risk of an even greater increase in radical attitudes.

name: Angelika Mlinar
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the ALDE Group very much welcomes this debate on the occasion of International Roma Day. Celebrating Roma culture also highlights the persecution and discrimination that Roma people face in all areas of life, and we would like to use this opportunity to remind everyone here that non-discrimination is a fundamental value of the European Union. Much more needs to be done not only to fight discrimination and stereotypes against Roma people, but also to support their socio-economic integration. This is the key to delivering on equality for all. The European Union and the Member States have committed to this, but if you look at the reality on the ground, we are far from living up to our standards. Forced evictions, segregation and discrimination in access to jobs, education, housing and health care cannot be tolerated any more in our Union. We cannot be satisfied with national strategies for Roma integration on paper only. The European Parliament should be further involved and should take a proactive stance in monitoring the extent to which such strategies are implemented – both from a cost-effectiveness standpoint and from a concrete-outcome point of view. We have a common responsibility to act and to ensure that fundamental rights are respected for all.

name: Cornelia Ernst
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the International Roma Day is really bad for folklore afternoons and not for half-empty halls, as we are seeing here. Rather, it is an opportunity to understand – really understand – that Roma have lived in Europe for centuries – more than 600 years. And I think that 600 years is enough to be considered native, as a neighbour, as a work colleague and – I may say so at least for the European left – as friends.  The latter is not difficult for us, because Roma are genuine citizens of the world, not only because they have never, and at no time, initiated any war, but because Roma have enriched and enriched society in many countries of the world and still do so today, they shape it, like the Canadian writer Ronald Lee, the Austrian jazz guitarist Harri Stojka, the cosmopolitan and civil rights activist Romani Rose, the singer Marianne Rosenberg, the boxer Johann Wilhelm Trollmann, who, like 500 million Roma and Sinti, was killed by the Hitler fascists in the concentration camp during World War II.  I have really spoken to Roma a lot in recent years, and again and again they have told me one thing: 'What we want is actually quite simple. We do not want our own state, nor do we insist on any particular religion. We want to be able to live where we live. We want to live like everyone else, we want to work, we want to start families, we want to grow old, we also want to die in this family round. We do not want privileges, no extra treatment. Dignity, that is what we want. We want to be treated equally," they say again and again, "have equal opportunities and, please, don't have to be afraid to say what we are: Roma."  The fact that today's Roma still have to explain that they really are human beings, that they really want to live in peace, that they do not just see themselves as musicians and certainly do not steal white children, but that they certainly have a problem with them when they are deported from Germany to Kosovo after 17 years, to a country where they have no livelihood, which is by no means a safe country for them – all this is one of the really great impositions of our time – a time when racism is booming again.  Fighting for an unbiased and dignified world under such conditions is not so easy for the many larger, but above all for the many small Roma organisations and initiatives, but really difficult. That is another reason why I take this opportunity today to thank them, not to repeat the whining and fuss of integration, to thank them, to all those who are waging this tireless struggle every day, such as Amaro Drom in Berlin, the Roma Centre in Göttingen, the defenders – this is very close to my heart – of the Roma Parliament in Budapest, the Gitanos in Spain, the many, many Roma initiatives in Bulgaria, Whenever there is talk of integrating new Roma, these initiatives do not talk about it, they make it quite easy. They show what is really at stake: the indivisibility of human rights, for which there is no precondition but one thing: to be a human being.

name: Terry Reintke
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, dear colleagues, and especially dear Roma all over Europe, International Roma Day is a day to commemorate the atrocities and the persecution that Roma have been facing for hundreds of years on this continent. But it is also a day to think about the injustices that Roma still face every day in Europe. The past – but also our present – makes it very clear that we hold responsibility. We hold responsibility to create a fully-inclusive European Union and to fight against anti-Gypsyism and for equal rights for all. We can make a difference today. We can shape the politics of anti-discrimination. We can create a society that gives equal chances with regard to housing, employment, education and health. As dry as it very often seems, the EU structural funds are one of the instruments at our disposal in order to do this. But we even need to go further, because the fight against discrimination does not end with merely shaping policies. It needs to go very deep in our mainstream society. To give just one example, there are 11 million Roma living in the European Union. There is a great diversity amongst this community. Yet still, when I open the newspaper, I see stereotypical images of Roma every single day. This does not represent their great diversity and this will not be a step in order to fight against anti—Gypsyism in the European Union. Lastly, in my struggle, together with Roma activists, I have again and again been thanked for what I am doing, and I hear them thank the Commission for fighting for equal rights.  I want to take this opportunity to say that I do not want to be thanked any more, because actually we are the ones who should be grateful. We are the ones who should be grateful for the richness that Roma culture represents within Europe and for the power of Roma activists within the political debates. I am thankful for all the Roma who have opened their homes to me, who have shared food with me, who have shared their experiences and who have let me be part of their struggle. So thank you – Erika, Nino, Andrea, Daniella, David, Ivana – for letting me fight side by side together with you against anti—Gypsyism and for a European Union of equal rights and inclusion. I am deeply honoured.

name: James Carver
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, of all the paternal advice that I was offered, I well remember a conversation with my father: ‘son’, he said, ‘never forget who you are and where you come from. If you cannot do this then you will never be true to yourself’. Dad was a Romani gypsy. His own mother was born in a caravan or, as we say in Romani, a vardo. He was typical of many of his kith and kin. Never held back by his own illiteracy, he was streetwise, shrewd and incredibly tough. As I am believed to be the only British parliamentarian of Romani descent, I am proud to champion the real concerns facing a community living on the margins of UK society. On Roma Nation Day I met with representatives of the International Romani Union, the Gypsy Council and Traveller Movement groups outside 10 Downing Street in London. I then hand-delivered a letter outlining my concerns over recent changes in UK planning legislation redefining a legal personality of a Traveller, thus placing increased difficulties on my community, who already face a massive shortage of site provision. I also asked for the appointment of Romanies to the UK Holocaust Commission, as the current absence from membership, despite the Nazi genocide that cost some half a million lives, is felt as another instance of exclusion. In 21st-century Britain there has never been a more pressing time to tackle the problems facing Britain’s travelling communities. Both the UK Government and the Westminster Parliament must rise to that challenge instead of continually sweeping the issue under the carpet. I will not hold my breath.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you very much for this inspiring discussion. I endorse every word you have said. I have to think about many of the things which you have raised here. Soraya Post said that we need to do a lot and we need to do it now. I think the situation is worse, because we are doing a lot – we have done a lot, we have invested a lot – and it obviously is not working because the situation is not improving. On the contrary, the situation is worsening. Now, with the worsening of the whole atmosphere in Europe and with increasing intolerance, the Roma people are among the first to be attacked, mocked and abused. That is why we have to do better. I am thinking deeply about where the barriers are and why we are not able to achieve better results in terms of including Roma citizens. I can see three main problems. One problem is resortism. We need to tackle all four areas with one series of well—targeted actions: health protection, labour, social protection and education, giving a helping hand to children and families with children. We see in Member States that these sectors are dealt with by different ministries, and they themselves say that they understand and they need common action. This is already being reflected in the national strategies. I hope that a solution can be found soon. The second problem is that I have a feeling that we are implementing this policy for the Roma but without their participation. We need to involve them more because action cannot be taken without them. Here it is necessary to give more support to the NGOs – some Members also said this – and local communities which are in everyday contact with Roma people. I have always criticised the fact that NGOs are only given financing for one year at a time, because NGOs are not the only ones working for the inclusion of Roma. We have to tackle the permanent problem of finance. They keep looking for money to maintain their activities, and so we should also look at the financing of NGOs, because financing for at least three years would help their projects become more sustainable. The last problem which I see is that EU funding should be better used. Again we are speaking about short-term projects, but longer-term action is necessary to change the situation, because the task ahead of us is not a trivial one. We want to change the stereotypes and prejudices in society, and this cannot be done in the short term and with badly-chosen instruments. So let us all work together on this, and let us be brave enough to admit that what we are doing is not working. Let us do better.

name: Pre
text: sit. – The debate has been closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Damian Drăghici (S&D)
text: in writing. – 45 years ago, on 8 April, the Roma representatives took a first common stand for the emancipation of our communities. We celebrate this and Europe joining our struggle every year on International Roma Day. I consider it is also a moment to emphasise our European society should equally accommodate all its citizens and value diversity as its undoubted chance to permanent enrichment. It is our common duty to ensure solidarity, freedom, equality and fairness will become the real pillars of the future EU. Fighting the social exclusion of marginalised communities such as the Roma should be accelerated. Ensuring equal access to development resources is the only way to break the poverty cycle threatening to entrap the Roma for many generations ahead. Our success stories should inspire non-Roma and Roma as well. Because, as the majority populations need to learn more about us, we shall explore more our values and increasing potential to make a difference in Europe. Not least, we shall not forget it is our shared responsibility to educate our children not to be judgmental on others’ skin colour or cultural background. The way we educate them will reflect on the future they are building.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Roma community, with an estimated population of between 10 and 12 million people in the EU, is the largest minority in Europe. The fight against anti-Anti-Itanism in the political, social and legal spheres is impossible as a result of the rise that this despicable phenomenon is taking on in the EU through the infamous discourse of hatred, directed against Roma, and the significant acts of racist violence that have occurred in recent times. Antigitanism is a special kind of racism directed against Roma and a form of dehumanization that is rooted in The History of Europe. Anti-itanism can be committed by state or non-state actors, in which case it is projected into public policies that directly or indirectly discriminate against Roma and deprive them of full enjoyment of their fundamental rights. It is important to require THEMs to prioritise national strategies to combat Roma discrimination and to provide a special day of commemoration of the Gypsy Holocaust which has been recognised by the European Parliament in its resolution of 15 April 2015.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Roma community, with an estimated population of 10 or 12 million people in the EU, is the largest minority in Europe. The fight against anti-Anti-Itanism on all political, social and legal fronts is impossible given the rise that this despicable phenomenon is taking on in the EU through the infamous discourse of hatred, directed against roma, and the significant acts of racist violence that have occurred in recent times. Antigitanism is a special type of supremacist racism directed against Roma and a form of dehumanization that sinks its roots in the history of Europe. Anti-Itanism can be committed by state or non-state actors in which case it is projected into public policies that directly or indirectly discriminate against Roma and deprive them of the full enjoyment of their fundamental rights. It is important to require THEMs to prioritise national strategies to combat Roma discrimination and to provide a special day of commemoration of the Gypsy Holocaust which has been recognised by the European Parliament in its resolution of 15 April 2015.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Writing. – Every year on 8 April we celebrate International Roma Day, commemorating the meeting of the first World Roma Congress in 1971. Now, 45 years later, European Roma continue to suffer discrimination, prejudice and social disadvantage. Most of them live in hopeless poverty, have much less chance of finding work, good education, health care and many, many years shorter lives than their non-Roma compatriots.  It is shameful that Roma are being unlawfully evicted in many Member States. It is scandalous that in many Member States they do not act to eradicate segregation, but defend discrimination, classify many Roma children as arbitrarily special needs and force them into lower-quality schools. Even today, a significant part of the resources allocated to the Roma do not reach the communities concerned. In recent days, I have organized Roma Week in the European Parliament with 22 fellow Members from six different groups and 10 NGOs representing roma, where we have held professional and cultural events to raise awareness of the situation of Roma in Europe and the importance of their inclusion. We believe that the European institutions and the Member States have a duty to do more than ever before to ensure equal opportunities for Roma.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: Writing. – I am sure many of you have been aware of the reprehensible and regrettable case that the event tent erected in Bucharest on the occasion of International Roma Day was painted by unknown people with offensive and crude anti-Roma inscriptions. The police have started the investigation, the Romanian government and the Romanian Head of State have expressed their outrage, several embassies have spoken out and even the World Bank has issued a statement condemning what happened.  I, too, can only join in the outraged reactions and say that similar manifestations are not worthy of an EU Member State in which the Roma community is grappling with a serious social disconnect. At the same time, I would like to draw attention to the fact that in Romania there is not only open discrimination against the Roma community, violent messages such as this one often appear against the Hungarian minority, at sporting events, on graffiti, but also incitement and incitement to hatred by some media outlets.  I would like the institutions of the state and politicians to condemn these phenomena with similar vehemence, because we cannot allow this form of behaviour to become socially acceptable.

name: Preşedinte. –
text: The next item is the debate on Sajjad Karim's report, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on the 2012-2013 Annual Reports on Subsidiarity and Proportionality (2014/2252(INI)) (A8–0301/2015).

name: Sajjad Karim
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, a colleague with a very good sense of humour said to me earlier today: ‘I so much look forward to your annual proposals for reform for subsidiarity, proportionality and better law-making’, and I did smile at him. It really has been a tremendous honour for me, over many years now, to be able to play my part in helping to develop the way in which we carry out our legislation-making processes. Of course, I cannot do it alone, and I must acknowledge and thank all of my shadow rapporteurs who have helped me for many years now: Tadeusz Zwiefka, Mady Delvaux, Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann, António Marinho e Pinto and, of course, colleagues like Angelika Niebler, who is currently leaving the Chamber as I am addressing you all. Colleagues, this is really a pivotal point for the European Union and, indeed, for my country – the United Kingdom – as well. I firmly believe that Britain and the European Union are stronger together, and I hope that, through our proposals, we can cement the relationship between this Parliament and our national parliaments. Britain’s input in the European Union, I believe, benefits the entirety of Europe. But this may be one of the last occasions that I, as an MEP, am actually able to put forward proposals of this sort, because we are about to undergo a referendum in the UK that, at this stage, remains far too close to call. What concerns do our constituents, our citizens, actually have on this particular topic? Well, they may not recognise the details that we attach and the names we attach, but they quite frequently say to all of us that the European Union is too distant, that it is doing far too much, and that what it does applies to far too many people unnecessarily. And we, as a Parliament, must address these pivotal issues. It is important for our own democratic accountability. In particular, if these reforms are rejected, we play into the hands of those who ultimately want to break the European Union and weaken all of our citizens. We must not allow that to happen. It is in that spirit that our national leaders came to an agreement and have put that forward for us to consider, in accordance with how we wish to proceed. Is the European Union’s law-making too distant? Well the role of national parliaments, and coupled with that, their responsibility and rights: we must bring national parliaments much closer to our EU decision-making processes. It is only by doing that that we strengthen them and we strengthen ourselves. Indeed, I have to confess that my own House of Commons EU Scrutiny Committee is not the best example of how EU legislation should be scrutinised, and I certainly do not recommend that as a way forward. Is the European Union doing too much? Well, we must have Europe only where necessary. Subsidiarity – reasoned opinions from national parliaments – has increased, but not all of our parliaments are fully engaged. The Impact Assessment Board itself has said that subsidiarity is not adequately addressed in our impact assessments. In my report, I also encourage more participation of national parliaments in the preparation of EU legislation, such as green papers or white papers. This could also include annual debates for each national parliament with the European Commission. The yellow card procedure in the Treaties should be easily implementable for national parliaments, since there are several circumstances in which difficulties have been reported. An extension to the eight-week time period for consultation with national parliaments under the subsidiarity check should be furthered. I have a number of other proposals which I will go into, but I will save those for when I come back at the end of the debate. But my final plea to colleagues is this: we have nothing to be frightened of when we say we want to empower ourselves and national parliaments to work much more closely to ensure that we, ultimately, are delivering legislation which is seen as relevant and proper by our citizens.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Karim for his excellent report on the Commission’s report for 2012-2013 on subsidiarity and proportionality. For the Commission, subsidiarity and proportionality must be at the heart of the European democratic process: the very key to our objective of being big on the big things and small on the small things. We have committed to give real effect to the principle of subsidiarity and to work closely with national parliaments and other EU institutions to enhance our common understanding of subsidiarity and ensure that every proposal complies with that principle. National parliaments play a key role when it comes to monitoring respect for the principle of subsidiarity. In that regard, the report calls on the Commission to deepen its relations with the national parliaments and to engage in a yearly debate with each national parliament. The Juncker Commission pledged to forge a new partnership with national parliaments, in particular by increasing the frequency of Commissioners’ visits to national parliaments. Since taking office in November 2014, Commissioners have made more than 270 visits to national parliaments. The Commission intends to continue the frequency of these visits, explaining what we do and why we do it and listening to the concerns of national parliaments. The report also suggests revising the guidelines for impact assessments. In May 2015 the Commission adopted the Better Regulation Package. This new framework includes a range of measures to make Commission policy-making more transparent and evidence-based. It comprises improved guidelines, both for ex-ante impact assessments and the retrospective evaluation of already-existing legislation. The revised guidelines also include strengthened guidance both on subsidiarity and proportionality analysis, as well as a dedicated tool for the legal basis of a given proposal and its subsidiarity and proportionality aspects. Furthermore, the package sets up a new regulatory scrutiny board responsible for reviewing the quality of impact assessments and of major evaluations. The board is also responsible for recommending improvements in case particular aspects, including subsidiarity or proportionality, have not been duly taken into account. This brings me to the comments in the report calling on all institutions to ensure that subsidiarity checks are also undertaken at the conclusion of the legislative negotiation before the adoption of the final text. The Commission is very pleased that the three institutions have recently agreed on a new inter-institutional agreement on better law-making. The agreement puts renewed focus on ensuring that the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are given full respect when developing Union legislation and assessing its impacts. The agreement not only obliges the Commission to explain in its explanatory memoranda how the measures proposed are justified in the light of the principle of subsidiarity, but now provides that the European Parliament and the Council will, when they consider it appropriate and necessary, carry out impact assessments in relation to any substantial amendments they make to the Commission’s initial proposal. The Commission is pleased that all the institutions have jointly committed to ensuring that subsidiarity is a key element throughout the legislative process. Let me conclude by reassuring all Members that the Commission will make sure that the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality remain at the heart of the European democratic process. We look forward to working with the other EU institutions under the new inter-institutional framework to ensure that every piece of legislation respects the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Helga Stevens
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – As rapporteur for the opinion of the EMPL Commission, I am very pleased that many elements of our opinion have been incorporated into the report of my ECR colleague in the Committee on Legal Affairs.  In our opinion, we made a number of recommendations: Firstly, the Commission and the Member States should strengthen the debate on the application of the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality in the field of employment and social affairs. Secondly, the principle of subsidiarity requires that we, as policy-makers, ensure that new European legislation is to offer tangible added value. Thirdly, the role of national parliaments must be further strengthened.  I close with two personal reservations. I strongly advocate the work of an independent entity for the impact assessment. Finally, I would like to stress that substantial changes can be made to the Commission's proposal during the legislative process. It is therefore important to check whether these amendments are in line with the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Patricija Šulin
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. – Thank you to the rapporteur, Mr Karim, for the report prepared. I am pleased that it also contains the recommendations that we adopted in the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. By applying the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality correctly, we will actually be able to come up with legislation that benefits citizens, businesses and workers and avoid unnecessary administrative burdens. In particular, the Committee on Budgetary Control has taken a stand against the Commission, in accordance with both principles, to simplify the procedures for obtaining European Union funds. Application procedures must be effective and result-oriented. At the same time, the Commission should better demonstrate and demonstrate the added value of the MFF programmes in the beneficiary Member States. The assessment of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality must be an essential element of the Union and the preparation and assessment of its policies and citizens' confidence in the European Union.

name: Tiziana Beghin
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on International Trade – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking on behalf of David Borrelli, draftsman of the opinion of the INTA Committee.  The issue of subsidiarity and proportionality is central to the harmonious and positive development of the Union's competences, because it concerns relations with citizens and the Member States. However, this issue is also not without impact on trade policy. That is why I would like to sum up the debate we have had in INTA.  First of all, the issue of the SDS, a well-known issue that has fuelled and continues to fuel a number of potential conflicts between the Powers of the Union and the judicial sovereignty of the Member States.  Secondly, the issue of macro-financial assistance. More ex ante and ex-post controls are needed, in particular to assess the proportion of assistance we offer to our partners while at the same time strengthening Parliament's control.  Thirdly, there are the issues of transparency and impact assessments of international treaties, making them sincere, reliable and consistent. The involvement of enterprises at this stage and especially of small and medium-sized enterprises, as called for in the INTA opinion, remains crucial. Finally, I would like to conclude by pointing out that subsidiarity and proportionality are central to trade issues. On the contrary, the real challenge is how to better calibrate our actions, bringing the decision-making process as close as possible to the citizen; I believe that trade policy cannot be excluded from this area.

name: Tadeusz Zwiefka
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Honourable Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. I have had great pleasure for many years working with Mr Karim on the annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality in the process of creating EU law, and every time there are new proposals or in-depth analyses of what we should do. It would be worth while to achieve their effective implementation, because it will undoubtedly have a very good impact on the quality of the law we create.  The principle of subsidiarity and proportionality is an absolutely fundamental principle in the process of EU legislation, I would say that this is the starting point for the creation of Community law. Especially now, at a time when many of our Member States are getting stronger and stronger anti-EU accents, questions arise: why is the European Union needed when it creates a complicated law when there is overregulation. Why does this happen at all?  Applying the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality – as Mr Karim recommends, together with a very well-conducted impact assessment process – is something that we should be exposing in our action, which should include in understanding the essence of European law-making not only european citizens, but also European entrepreneurs, so that they understand why Community law is an added value and not something that we create for ourselves. Hence the important role of involving national parliaments to participate more in the creation of this right and to make them want to be more active at the stage of expressing their views on new proposals. This applies both to the proposal submitted by the European Commission and to the very law of the final effect of the negotiations between the European Parliament and the Council. I believe that the deadline for submitting such proposals in justified situations should indeed be extended, we should strengthen the role of national parliaments. That is why the innovative proposal put forward by colleague Karim to introduce a so-called Green Card, which would allow national parliaments to make very legitimate and very sensible proposals already to the European Commission, seems to me to be extremely well founded.

name: Mady Delvaux
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr President, Commissioner, I think we all agree that we are in agreement to reiterate how important the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are for us to form a Union close to the citizens. These principles are necessary and useful to the smooth running of the European Union, and I say, the right thing is going on. These principles are in no way intended to prevent the Union from acting effectively. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality must be finely calibrated in relation to the need for efficiency in the work of our institutions, so as to achieve the right balance. However, I believe that the report as presented to us threatens this fragile and yet essential balance for the proper functioning of the Union. And I cannot bring myself to have the founding principles serve the aims of the Eurosceptics. In the name of respecting the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, this report calls for the creation of additional steps in our legislative process. These steps add to the bureaucratic burden that already weighs on our institutions and the application of such procedures has the effect of slowing down or even blocking the European legislative process.  However, we owe our citizens an effective Union, which takes into account their concerns, a union that is efficient in the service of their interests, a flexible Union capable of responding promptly to the challenges imposed on it, an ever closer Union between peoples, capable of reacting in a common way to circumstances with mutual respect. That is why, on behalf of those who believe in this European Union, I call on colleagues to support the amendments of the S and D Group which protect a precious balance for Europe. I say 'yes' to subsidiarity and proportionality, but not to the detriment of an effective Union for citizens. I assume you guessed, Mr President, that I do not share the rapporteur's view on the principle and the application of subsidiarity and proportionality, but I want to thank him for his fairness and for the good collaboration.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I fully agree with Mr Karim. Unfortunately, in my language, The German, there is no other word for subsidiarity. What does that mean? If my hometown of Hamburg has a problem, then the hamburgers should try to solve it. And only when they can't, this problem should go to Berlin. And only if Berlin cannot solve it should it go to Brussels. Unfortunately, this House is constantly violating this. One of the main reasons for the violation of the principle of subsidiarity is the single euro, ladies and gentlemen, because it automatically leads to the exact opposite, namely centralisation, and this centralisation increasingly alienates Europeans from Brussels. It is increasingly leading to a lack of competitiveness in the euro area and, above all, to right-wing radicalism. That is why here again my Ceterum censeo: I believe that the single euro not only leads to discord and discord, but also increasingly leads to centralism and must therefore be abolished.

name: António Marinho e Pinto
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Thank you, Mr President. I would like to begin by welcoming the rapporteur to commend the work he has done in this report. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. One of the most serious problems of the European Union today is the removal of citizens and even some Member States, from the Union institutions themselves. I believe that Mr Karin's report is part of this problem, and it seeks with rigour and seriousness, to bring about a good application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. To that extent, it will contribute decisively to the prestigious institutions of the Union and to bringing them closer to the citizens. Bringing the European Union closer to the citizens and not pushing it away.  It is important that laws are understandable and their process is simple and accessible to the majority of citizens, on behalf of those who act here and intervene here. The results of the European elections show that citizens are increasingly separated from the Union itself, from the Community institutions themselves. In this regard, I would like once again to welcome Mr Karin's work and to commend his efforts to combat this problem, this issue, in the European Union. I support the report, I will vote in favour and I have only one small question here which, moreover, is practically outdated, which was the possibility of extending the deadline for national parliaments to speak, extending that deadline from eight to twelve weeks. I agree extending the deadline will allow the reports and a more thorough and reasoned analysis by those for national parliaments and this will honor the European Union itself. I would like, however, to say that the Treaty does not provide for such a possibility, but the Council, the Member States unanimously approved this extension of that period and, therefore, I think that the issue is over, in the near future, this should be introduced into the Treaty itself.

name: Paloma López Bermejo
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, as you know, but a large number of Europeans are unaware, the European Parliament is the only democratically elected institution but does not write European laws. And the reason is not coincidental. The Treaties themselves intended to prevent the working majority from being able to directly transfer their social demands on legislation, by ceding that competence to the Commission.  Moreover, even after hearing Parliament's voice, it is the governments of the States that must again approve it by showing their co-responsibility in the neoliberal and deregulatory agenda that currently dominates Europe.  The complexity and lack of legitimacy in this way of legislating and governing are at the heart of the debate today: the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are supposed to bring some clarity to the European legislative process, but it is in practice vague principles, as you yourself admit, which are interpreted to the taste of the legislature.  Let me say that the guiding principle of European politics is another: neoliberalism. I can illustrate this with examples of your own report: you are talking about subsidiarity, that national parliaments can decide sovereignly on their policies, but as soon as they start talking about the countries intervened by the troika, such precautions are forgotten.  As regards proportionality, you apply it as the Commission itself, in an openly politicised way to curb new legislative proposals that curb the erosion of workers' social rights.  (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Max Andersson
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr This report on the annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality 2012-2013 contains several good proposals to get the EU in the right direction in order to make subsidiarity control work, which is very important for strengthening democracy in the EU. It also contains a number of rather poor proposals for an excessive number of impact assessments. I will start by talking about what is problematic about this report. Impact assessments are not as easy to do as you might think. It is easy to produce figures – not necessarily accurate figures but figures – for how much it will cost a company to implement, for example, good new environmental legislation. However, it is more difficult to find out how much the socio-economic benefits are from a proposal. Impact assessments risk being skewed in the direction of doing nothing. To have impact assessments before, during and after work has been made on a proposal, as proposed in this report, is far too much of an impact assessment, and that would cause problems for the EU's ability to act. The good things in the report are about making the EU's subsidiarity control work, getting the yellow card that is not used at all to the extent that it should today. 15 of the parliaments in the EU's 28 Member States hardly use it at all. There are things that we can do here to make subsidiarity and proportionality control work. We could take and extend the time that parliaments have to do so. We could take and introduce a green card, so that parliaments have the opportunity to present their own proposals to the Commission that the Commission can look at. There is much to be done, and I hope that the next report will be even better.

name: Gerard Batten
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, this report on subsidiarity and proportionality quotes Article 5 of the Treaty, which says: ‘notionally invites consideration of whether exercise of an EU competence is necessary or could properly and effectively be done at the Member State level’. How very decent of you to actually concede that some laws should be made by democratic nation states and not the EU. Say something about subsidiarity. I might be wrong but I seem to remember about 24 or 25 years ago, when the Treaty on European Union was progressing, somebody suggested that there should be a cash prize for anybody that could actually define subsidiarity and describe how it would work in practice. As far as I know nobody ever won. Proportionality is a bit late when the EU now controls most areas of domestic policy, and most of our laws now come from the EU, down to the wattage in electric kettles, toasters and vacuum cleaners. We recently saw the British Prime Minister on his hands and knees begging the EU to allow him to reduce VAT on tampons, which is something that he is powerless to do. David Cameron’s so-called reforms include something on the yellow card, which says that Member States – not individual Member States, of course: 15 together – can stop some legislation. I would like to ridicule this but I do not have to, because it was already ridiculed by William Hague when he was Foreign Minister in parliament, when he absolutely tore this idea to pieces when it was proposed before. If you do not believe me you can see it on YouTube, and you can see David Cameron laughing away next to him. Now he has adopted exactly the same policy as one of his most mooted reforms. You are all going to get a lesson in subsidiarity and proportionality when the British people have their referendum on 23 June and when they vote to leave. They are increasingly coming to understand that the essential question is: do you want to live in a democratic state or an undemocratic state where you do not elect and cannot sack your government in Brussels?

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the yellow card procedure is the main weapon of national parliaments to force the Brussels Commission to respect the principle of subsidiarity. It obliges the Commission to reconsider a legislative proposal when it has been the subject of reasoned opinions, i.e. protests by one-third of the national parliaments of the Member States. The report notes that this yellow card has succeeded only once in persuading the Commission to abandon a proposal. It was in 2012, with regard to the scandalous Monti II proposal, which called into question the right to strike. This is a very meagre record because, the rest of the time, the Commission has rejected with some arrogance the other yellow cards. Subsidiarity is therefore a decoy. The Commission does not respect it and violates it, either directly or indirectly, through delegated acts, i.e. decree-laws to which it uses massively, as the report deplores. The report has the merit of denouncing this situation, but it disappoints by merely calling on the Commission to engage in dialogue with national parliaments and improve its impact studies. He certainly proposes to create a green card, which would allow national parliaments to make suggestions to the Commission, but this would only resurrect the placets of the Old Regime that the beggings presented to the king's delight.  It is a much more radical and much more democratic solution that should be put in place. It would create a real red card procedure that would allow each Member State to oppose a commission legislative proposal, since it considers that the proposal undermines its vital interest. This red card would be a veto that would allow each state to enforce its sovereignty. It would therefore be a first step towards the replacement of the European Union by the Europe of Nations, which I would like to call for.

text: NI). Mr President, public distrust and Euroscepticism is the result of non-compliance with the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity in EU policy-making. Obviously, it is not the peoples of Europe who are to blame, no matter how much propaganda is used.  Example Greece: the Greek people are not lazy, corrupt and dishonest. Only gullible and misled by political saltibagus and directed media, domestic and foreign. For six years he has been misled that memoranda and implementing laws are imposed to his advantage and in the light of the viability of his country, while they themselves keep exorbitant bank accounts and offshore companies. Scandals covered, lists of tax irregularities that are never investigated, sworn politicians hiding behind parliamentary immunities. How proportionate and subsidiary is this to citizens who do not have to eat or pay for their medicines? No memorandum policy and no implementing law complied with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality for Greeks. Only the principles of punishment, the banking macro-economy and the loot in private, real estate and movable property. The lies are over and together the failed right-wing and left-wing governments are ending. We as nationalists say yes to the Europe of peoples and nations, but with fairness in proportionality and subsidiarity.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: – I would like to thank my colleagues on the JURI Committee for their involvement in the drafting of this report and I would like to thank Mr Karim for an acceptable compromise. For me personally, the issue of subsidiarity and proportionality is one of the fundamental issues of the legislative process in the EU. It is a qualified way of involving national parliaments in this process, it is a useful tool in this day and age, when the relationship between the Member States and the Union is very sensitive. At the same time, the application of this principle is also not the only way in which national parliaments affect the Union legislative process. Let us recall that the Council of Ministers includes ministers who are also accountable to their national parliaments.  However, this principle is understandable to our citizens and citizens ask that we implement it. We must say that this principle is not only a kind of skrutiniem, but also a prerequisite for the successful implementation of the joint European initiatives for which we are responsible and not just a tool to block them.  As I have already said, I believe that this report represents a good compromise applicable to our future work in discussing concrete proposals.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, as you know, the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are very important and also very delicate, not only to be achieved, but above all to be balanced between them, not by chance, many colleagues have pointed this out.  But what is the result of the report we are debating? Paradoxically, all the additional forms of control introduced end up removing transparency from the processes that will be dealt with and, on the other hand, overturning what for us is the positive path, that of giving the European Union greater autonomy and power. Instead, unnecessary responsibilities are being handed over to the Member States.  So in fact this is a measure that takes us away from the objective for which we are here to represent the citizens of Europe. I would like to point out to you, among other things, not because of the responsibility of those who have worked on this issue, that we are faced with a hypothetical solution that runs counter to other measures that are under discussion at this very moment or even at this time, those we are going to deal with, we will vote on as early as tomorrow, are not consistent with the interinstitutional agreement on better regulation and have elements of strong contrast , for example with the compromises that we will be voting on REFIT.  Therefore, the direction taken is a direction which, in my opinion, absolutely and rapidly needs to be changed.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur for an excellent report. Subsidiarity and proportionality are two guiding principles of the European Union. But it is also necessary for these guiding principles to be applied and for them not to be contradicted in practical legislative work, as is repeatedly observed. What we now have before the European Parliament is the European Commission's proposal on Pan-European deposit insurance as the third pillar of the Banking Union. This Pan-European deposit guarantee does not take into account the specific structures of the European banking landscape, does not take into account savings banks and Raiffeisen funds, their deposit insurance and the institution guarantee that is associated with them. Worse still, it does not take account of the fact that economic policy is and must be different in the different states of the European Union. If states are able to create different risks for their companies through different economic policies, then a Community deposit guarantee is precisely the wrong thing, something that goes against the principle of subsidiarity, because it is an incentive to discharge risks into the bank balance sheets, because the deposit guarantee will be for it.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, subsidiarity and proportionality are basic principles for the harmonious construction of the European Union. The mechanisms put in place to respect them are now insufficient and formalistic and provide time limits for stakeholders, especially European regions with clearly insufficient legislative powers. Moreover, in some States, for example mine, the procedure for shaping the State's opinion on this issue does not guarantee that the voice of the regions, if it does not coincide with the State's point of view, is contained in the early warning reports.  If we have this gap in subsidiarity, imagine what will not happen to the substance of the issues on which it is legislate. Everything that is lost along the way, takes european institutions away from citizens and harms transparency and participation.  The experience of these years has shown that the procedure must be corrected and I believe that, as the report points out, ex ante control is not sufficient, but at least one assessment report on the ex ante functioning of EU legislation should be made from the perspective of proportionality and subsidiarity. In short, this must be taken seriously, if we really believe in a federal Europe and the concept of union and what it means: a voluntary sum of its members. And nothing better to encourage it than to treat all the institutions affected by European policies as adults.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, applying the principle of subsidiarity, when properly interpreted, means making sure that decisions are taken as close as possible to the citizens, which is extremely important and fundamental for the 5-Star Movement.  We understand very well that this is not an instrument of direct democracy, but there is no doubt that this is a principle that aims to bring the European Union closer to its citizens, ensuring respect for the sovereignty of individual Member States and the adoption of action at local level whenever necessary. We therefore welcome a report which courageously highlights both the centrality of this principle and the limitations encountered in its correct interpretation.  We particularly welcome paragraph 29 of the report, at a time when, in accordance with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, it would be appropriate for the Commission to simplify the procedure for applying for EU funds, so as to make it more efficient and meritocratic and so as to prevent cases of corruption, which very often lurk in bureaucratically complex procedures. , and we also call for clarity on the conformity with the principle of subsidiarity of the various aspects of international trade treaties, which the European Union is negotiating without the necessary transparency, including, for example, TTIP.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF).
text: – A few days after the Dutch referendum with the well-known result - two thirds of the population spoke out against a measure of the European Union - I think it would be useful to reiterate the principle in relation to subsidiarity. Ideally, subsidiarity should prevent the European Union from expanding, from grasping around itself and from appropriately entrusting itself with powers that do not belong to it or which should not be dealt with at European level.  What do we get from the JURI Commission here on our plate? A text stating - and I quote - 'that the Union may only act in the areas not covered by its exclusive competence' - and I quote again - 'if and to the extent that the objectives of the proposed action cannot be sufficiently achieved by the Member States at central, regional or local level, but because of the scale or consequences of the action envisaged, the Union can be better achieved'.  With such a phrase, colleagues, one can of course go in all directions. With such a phrase in the hands of the adepts of the European Union, we are moving towards an enlargement and further centralisation of that European Union. With such a phrase, combined with the exclusivity of the powers held by the European Union, the principle of subsidiarity, namely that powers should be exercised at the lowest possible level, is a principle that becomes dead letter.  The European Union, even in this European Parliament, is being given a blank cheque on this important principle in order to continue its plans for a federal Europe. The ever closer Union continues here again today and we can hardly stop that, unless with referendums to the Dutch example, which gives you all here as adepts of federal Europe, a moment to wake up.  The aim, namely a federal Europe with a phrase like this, justifies all means and the fact that subsidiarity turns out to be a piece of paper after all.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: – First of all, I congratulate my colleague Karim on the text that has been tabled. The reasoned opinions of national parliaments share the european citizens' initiative: to bring European policy closer to citizens and to strengthen the democratic accountability of the European institutions. However, there is another similarity. The Commission's replies to the so-called yellow cards of national parliaments are reminiscent of the response to the proposal for a European citizens' initiative, One of Us. They're a spirit of superiority. The resolution tabled in several places draws attention to the Commission's tendency to promote its own view at all costs, while at the same time simply ignoring objections from national parliaments and citizens' initiatives. A separate chapter is the own-initiative reports of this House. Many are written as if their authors had never even heard of subsidiarity and proportionality. I therefore call on Parliament's leadership to introduce stricter rules for checking compliance with the principle of subsidiarity before the vote on them in plenary. If the Commission and this Parliament do not start taking seriously the reasoned objections and proposals from below, they will permanently poison the entire European project with their formalism. And then, unfortunately, they won't care about their opinion anymore.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the debate on subsidiarity and proportionality is marred by the many Eurosceptics who tell us that Europe does not respect this principle.  The reality is that when you look at the very small number of yellow and orange cards that not only come to an end, but the very small number of those who start a procedure – because to start a procedure for violating subsidiarity you have to be able to prove that it is actually violated – this shows us that it is very rarely the case that the infringement is carried out by the Commission and that it is therefore difficult to prove its existence.  I believe that the structure of the report is somewhat marred by this concern, with the risk, by inserting too much caution, too many additional procedures, of damaging the other fundamental principle, that of simplification and better lawmaking, or of lengthening the decision-making process indefinitely. I therefore believe that some amendments are to be voted on, as they are necessary.  I would like to say a few words on the question of the green card. I believe that this is an interesting subject but one that must be included in a treaty that is not used, put into practice now, because it must be linked to the european Parliament's power of legislative initiative, otherwise this would weaken our legislative role.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in accordance with Article 4 of the Treaty on European Union, any competence which is not awarded to the Union by the Treaties belongs to the Member States. This regulation solemnly states that the presumption of competence belongs to the Member States, which retain their exclusive sovereign rights in all fields, except those in which the Treaty, on the basis of the principle of competence, conferred power of action on the institutions of the European Union, which, even when acting within the scope of the powers conferred, must respect the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality.  In Greece, the European Commission and the troika and the ECB are constantly brutally violating the principle of donor competence, as acting in areas that do not even belong to the competences of the European Union, they impose reductions in wages and pensions, increase income and property taxes, break up insurance and industrial relations and demand a sell-off of public property.  Gentlemen of the Commission, stop at last breaking the law and violating the Treaties of the European Union!

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to convey my congratulations on this agreement. Indeed, the principle of subsidiarity and the principle of proportionality are fundamental to the proper functioning of the European Union and are the starting point for European policies. There is no doubt that the principle of subsidiarity brings European policy closer to the citizen and determines when the European Union has jurisdiction to legislate. The same is true of the principle of proportionality, which makes any action by the European Union meaningful and adapts to the aim pursued. The report is important, because what it is trying to do is to ensure effectiveness and also democratic legitimacy in decision-making and, in some way, to strengthen the European project. It is true that a whole series of cards available to national parliaments have been created after the Lisbon Treaty to establish mechanisms to properly monitor the application of these principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. It should be noted that this has been carried out normally, but that it is true that all these mechanisms have to be agile, have to be really simple and have to be effective. The most important thing in these cases is cooperation between all national and European administrations and ensuring and reinforcing these two principles.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Subsidiarity should mean closer to the citizens, more democracy. Subsidiarity, however, does not mean inability to act in European legislation. We are constantly dealing with people who are quite right to ask themselves the question: how does European democracy work? The procedures are so insanely complicated. And when I look at this report now, it gets even more complicated. Many of the points in the report make the European legislative process almost impossible. Instead of a clear, transparent division of powers, the report, on the pretext of subsidiarity control, awards national parliaments the right to hinder European processes in any progress. Supporting is one thing, but hindering is, of course, a problem. Of course, national competences should not be undermined by European agents. However, the level of national control shown here is simply inefficient. Particularly in connection with the introduction of a green/red card system for national parliaments, I warn against their deliberate use as a blocking instrument, as an instrument of sabotage for good projects. And also pay attention to social dialogue. The implementation of the proposed skills adjustments could also serve as a pretext for ultimately weakening the social dialogue and the social partners. In this respect, I refer – and I am happy to advertise it – to the Kaufmann report on REFIT. In the end, much better measures are proposed here, which also mean that the principle of subsidiarity is respected much better in a democratic way and that social partners are also involved.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Dear! First of all, I congratulate the rapporteur on a very good report which stresses the need to attach greater importance to the principle of subsidiarity when creating European law. I agree with the rapporteur that we need greater involvement, real participation of national parliaments in the creation of European law, that this is the essence of democracy, that we need to expand and strengthen the tools available to the Member States through which they can influence the shape of the law being created. And here we are talking about a yellow card that already exists (the report proposes a green card, a red card). These are the tools that allow you to effectively inhibit or contribute your own contribution to the law you create. We also need a better understanding of what subsidiarity is, how to interpret the law and where the limits of the competences of the European Union and the Member States are. This report reminds us of the principle of subsidiarity, that this is the universal principle that underpins the European Union, that everything that can be done at Member State level should be done there, and only what is beyond that – at European Union level, so that what we do at European Union level is actually a bonus and brings benefits to everyone, not a corset. that emases us. It is very important to bear this principle of subsidiarity in mind, because breaching this principle undermines trust in the European Union and makes the European Union sometimes seen as a threat to independence, which is, of course, complete nonsense. Thank you very much!

name: Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In my opinion, the last six years have shown that the Lisbon system of subsidiarity as a whole has proved its worth. The mechanism works. The European institutions have paid increased attention to respect ingestion of the principle of subsidiarity, and the national parliaments have shown a very high willingness to exercise their powers. This is also reflected in the very interesting reports of COSAC.  It is a good sign of the now developed culture of subsidiarity that there were only two yellow cards of national parliaments in the direction of the Commission all the time. It is undoubtedly necessary and right to intensify the political dialogue with the national parliaments, and I am interested in that, and we should all be interested in that. At the same time, however, I would like to stress that the European Union is a multi-level political system. Its functioning is complicated. However, it will only become comprehensible and comprehensible to citizens if it is clear who is responsible for what and who is responsible for what. It is therefore important not to mix up the different competences of the different levels of action.  Especially at a time when populists of all stripes are blowing attacks on the European institutions, as recently in the Netherlands, we should disenchant the transparent trick when the different levels are deliberately pitted against each other, according to the motto: here – in quotation marks – 'the good region' and there 'the evil Europe'.
