We should not allow the reference to the principle of subsidiarity to be misused in order to weaken or even call into question our European Community under this guise. Today, more than ever, it is necessary to strengthen the European idea and the European institutions, together with the national and regional parliaments.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on his work. Over time, the European institutions and national parliaments have been concerned with identifying effective mechanisms necessary for the adoption of legislation that corresponds to both national requirements and the general interest of the European Union. Compliance with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in the legislative procedures at European Union level is the 'keystone' of a regulation that respects the needs of the European citizen as much as possible. The introduction and strengthening of procedures to assess compliance with the two principles at different stages of the decision-making process, public consultations in which stakeholders submit comments, and possible solutions to the problems identified are likely to provide added value to the legislative process. On the assumption that the two principles are the starting point for policy formulation at European level, the Commission is expected to further examine in a thorough way the extent to which they are being respected. However, a few observations are required. Throughout the legislative procedure, it should be borne in mind that impact studies cover only the initial stages of the legislative process, since legislative proposals may undergo substantial changes in the adoption process. In view of these aspects and in order to respect the interests of European citizens exactly, it is therefore necessary to carry out a check... (The President interrupted the speaker's speech.)

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Thank you very much for this report, because from when I was responsible for implementing European legislation in government proposals in the Czech Republic, I have to say that a number of proposals that were coming, or therefore already approved directives that were coming to nation states, including the Czech Republic, lacked a factual justification for the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality. The reasoning was often very formal, as is also demonstrated by the studies and analyses that we are debating here today, when the Impact Assessment Committee made it clear that for up to one third of the proposals put forward by the Commission, the justification for subsidiarity is only formal.  If today's negotiations and the approval of the document lead, Commissioner, that the Commission will assess these two principles, these two criteria of European legislation in fact factually, very intensively, then I personally will be happy. In my opinion, this is also a necessity, given the political situation in which the European Union finds its place, and I think it is in the interests of all of us, those who believe in preserving the idea of European integration, that the positions of national parliaments, in short and well, be taken into account more. And if any material receives a so-called yellow card, then I believe that the Commission should abandon such material.  This also applies to the principle of the European Prosecutor, the honourable Commissioner, who you represent here, and who received just such a yellow card in 2013.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the principles of solidarity, subsidiarity and proportionality are important. They were created to ensure a balance of powers, but also means for representing local interests. But I do not agree with what the rapporteur said. Europe must not exist only where it is needed. The European Union was created because it was necessary for peacekeeping, for better coordination between Member States, for the well-being of European citizens, for common rules, for mobility, for increasing Europe's potential. The rapporteur said not to be afraid. I'm not afraid of Europe. Unfortunately, I have the feeling that you are. I like Europe and the European Parliament, because here the voices of both are heard and the voices of our countries are equal. That is why I support the idea of increasing participation and expressing national and local views, and we need to have a better dialogue with national parliaments. But this must first be achieved through existing mechanisms and with a balance in this approach, not with populist messages.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, all policies are local, every policy is local, because every policy, including the one we run here and what we bring as regulations, has reflection and consequences on the local level, i.e. on our citizens living in a municipality, in a city, in a region.  That is why all policies are local and therefore the principle of subsidiarity is an extremely important principle for me to make the European Union more easily recognizable among our citizens because we cannot escape this fact that we have problems with the identity of European policies. Of course, not all policies can be run exclusively at the local level, this is quite clear.  We need to have a lot on a European level, but we need to be able to translate this European policy in a simple way into local politics. Then we'll have success. Otherwise, success will definitely be absent.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you very much for this interesting debate, and I thank Members for their comments and questions on this important topic. I would like to use the opportunity to react on what Mr Pospíšil said. The proposal on the European Prosecutor’s Office is quite a good example of how the current Commission works. The proposal received – I think – 11 yellow cards from the national parliaments and, as I said before, this Commission has already visited national parliaments 270 times. At least 10 of these were mine, because I did not see the Commission sending a letter to the parliament as the end of the matter. I felt it necessary to come back to these national parliaments and to explain how we modified the proposal by replacing the centralised structure with a decentralised one. The national parliaments could see that it is in my strong interest to explain and to convince them that the issue of subsidiarity has disappeared. This is merely how this works in one example: the case of the European Prosecutor’s Office. I feel it is necessary to create such a model, which will not replace national prosecution but will strengthen it. So this is another example of how we are trying to improve communication with the national parliaments and to ensure that we keep solid, mutual communication. I would like you to know that all the Commissioners remain at your service to discuss the subsidiarity and proportionality aspects of proposals tabled by the Commission, and once again I wish to thank the rapporteur and all the Members involved for an excellent report.

name: Sajjad Karim
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, may I start by thanking the Commission for its input today and indeed by putting on record the tremendous support that I have received for my ideas from Frans Timmermans. The Commission work programme also reflects that. May I thank all colleagues from all sides of the House who took part in the debate today for putting forward, on the whole, their constructive observations. I know that, in most cases, even where we have disagreement, their proposals are based upon foundations where they are putting forward a critical but positive analysis of how they feel we can best move forward. So I thank all of my colleagues for their input. I wish briefly to touch upon one or two issues. First of all, in relation to the red card: this is not a veto. It was never proposed as a veto, and it was never envisaged to be anything of the sort. But the point is that, if we have the other measures that bring national parliaments much closer to our decision-making, we will never have a need for any of our national parliaments ever to have to exercise a red card, let alone for it to be described anywhere near a veto. On subsidiarity – once again this has been raised by colleagues – we must evaluate subsidiarity mid-term and at the end, but those evaluations are not binding. They provide a measure to ensure that we have not moved so far away from the subsidiarity principle that we are carrying out work at our level that we should not be doing. My Liberal colleagues raised an issue in relation to the extension of the eight-week time period. I agree with them that any extension of the current deadline for submitting opinions on subsidiarity should indeed be incorporated into the Treaties when they are next updated. Finally, various comments were made by the extreme right of this House which were quite interesting for me, particularly from the UKIP representatives, who are not present here. They made various points, but when it came to the technical issues, there were only two, and on both they were completely wrong. They were wrong in describing the red card as a yellow card, and I am pretty sure that the British people will show them the red card very soon indeed. The majority of laws that are made in the UK do not emanate from the EU. It is 13%. That is not a majority. So I look forward to showing them the red card on 23 June.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 12 April. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: in writing. – I propose that the rapporteurs of the European Parliament consult the specialised committees in the national parliaments, in particular in the case of legislative reports. In this way, political dialogue with national parliaments on compliance with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality can be opened much earlier. On this basis, the rapporteurs of the European Parliament can better base their positions on the European Commission's legislative initiatives or on their own themes in their own-initiative reports.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the motion for a resolution, tabled by Pavel Poc, Katesina Koneen, Bas Eickhout, Piernicola Pedicini, Mark Demesmaeker, Sirpa Pietikäinen and Frédérique Ries, on behalf of the ENVI Committee, on the draft Commission implementing regulation on the renewal of the authorisation of the active substance glyphosate in accordance with Regulation (EC) No. 1107/2009 of the European Parliament and the Council on the placing on the market of plant protection products and amending the Annex to Implementing Regulation (EU) No 540/2011 (D044281-01 - 2016/2624(RSP)) (B8-0439/2016).

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, today's debate was not on the original agenda, but I think it was right to discuss, in this House, such an important issue that closely affects human and animal health and the environment, and I am therefore pleased that this debate can take place here before everyone.  In recent months, we have seen intense discussions on the European Commission's decision to renew the authorisation to use glyphosate within the regulatory framework outlined in the regulation on the placing of plant protection products on the market; the current authorization expires in June 2016. As you all know, glyphosate is an active ingredient in a selective herbicide and is currently the most globally produced herbicide; it has been used worldwide for the last forty years and is used in 76 % of cases in the agricultural sector.  The ENVI Committee of this Parliament, on whose behalf I am presenting this position today, has raised and approved the objection that we are now debating, asking the European Commission to withdraw the draft implementing regulation, not to renew the approval of glyphosate, to draw up a clear timetable for drawing up a list of coformulants that cannot be included in commercial products. The report also calls on the Commission to carry out an independent review of the classification of glyphosate in a short time, in the light of available scientific evidence of the carcinogenic potential of the substance itself, as well as the possible properties of interference on the basis of horizontal scientific criteria for endocrine disruptors.  But I would take a brief step back, in order to better understand what has happened since the Commission renewed its authorisation. In March 2015, in fact, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) classified glyphosate as likely carcinogenic to humans, based on limited evidence of carcinogenic effects on humans and sufficient evidence of tumours in laboratory animals.  In November 2015, EFSA, the European Food Safety Agency, contrary to the opinion of the IARC, completed a joint assessment of glyphosate and concluded that it is unlikely to pose a threat of cancer to humans and that the available evidence does not justify its classification of its carcinogenic potential, in accordance with the Regulation on the placing on the market of plant protection products.  In view of this situation, the ENVI Committee decided by a large majority that the precautionary principle should be applied in this case in order to ensure that active substances or products placed on the market do not have harmful effects on human or animal health or the environment. The Regulation on the placing on the market of plant protection products states that, in particular, Member States are not prevented from applying the precautionary principle where there is scientific uncertainty as to the risks to human, animal or environmental health risks to plant protection products to be authorised on their territory.  The ENVI Committee therefore considers that the Commission's draft implementing regulation does not guarantee a high level of health protection, does not apply the precautionary principle and exceeds the implementing powers laid down in the legislation. It therefore calls on the Commission to withdraw the draft regulation, calls on the Commission not to renew its approval, and calls on EFSA to disseminate all scientific evidence. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this is the position of the committee that I chair, on which you must of course express your opinion.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, allow me to recall that the right of scrutiny of the European Parliament concerns the question of whether the draft implementing act exceeds the implementing powers provided for in the basic act. In this respect I would like to point out that the draft implementing regulation for renewal of the approval of glyphosate has been processed in line with the procedures set out in Regulation No 1107/2009 and Regulation No 182/2011 on comitology. The Commission considers, therefore, that it has not exceeded its implementing powers. The Commission services have presented a draft implementing act to the standing committee in compliance with the legal framework. The Commission services are now discussing with Member States the best way forward on the renewal of the approval for glyphosate and will endeavour to find a solution which commands the widest possible support among the Member States. The current draft implementing act is therefore likely to be amended and should not be considered as a decision from the Commission. Before Members express their position on this draft resolution, I would like to recall a few important points that were raised when this was discussed in Parliament’s Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. The draft regulation includes a firm commitment to review the approval if the European Chemicals Agency process leads to a classification relevant for the approval. Second, the Commission has started working on co-formulants. The current draft, if adopted, would not allow the placing on the market of glyphosate-containing products containing the co-formulant tallowamine. Third, the Commission has called on the industry to publish the regulatory studies submitted by companies. I refer here to the letter that Commissioner Andriukaitis recently sent to the glyphosate taskforce. The Commission services have received the response of the applicants and are now clarifying the details with them.

name: Angélique Delahaye
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, on form, I would like to point out that this is an objection to an act of execution and, therefore, that it will have no legal consequences. However, this issue is one of the concerns of citizens and, at the same time, the agricultural world is going through an unprecedented crisis. In Europe, many farmers use glyphosate in most plant production. Glyphosate is fundamental to weeding strategies. To date, however, there is no economically viable alternative to offer farmers that will ensure that there are no consequences for human health. For all these reasons, we must be a force for proposal so that the current deadlock between the Member States and the Commission can find a way out. I would also like to point out that we have a procedure for approving substances that we, the co-legislators, have decided and voted for. In this regard, the procedure was followed. In addition, in the event of new information, the Commission can always reverse its authorisation, and we are also waiting for the analysis of the gap by the end of 2017. In view of these elements, I have proposed amendments, on behalf of the EPP Group, limiting authorisation over time, asking the Commission and the Member States to speed up their work on the list of coformulants to be banned, such as tallow amine, and proposing to the Commission framework measures for The Member States. I also want to strengthen research and innovation in order to find alternatives to the use of glyphosate. I count on all my colleagues to approve these proposals. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Susanne Melior (S&D)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the Madam President, you have just raised a number of points that are important in relation to glyphosate and the use. You did not mention that, of course, we also import feed from third countries. This is also a point that needs to be discussed in this context. I would like to ask you whether you should not vote against the continued use of glyphosate in both food and feed because of the precautionary principle in the European Union.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer. Colleagues, I hope I understand your question from the transcript. I think there needs to be a more advanced debate on this issue before we take a firm and definitive position.

name: Pavel Poc
text: on the part of the S&D Group. That's just terrible.  Perhaps we should revise the whole process of so-called comitology, an incomprehensible decision-making process that is leaving the European Union to its citizens.  Glyphosate manufacturers once claimed that residues do not remain after its use. It was a lie. The residues are full of our environment, our food and ourselves. In the United States, the Food and Drug Administration will begin testing the glyphosate content of food this year. Our resolution calls on the European Commission to follow in the interests of the security of European citizens.  We are similarly convinced that glyphosate is not dangerous to human health. The European Food Safety Authority bases its recommendations on several so-called key but classified studies funded by whom? Industry. But the International Agency for Research on Cancer and dozens and dozens of independent scientists are bringing more and more evidence that glyphosate can be the cause of a number of health disorders and is probably an endocrine disruptor. The European Union wants to fight antibiotic resistance, glyphosate has been patented as an antibiotic. Only this Parliament is interested. We are aware of the sad fact that European agriculture cannot recover from its dependence on glyphosate.

name: Julie Girling
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, my Group will robustly rebut this resolution: we will not be voting for it. I could give you a long speech on the use of glyphosate and how important it is to agriculture. I do not have time for that, so let me just concentrate on what I see as the failures in the resolution. The resolution states, as part of its justification, that residues of glyphosate have been found in soil and water; well, yes, they have. But, as the German Federal Risk Institute tells us, they have been found in quantities at less than 1% of the daily acceptable rate. It also states that residues have been found in food. Again, this is not about hazard, this is about risk, and they are at levels way below those which are acceptable to human health. So why does this form such an upfront part of this resolution when it is frankly irrelevant? It also says, in Recital J, that the current proposal has no restrictions on use. That is not the case. The draft implementing regulation clearly states that regulatory measures to identify co-formulants must be developed. It is already there in the draft regulation. So before we even think about the use of glyphosate and its value to us, we really ought to get our facts right. And where we talk about the precautionary principle, once again: the precautionary principle as enshrined in EU law is to take care of cases where there is not any scientific advice. There is a plethora of scientific advice here. That is one of the problems: that we have to choose between our own European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) advice and the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), and I see no reason to move away from EFSA.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I am lucky that I checked when the public debate would be in plenary, because I just found out that it is now! But my own process was as difficult as the whole process of the authorisation by the Commission, because let us be clear: what kind of process is it when a Commissioner, after tabling the authorisation, sends letters to the biggest industrial giant in this area asking for more transparency? So there have been huge difficulties and yes, we have EFSA, we have a strong role in our decision-making process in Europe, and we count on EFSA, and EFSA is relatively clear in its statement. So my Group believes that we should look very closely at what EFSA is saying. But EFSA is not saying anything about the amount of time – the number of years – that we should go for. Therefore we have just tabled an amendment, as the Liberal Group, in which we call on the Commission to renew the approval of glyphosate with a maximum of five years, and to take into account any new evidence up to that time which proves that it is more dangerous than we previously thought, in which case the authorisation should be withdrawn. That is what we just tabled 20 minutes ago, and I hope that you can follow that line during the plenary vote.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: "blue card" question to Congresswoman Julie Girling. – Yes, I wanted to ask Mrs Girling that question, but I think it is part of the debate that if there is so much resistance to the use of glyphosate – I note, by the way, that the world's agriculture uses about half as much glyphosate as the total cocoa crop, so it is a very large quantity – are there no alternatives? That's the only solution: glyphosate? I think there are alternatives, and that's what we should be working on.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – If I understood that correctly, this was a question about the use of glyphosate and – did you say cocoa? I am sorry but it did not come across very well in the translation. Yes, there are many aspects of agriculture – some of them much closer to home than cocoa – in the European Union that rely very heavily on the use of glyphosate. In some cases there is resistance, and that is why we have a Sustainable Use Directive which lays out very clearly for farmers exactly how products such as glyphosate should be used and, if resistance is detected, what steps they should take. So I am perfectly confident that resistance can be dealt with, so no, I do not have a problem with that. We really do need glyphosate.

name: Merja Kyllönen (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, according to the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) in March 2015, glyphosate was probably classified as a cancer-at-risk substance for humans. In addition, there is clear evidence that glyphosate acts as a hormone disruptor.  According to advertisements, glyphosate breaks down in nature in a couple of weeks. However, recent studies have shown that glyphosate and its degradation products, in particular AMPA, can bind to the soil and continue to flow to other parts of the environment. The risks are especially high in cold climates, where soil processes are slow. Evidence of rapid degradation of glyphosate is based on warm conditions and tests carried out on them. We need research into how glyphosate breaks down, persists and also affects a colder ecosystem before blindly authorising us to continue current practices.

name: Martin Häusling (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Yes, it is good that we are talking about glyphosate today, because the substance is at the centre of the debate, partly because it concerns a principle that is almost sacred to us as Europeans: the precautionary principle. There is a suspicion of cancer that has not yet been dispelled, and no one has said that, but the World Health Organisation has said that it is in the room and it is not clear.  There is a massive loss of biodiversity in the use of this agent, which is still applied to 40 percent of the land and has increased by 70 percent in the last 10 years, and glyphosate is now detectable everywhere, in beer, in cereals and also in us. And I don't care about Mrs Girling, we don't have to argue about limit values, the substance simply doesn't belong there. That is why we really need to think seriously about whether we are not looking at alternatives firstly and, secondly, whether we accept that, after a long discussion process, a Commission should make a proposal that says that it must be extended by 15 years, with no restrictions. No restrictions mean: it may be used before harvesting, it may be used by any layman, and it may be used for purely economic reasons: the farmer saves 100 euros. This raises the fundamental question: can economic reasons be valued higher than ecological or health reasons? Therefore, this substance may not be extended in the authorisation.  And one more sentence on the Commissioner's transparency initiative: so sorry to do so afterwards and then ask the companies, that is a sign of poverty. There is a general transparency in the procedures. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Peter Liese (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Häusling, you said that the Commission has not proposed any restrictions. However, there are now amendments – for example from the PPE- and the PPE- And would you approach this request, also in view of the fact that if the resolution goes through in this way and glyphosate is immediately banned, perhaps even more toxic substances may be used? That cannot be in the interests of the Greens.

name: Martin Häusling (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Liese, I would like to thank Mr Liese for his work on this I think that the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has already taken a major step forward. After the debates in the Committee on Agriculture and Development, this is an important step. But I think we have to put the emphasis on it: there are not only chemical alternatives to glyphosate. In the vast majority of cases – I say 90 per cent of the time – the use of glyphosate can be replaced as an alternative by mechanical measures, ploughing or even weed control with the hoe. The question is therefore whether we will really allow such a means to continue to be fully applied. This is a matter of principle. This question of principle, I said, is about the precautionary principle. (The speaker agreed to answer another question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Pilar Ayuso (PPE)
text: "blue card" question. – Can you tell me how much farming measures cost and how much they mean in greenhouse emissions?

name: Martin Häusling (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mrs President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her report I manage a farm organically, and I would like to invite you to really look at the measures that are possible as an alternative to glyphosate on a farm that has not used glyphosate for 30 years. It is feasible, and it is an alternative.

name: Eleonora Evi
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too am involved in this debate, because it is important that we be able to talk about it today in the run-up to Wednesday's vote. The renewal of the authorisation of glyphosate must be stopped and must be stopped because, in particular, there can be no question of renewing the authorisation at a time when the two largest scientific agencies do not agree on this point. We need a joint table in order to reach a common position, without which these European institutions cannot consider renewing the authorisation of glyphosate. Furthermore, we have already said in this House the danger of endocrine disruptors and the fact that ECHA – here we are missing another agency that has yet to give its opinion – which will have to give its position in the coming months. Before this position it is unthinkable to make a decision on any renewal of glyphosate.  Finally, the environmental impact, the environmental impact on the environment, especially on aquatic organisms, must be studied, monitored, as well as that on human health.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank my colleagues for this very important debate. The correspondence I received on this has been quite interesting. There has been quite a large lobby to ban glyphosate, and we respect those who emailed us in that regard. But in recent days I have been getting emails from individual farmers – and I welcome those emails – not from the farm organisations, but from individual farmers – talking to me about how vital glyphosate is for them when they are practising conservation agriculture and trying to reduce their carbon footprint in a sustainable way that is positive for the environment. I think it is very easy to call for a ban on the chemical, because chemicals raise concerns among our citizens. We need to reflect on exactly what is before us here. There are two, apparently different, scientific assessments. But in fact one – the EFSA position – looks at the risks, while the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) looks at the hazards. We need to differentiate between both of those. The position of our group – the EPP – is, in my view, very measured. We very much want to make sure the products are safe, but we do not want an outright ban. We support re-registration of this product, but not for 15 years. We want actions taken if there is, in the future, evidence where there are concerns about it. Let us not ignore the voices that talk to us, but let us listen to all of the voices that lobby on this important issue.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. We are talking about glyphosate and today we have referred to it as a plant protection product. It is not a plant protection product, it is a total herbicide, it kills plants. It is therefore not a weed killer, because it does not really make any difference between weeds and cultivated plants. This difference only makes it if this crop is RR-compatible, i.e. if Monsanto or anyone else has succeeded in planting an enzyme in the plant that makes it resistant to this toxic rain. In other words, I believe that we have already agreed relatively clearly today that glyphosate is suitable for damaging the human body, whether it is carcinogenic or hormone-altering. And, of course, it is a question of risk. In other words, how often are we exposed to this risk of injury, this potential for damage? If we simply deny that there is a multiple confrontation with glyphosate, then we can agree to authorisation. If we believe that there is both a risk and a great potential for damage, then we must prevent authorisation from being extended here. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: A question raised by raising a blue card. – Dear colleague, I have been a fruit grower since 1986 and for about 25 years I have also used glyphosate as one of the herbicides in fruit growing, the wine growing where it is most commonly used. Believe me, it is best to get to the bottom of this with the truth. Above all, I think that this preparation is about 40 years of use, and at 40 years of use there is no longer any need to identify only preventive and cautious measures...  (The Speaker's Chair interrupted.)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Bogovic, I would like to thank mr Bogovic for his The point of the 'blue card' procedure is that you ask your colleague a question, not that you are giving the speech that you would have liked to have given in the catch-the-eye procedure. Mrs Kadenbach, I am afraid that there is nothing to answer. That is why we are now continuing in the list of speakers.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: Mr President! The fact of the matter is that the WHO panel of experts has classified glyphosate as likely to be carcinogenic and that EFSA concludes that glyphosate hardly poses a risk to humans. These are two very different assessments of the drug glyphosate, and that is precisely at the heart of this case - that we have two very different assessments. In this light, I find it worrying if we allow an extension of the round-up licence for another 15 years when there are two so-widely different assessments of the substance. I therefore urge the European Commission to put human health before money. We need to get the drug glyphosate fully studied before we grant an extension of the licence for another 15 years. We can't be anything else familiar. It may be that it may then be difficult to find alternatives, but we need to look into this. We cannot ignore who's concerns.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: For the catch-the-eye procedure that follows, I have to tell you that I have more messages than I can count in the short time available. So I cannot accept all of them and ask for leniency because of the subsequent debates and the Members who speak in these debates. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – I voted in favour of having a debate on this point, because I believe that citizens should know what we are voting on here.  Assessing, authorising chemicals used in agriculture that affect human health is a key priority and I believe that it is also a top priority for the European Commission, which decides on this as a matter of priority, and is also a crucial priority for the Member States. I therefore requested the opinion of the Ministry of Agriculture and the Environment of the Czech Republic, which were consulted, who participated in the decision-making process and who recommended that we, as Members, support the opinion of the European Commission.  I will also vote in favour of the amendments of the European People's Party, which, of course, have the security aspect as their priority, and propose, for example, to reduce the permitted period to 7 years.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I think it is very opportune that there should be this debate, because there is uncertainty and it is therefore appropriate to clarify some aspects. I think it is serious for a colleague to say that there are different agencies with different opinions. No. The European Food Safety Authority, EFSA, which, whether we like it or not, is our European food safety authority, has said that there is no risk as to the active substance. So has the German Federal Institute for Risk Assessment, and then we have the International Agency for Cancer Research, which said it foresees risks with regard to the final product, the final herbicide. Therefore, there is uncertainty. Obviously, it is a product widely used by farmers, but that is not the argument. The argument is whether or not we believe our food safety authority. I prefer to believe our security system than others. Therefore, if there are doubts, let's solve them. But, of course, the objection is not timely.

name: Richard Ashworth (ECR).
text: – Mr President, this House has a duty to ensure that public food is safe and that the environment is responsibly managed, and we must take those responsibilities very seriously indeed. But on the other hand, we must also ensure that decisions we make are strictly proportionate to risk, not to hazard, and we must be aware of the consequences of those decisions. In the case of glyphosate – a product which is endorsed by the Food Standards Agency as safe and for which there is no immediate substitute – for the industry to achieve the same effects, it would have to revert to more traditional mechanical operations. I could not disagree more with some of the comments which were made earlier about mechanical operations. We would have to revert to greater use of other agrochemicals and, in consequence, we would add considerably to the costs of an industry that is already under great difficulty. This House must be guided by the facts and common sense, not emotion. I urge the Commission to renew approval.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, the International Agency for Research on Cancer has included glyphosate in the category of substances that are likely to be carcinogenic. A meta-analysis of epidemiological studies of workers who used herbicide in their work showed an increased risk in them of B-cell lymphoma.  Multinational companies, on the other hand, reduce the danger of glyphosate to health because they still want to sell GMO which is only competitive with the application of this herbicide. In my view, we must take the decision to extend the authorisation of the use of glyphosate in compliance with the precautionary principle. The distortion of this principle undermines the right of citizens, and in this case farmers, to live healthy lives in a healthy environment as well as to their safety in work.  After consultations with experts that a more detailed analysis of the effects of glyphosate on human health can be done within a year, and aware of the extent of the use of glyphosate as an active substance in agriculture, I propose to reject this proposal from the European Commission.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – Thank you, President. The European Commission is not committed to change on glyphosate, which is why Parliament's role here is particularly important. The Commission's action shows that, in its view, problems with glyphosate do not exist, even before the scandals that have arisen in Europe as a result of German beer, not to mention studies carried out by scientists on the possible harm to the human body of glyphosate. On the other hand, of course, a complete ban on glyphosate is still premature. Today, agriculture is already experiencing a crisis, with cereal prices reaching historic lows. By banning the use of glyphosate, we will put farmers in an unenviable situation, so it would be most rational today to extend the use of glyphosate for a couple of years and to strengthen the rules for the use of glyphosate, considering that glyphosate spraying fields is not always safe, for example before harvesting. It is therefore reasonable to invest time and funds in the search for alternatives of similar quality and the corresponding education of farmers. Thanks.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me repeat that the point at issue in this debate is whether the draft implementing act exceeds the implementing powers provided for in the basic act. As I said before, the draft implementing regulation for renewal of the approval of glyphosate is consistent with the relevant regulations. The Commission considers, therefore, that this falls within its implementing powers. The Commission services will continue to discuss with Member States the best way forward on the renewal of glyphosate, seeking a solution which commands the widest possible support among Member States. The draft implementing act is therefore likely to be amended.

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I must stress the usefulness of this debate, which has enabled us, in the presence of all our fellow Members, to be able to express our positions each other.  We have seen that there are very different positions within Parliament, as has already been pointed out in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, but today is the time to look for possible solutions as well. We have heard, in this House, the proposal for a number of amendments from the political groups, which could balance, on the one hand, the need for a renewal of the authorisation, but, on the other hand, obviously be able to give guarantees more quickly on the actual and not presumed, possibly, carcinogenicity of the product.  One thing is certain, however, and we must all be aware of this, and that is the importance that this product widely used in agriculture today has as a herbicide and that, obviously as some of my fellow Members have said, it could only be replaced by mechanical interventions, that is, manual or mechanical mowing which, objectively, if, on the one hand, are technically possible, on the other hand, would certainly undermine the competitiveness of our production system. So tomorrow and in the next few days we will be voting on this issue again, and I call on everyone to reflect more widely.  On the other hand, another element that has emerged and which I would like to highlight briefly is the role of the Food Safety Agency: it is the technical instrument available to the European Union. And, as Mr Aguilera said, it is certainly the instrument that we have at our disposal and that we should also trust in our assessments, otherwise I do not know what the agencies that weigh on Europe's budget should be for.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: At the end of the debate, a motion for a resolution was tabled by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 12 April. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. Glyphosate is an active substance widely used among herbicides. In 2000, at the end of the patent, it was marketed by multiple companies and several hundred plant protection products containing glyphosate are currently registered in Europe for use in the agricultural sector.  In March 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) classified glyphosate as "probably carcinogenic to humans" on the basis of "limited evidence" of carcinogenic effects in humans, "sufficient evidence" of tumours in laboratory animals, as well as "solid evidence" of mechanistic data concerning the carcinogenicity of "pure" glyphosate and glyphosate-containing formulas. Nevertheless, in November 2015, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) completed an assessment of glyphosate and concluded that glyphosate is unlikely to pose a threat of cancer to humans and that the available evidence does not justify its classification of its carcinogenic potential in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1272/2008.  The 5-Star Movement does not intend to renew the authorisation of glyphosate until there is a single ruling on the absence of carcinogenic risk and ECHA has also ruled on the likely endocrine disrupting properties of the active substance, an assessment expected by 2017.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. Mr President, banning glyphosate, without accompanying measures or medium- and long-term vision, would have both a damaging impact on the agriculture sector already in crisis and counterproductive in terms of health and environmental security.  Together with my colleagues in the EPP Group, we are proposing a series of amendments to the draft resolution, in order to preserve the competitiveness of the agricultural sector and ensure a high level of health security. Our proposals aim to reduce the length of authorisation from 15 to 7 years, in order to take into account the lack of consensus among scientists, but also the time it takes for agricultural professionals to adapt to possible regulatory changes. Glyphosate is now an indispensable product for various types of cultivation, we cannot ban it without offering farmers technically and economically viable alternatives.  Aware of the current concerns and uncertainties, however, I am in favour of stricter supervision of the use of glyphosate, limiting it to professionals, strengthening the training of farmers and prohibiting its use before harvest. Finally, we must be able to review the authorisation at any time if new scientific evidence justifies the banning of the product. Thank you.

name: Esther Herranz García (PPE)
text: in writing. – I think it is important that the European Parliament does not disallow the opinion of a Union body such as the European Food Safety Authority. The possible ban on the use of glyphosate not only puts many farmers in enormous trouble at the absence of an alternative solution, but also favours imports from third countries using pesticides prohibited from use within the territory of the Union.  We need to ensure that consumer health is preserved, but before we take such a drastic measure as withdrawing the authorisation of this substance, we would have to make sure that there are well-founded scientific reasons and that there are no intermediate solutions that could be put in place to reduce the potential risks of glyphosate.  It is clear that the International Cancer Research Agency has conducted a laboratory assessment very different from the approach taken by the Food Safety Authority, based more on the actual impact of glyphosate on the ground. At this rate, we will end all kinds of phytosanitary treatment, leaving the supply of food in Europe at the mercy of imports from third countries. In my view, not only will the European farmer lose, but also the consumer.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Commission's proposal to renew for 15 years the approval of the use of glyphosate (a substance contained in the Round up) is not acceptable due to concerns about its use in the composition of agricultural and household products.  The European Parliament's Committee on the Environment has taken up this issue and part of the scientific community has highlighted probable health risks when using products - widespread - containing glyphosate. Today, in the plenary session of Parliament, this objection has unfortunately not been accepted and I regret it. A majority of MPs supported a seven-year renewal agreement. I objected. By granting this "half-white seing" to the Commission, the European Parliament is sending the wrong signal. It is now up to the Commission and then the States to take into account the reluctance expressed.  Today I call for a reformulation of the proposal taking into account the potential dangerousness of this substance, while allowing a sustainable transition for farmers and alternative products economically and ecologically responsible. Thank you for your attention.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – More and more evidence and independent studies on the risks of glyphosate to the environment, biodiversity and human health: toxicity, carcinogenic and reproductive effects, mutagenic action and residues in food. WHO calls it "probably carcinogenic". It should also be recalled that Monsanto has placed on the market genetically modified soya resistant to glyphosate (the active substance of the herbicide which it itself markets). And someone should also explain why before these GMOs the residual maximum limit of glyphosate in soybeans in Europe and the United States was 0.1 mg/kg and from 1996 it raised it to 20 mg/kg. Was it the studies and evidence of companies, perhaps, that determined to raise this limit? I wonder: what else has to happen for the European Commission to react and apply the precautionary principle and not renew the authorisation of glyphosate? Have you forgotten about the mad cow scandal yet? Farmers and farmers are the first interested in ensuring food security. Stop using us as an excuse to protect interests contrary to our own. Get to work on the alternatives, which, as you well know, exist.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Only the outright removal of this product dangerous to the citizen will be a real satisfaction. One wonders why some governments, including the Belgian government, are positioning themselves in favour of the authorisation of glyphosate. There are serious suspicions about this product, which is likely to cause cancers and hormonal problems and is dangerous for development. It has been the subject of numerous studies highlighting the toxicity of its side effects as well as the link between exposure to glyphosate and the development of autism in children. WHO has classified the herbicide as probable carcinogens. It is understandable that Monsanto is doing everything possible to allow glyphosate, as its withdrawal would reduce the multinational's profits. But when there is a danger to our citizens, it is our duty, ladies and gentlemen, to uphold the precautionary principle! I cannot accept that a product that poses serious potential risks to the health of Europeans remains on the market. There is still a month left for the States that have remained blind to this fact to finally join us in this fight for the safety of European citizens.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann's report on the Regulatory Efficiency and Performance Programme (REFIT): Inventory and Outlook (2014/2150(INI)) (A8-0208/2015).

name: Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the Ladies and gentlemen, the reason for this own-initiative report is the Commission's 2014 communication on the programme to ensure the efficiency and efficiency of legislation, abbreviated REFIT. Unfortunately, some time has already passed since then. REFIT has been around since 2012. In May last year, the Commission presented its comprehensive reform package on better regulation, and we now have a new interinstitutional agreement between the Commission, Parliament and the Council. The REFIT programme plays a central role in the work of the Commission and will also play a role in the cooperation of the institutions in the legislative process. It is therefore high time that our House finally took a position on this programme.  Let me highlight some aspects of the report, which was adopted by a large majority in the Committee on Legal Affairs. It is good that Vice-President Frans Timmermans has been entrusted with the Better Regulation business. This was and is a strong political signal to the citizens of the Union, who perceive our European Union as too bureaucratic. Citizens rightly expect something to change. The report rightly emphasises that better regulation is not, at its core, about the mere number of EU laws, not about the question of more or less legislation. What matters is their quality, and I would remind you that a European standard usually replaces 28 standards, which in fact leads to less bureaucracy and at the same time strengthens the common judicial area and the common market.  Dialogue with citizens, social partners, stakeholders from all sectors of civil society helps to ensure that EU legislation is transparent, effective and coherent. In the report, we therefore attach great importance to the Commission taking sufficient account of the views of all stakeholders when consulting. Balance and transparency are also needed when it comes to the various comments made on the Commission's website under the new heading: 'Burden reduction – Tell your mind', which will be examined by the newly created REFIT platform. It is still too early to assess the REFIT platform, but the Commission can be sure that Parliament will follow this process closely.  My report also emphasises that impact assessments play an important role in legislation. There have been very much heated discussions in this House about how they should be done and when by whom. In this respect, the report makes it clear that the new Regulatory Scrutiny Board must not issue binding opinions to the Commission. This must continue to be the case in the future, because the Commission, as the executive, has political responsibility. It has to decide and it must assume its responsibilities. Impact assessments are simply not a substitute for political decisions, and as far as agreements concluded by the social partners are concerned, the autonomy of the social partners naturally applies.  The report rightly pays great attention to reducing administrative burdens, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the backbone of the economy. Here, too, the same applies to many things, as in other things: the EU is not a company, and good EU legislation cannot be reduced to operational cost-benefit calculations. That is why the report emphasises that the reduction of administrative burdens for SMEs must not lead to a questioning of workers' rights or perhaps even to fragmentation of the internal market for SMEs.  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, last but not least, Parliament will continue to pay close attention to the issue of REFIT. I would like to thank all my fellow Members for their good cooperation and cooperation in committee, especially, of course, the shadow rapporteurs.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, rapporteur, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I would just like to say very briefly that the REFIT programme is really a good programme, that it is to be welcomed that the Commission is also withdrawing concrete proposals. This is a first of the Juncker Commission, and that can only be supported. I have one point that I would like to raise, which is the issue of impact assessment. For many years, including in the course of better legislation, we in Parliament have put a great deal of effort into ensuring that the proposals, including amendments that came from Parliament, are subject to a proper legislative impact assessment. We must once again encourage the Commission and call for it to become even more ambitious. There is this regulatory scrutiny committee. As a group, we once wanted to set up an independent standards control council, just as many Member States have it, and it is the case here in Germany, in the Netherlands, in the United Kingdom, that is where it works. What the Commission is now doing with the Regulatory Scrutiny Committee is a step backwards, and I simply ask that we continue to do so in terms of the independence of this legislative institution. We will do this from Parliament.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: Thank you, Mr. President. I, too, want to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on this document. Appropriate and functional regulation through the REFIT programme is essential in order to increase transparency and improve decision-making. Entrusting a portfolio on good regulation to the first Vice-President of the Commission is, in this respect, a response to the requests made by the European Parliament.  In the face of increasing red tape and declining confidence in the European Union, I believe it is important to strengthen civic dialogue and social dialogue in particular. In this respect, strengthening the role of institutions such as the Committee of the Regions or the European Economic and Social Committee is a priority also mentioned in this report. I would therefore also welcome the extension of the public consultation period to 12 weeks in advance, during and after the legislation was drafted. In greater legislative coherence, however, we need to ensure, however, that the Member States implement the legislation, but above all that citizens understand it, approve it and are very well informed.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, as professor of European Union institutions at the University of Crete, I have always, and continue to pay, great importance to the role of the Commission, because the Commission is the guardian of the application of Community law. The Commission has the tools to enable it to assess the efficiency and appropriateness of the legislative work produced by the institutions. These tools must, of course, be improved.  However, the Commission is not doing the same, Mrs Jurovà, as a member of the troika in Greece. Because that is where the conflict of interest arises. There, the Commission acts purely as a representative of the lenders and I will give you an example. At the moment, the troika in Greece is pushing for measures to be taken on the pension, on the level of pensions, on the reduction of supplementary pensions, and I ask: with what competence does the Commission intervene? Pension matters fall within the exclusive competence of the Member States. You do the same with the tax policy you impose on Greece. Therefore, there, as a member of the troika, you are out of your powers.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, we are all fully aware that the European Union is over-bureaucratic. The Vice-President of the European Commission himself, Mr Timmermans, spoke about it here in Parliament, and not just once.  However, what we are really doing to simplify procedures and to truly be clearer with our legislation to citizens, especially those who are in some way the clients of the European Union, I think first of all about many SMEs. I would like to highlight in particular, among other things, the problem of the complicated use of various sources of funding from the European Union.  There really is a forest of regulations that we kind of need, because we have to have rules. However, this forest of regulation is purely impassable for many who really need financial assistance from the European Union. In this context, I also call for simplification of the rules.

name: Andrey Novakov (PPE).
text: – Mr President, REFIT was designed to be a firewall and watchdog since 2012. The programme implemented over 200 actions and contributed to savings for businesses and individuals, which is great. However, this motion for a resolution does not cover very obvious items. The idea is to go simple, right? But there are 65 key documents on REFIT, so it is not that simple or user-friendly. The Commission work programme for 2016 includes 40 REFIT initiatives, but not that many of them concern the reduction of the administrative burden for beneficiaries of EU funding. At the same time, original investments through the EU budget for the period 2014-2020 total over EUR 250 billion. Billions of those euros are absorbed by bureaucracy in the process of application, management and control of EU-funded projects. In November 2015, 92% of the MEPs in this Chamber voted in favour of a resolution for cutting red tape, but few of those priorities are implemented in the resolution. I support the Commission in that initiative, but when things are not going as planned more concrete action is required. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Ms Kaufmann for the report on REFIT. The conclusions of the report are a strong encouragement for the Commission’s work in this area and also for me personally. Making EU law more effective and efficient, reducing the costs of its application and working with Member States to ensure that it is implemented well: this is a task for all European institutions. Our success in this area will make a positive contribution to growth and jobs and, therefore, help to fight the ‘EU fatigue’ we are too often confronted with. This common endeavour is reflected in the interinstitutional agreement for better law-making which you approved on 8 March 2015. The report we are discussing today dates from before that agreement, so many of the issues it raises have in fact already been resolved between us. The Commission adopted the better regulation package on 19 May 2015 with a view to ensuring an effective and efficient regulatory environment for businesses as well as for other stakeholders. The package included several measures, one of which, the new Regulatory Scrutiny Board, is already in place. Half of its members are external to the Commission, and its prerogatives have also been extended to cover the review of ex-post evaluations. This includes new comprehensive guidelines and tools to cover the application of better regulation throughout the entire policy cycle. It means planning, impact assessments, legal drafting, implementation, monitoring and evaluation as well as stakeholder consultation. This is the first time that such integrated guidance has been prepared in the Commission. A new REFIT platform has been established. A first meeting took place in January, and I hope that first results can be presented by the summer. Our new interinstitutional agreement on better law-making includes a number of important achievements. On implementing acts and delegated acts, the proposed approach should facilitate future discussions between the co-legislators and reassure them. The Commission will also provide greater transparency by allowing stakeholders to see the text of delegated acts and implementing acts before they are adopted. On annual and multiannual programming, the interinstitutional agreement provides for intensive cooperation between the institutions in setting priorities through annual and multiannual programming and on identifying the priority files for the legislative procedure. On regulatory fitness, each new act will set out how the legislation will be monitored and evaluated in the future so that we can check whether it is working as planned. The Commission’s regulatory fitness programme will also play a central role in simplifying the body of existing legislation and reducing unnecessary regulatory burdens but without weakening any of our important social or environmental goals. On transparency, in some cases working jointly across the institutions to build common IT platforms for delegated acts – and later perhaps for the codecision procedure – will help open up decision-making to public scrutiny. After formal adoption, the Commission will immediately start working with Parliament and the Council to ensure the timely and effective implementation of this agreement so that together we can start delivering even better legislation for citizens.
