name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The REFIT programme, relating to better eu law--taking and regulatory efficiency, is an important step towards simplification and a significant reduction in the regulatory burden for SMEs, which account for 80% of jobs created in Europe. However, it should be borne in mind that any changes to legislation should be thoroughly considered, including in the long term.  Too hasty simplification of administrative obligations in the areas of data protection, consumer product safety and public procurement can have a negative impact on civil liberties and workers' rights. I agree with the rapporteur that it is necessary for workers to have the right to protection of safety and health at work and minimum conditions of employment, regardless of the company in which they are employed.  Furthermore, an important aspect of the REFIT programme is the analysis of the Commission's impact assessment, which should include an assessment of the social and environmental consequences of non-legislation and its impact on citizens' fundamental rights. In addition, ex-post control needs to be improved throughout the legislative process and for transparency, predictability and legal certainty at Union level.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We have heard many times that the Commission does not wish to attack the level of social, environmental, or consumer protection. That what you want is to legislate better, in a clearer, simpler, more transparent and more informed way. And in these statements that are nothing more than propaganda this report falls abundantly. Let's be clear. The debate on reducing bureaucracy and improving legislation fulfils a dual objective: first, to create an unfavourable climate towards public intervention; second, to favour technocratic institutions and employers' interests in the development of legislation. It is no coincidence that it is the most social rights protection initiatives that are withdrawn, as is the case with the Maternity Directive or the lack of labour health legislation. It is no coincidence that expert groups are normalized to take the place of elected representatives when deciding whether a regulation is outdated or necessary. We must escape instrumental debates and say that the problem of European legislation is not its complexity, but its systematic attack on the rights of European workers.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of Anneleen Van Bossuyt's report on "Towards better regulation for the Single Market" (2015/2089(INI)) (A8-0278/2015).

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt
text: Rapporteur. I am pleased that I am finally able to present the report on better regulation in the internal market today. It's been a long-term process.  The least we can say today is that the European Union is in choppy waters. We have the euro crisis, the refugee crisis, the security crisis, Brexit, Grexit and last week's referendum in the Netherlands. I would therefore like to say that the time to walk around Europe with blinkers and see 'More Europe' as a solution to all this is over! When people ask me 'What can Europe do to reconnect with its citizens?' I invariably reply that Europe has a responsibility to demonstrate its relevance. It is only if Europe can show that it matters that people will see its added value.  It is therefore a shared responsibility of the European institutions to be guided by this principle, translated into the principle of subsidiarity, when deciding whether or not to act, to decide how best to act when regulations are needed, and ultimately to ensure that the regulations adopted are simple and easily applicable. This is therefore the starting point of the report on better regulation in the internal market. The single market, which is one of the cornerstones of European cooperation.  It is therefore important that the legislation adopted is also implemented and transposed by the Member States. In order to facilitate the achievements of the internal market and also to exploit the challenges of the single digital single market, the institutions must show determination. If not, efforts to achieve better regulation may be thwarted by regulatory drive. Implementing legislation in a simple and effective way and also constantly evaluating the legislation to ensure that the objectives are achieved, that is the message.  Improving the regulation of the internal market does not mean abolishing regulation, but rather creating a competitive regulatory environment that keeps jobs and businesses in Europe. A single market that does not frustrate production, innovation and trade, but stimulates it. Dare to ask questions, dare to be critical, without taboos. In this way, we are committed to a strong and dynamic internal market that contributes to long-term growth in Europe and therefore to the prosperity of European citizens. That is what I had in mind with this report. I therefore hope to be able to count on your vote in tomorrow's vote.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur very much for an excellent report. Better regulation is a roadmap to a better-functioning single market. Better single market rules are not about diminishing workers’ or consumer rights; they are about about diminishing bureaucracy and red tape. The single market rules must be simple, proportionate and applicable in the real economy. We need to move from inadequate to quality impact assessments and to make problem—solving tools, such as SOLVIT and Your Europe, available to all citizens. Dialogue with stakeholders is essential, and so is avoiding gold-plating, where Member States impose an extra burden when implementing single market rules. It is therefore bizarre that the left are resisting the better regulation agenda at a time when we need a transparent, effective single market that is closer to our citizens. We need enforcement, not ideological confrontation between business and consumers. As Commissioner Timmermans rightly says, we need to be big on big things and small on small things.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – Mr President, compliance with consumer protection rules is an important element of the single internal market, which, of course, often does not happen because consumers are unfortunately not aware or sufficiently aware of the means at which they have the means to enforce their rights. It is therefore essential to keep informed throughout Europe, as well as to consult interest representatives. The common EU framework should also ensure that single market regulation is kept up to date as far as possible. Digital innovations, and thus user needs, must be continuously monitored, thereby helping to complete the European single digital market. For the record, there is a Hungarian development, the essence of which is to go on the barcode with a mobile phone, the barcode of the given product with a camera, and already give out the details of that product. These are the kind of things the Commission should embrace.

name: Vicky Ford (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the single market is meant to make it easier for businesses and consumers to trade across 28 countries with 500 million consumers. It is not meant to add more costs; it is meant to remove costs and thus help our economies to grow, create jobs and growth. This report by my Belgian colleague and supported by others from many countries tonight will say that we should only introduce new rules where it helps our economies to grow, that new rules should be simple and easy to apply, that small businesses in particular should have a lighter burden and that national parliaments should have a stronger voice and be able to use a red card to block unwanted laws. Britain is not alone in asking for reform and it has been very good to hear colleagues from all across Europe support this report tonight. I hope we will all vote for it in the plenary tomorrow.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the particular issue of the single market, an essential instrument for reviving economic growth and employment, poses challenges to the effectiveness and efficiency of legislation that cannot be postponed, as, by means of the right body of legislation, it restores fruitfulness to an environment that is no longer competitive for our businesses and to improve single market legislation, which strengthens consumer confidence.  This optimisation of the legislative process highlights European added value, both in the shared choice of single market governance and in the adoption by Member States of implementing legislation. Furthermore, the problem of the lack of sufficient indicators to measure the effectiveness of the implementation of legislation in the different areas of the single market should not be overlooked.  In any case, above all legislative and executive process – I will never tire of emphasising this – comes the guiding principle of respect for fundamental rights, through which objectives of simplicity, transparency and coherence must be achieved.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I can only agree with the view of the report on what a well-regulated single market should look like: one that avoids unnecessary legislation and bureaucracy, but also one that does not lack ambition and does not compromise on environmental protection, health and safety, consumer protection and social standards; one that recognises the importance of better implementation and enforcement of existing rules instead of creating new legislation before the old has even been tested; one that provides for an environment where competition can thrive and can lead to more growth and more jobs; one that does not lag behind in new emerging economic areas but provides for a strong development platform for the companies of the digital economy; and ultimately one that is able to secure the long-term growth of the European Union for the benefit of its citizens.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr. President, the single market represents the greatest benefit of European integration for all Member States. Today it is perfectly normal for all of us to trade and recognize cross-border business opportunities and invest in them. As long as that's the case, there's no fear for Europe.  To continue prospering from the single market in the future, we need to extend it to all types of services and protect against poor practices and over-regulation. Deficient and unnecessary laws and regulations, on the one hand, and the slow and poor enforcement of quality regulation, on the other hand, are most damaging to small and medium-sized enterprises employing more than 80% of private sector workers.  If we do not want to seriously undermine europe's socio-economic picture in the future, better regulation of the single market, which will reduce administrative burdens and provide more opportunities for SMEs, must be an absolute priority for us.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of the Commission, I would like to thank the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and, in particular, the rapporteur Ms Van Bossuyt for this report. We agree that the single market is a cornerstone of European integration. In recent decades it has delivered more jobs and contributed to higher growth. We need to address the whole policy cycle, so last year the Commission presented two main initiatives designed to do that: the Better Regulation Package and the Single Market Strategy. Last May we proposed a Better Regulation Package, covering the entire policy cycle from consultations and impact assessments to the adoption, implementation and evaluation of EU legislation. The package will help us make sure that EU laws tackle the real problems of citizens and businesses. From now on, EU laws should be adopted according to better evidence and a more careful assessment of their impact on the real world. This will help us regain the trust of EU citizens. More recently a new interinstitutional agreement on better law—making was negotiated by Parliament, the Council and the Commission. We now have a strong political framework and a renewed commitment from the institutions in support of better regulation. After formal adoption it will be up to Parliament and the Council to work with the Commission to ensure its timely and effective implementation. We need to ensure that we deliver the benefits for citizens and businesses in practice rather than just in theory. Let us take the Regulatory Fitness Programme as an example – the one which we discussed a while ago. The Commission’s Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme will also play a central role in simplifying the body of existing legislation and reducing unnecessary regulatory burdens, especially for microenterprises and small and medium enterprises, and we will do so without weakening any of our important social and environmental goals. The second major initiative that we took last year is the Single Market Strategy adopted in October. It has three key aims: creating new opportunities for people and businesses, encouraging and enabling the modernisation and innovation that Europe needs and, above all, ensuring practical delivery. In some areas we need to launch new initiatives, such as introducing a service passport for key sectors of the economy, adopting a legislative proposal to prevent discrimination against consumers based on nationality or residence, or revising the Mutual Recognition Regulation. However, it is not enough just to come forward with new initiatives. We need to ensure the effective and efficient application of the existing legislation. We need to design legislation better and to evaluate and fix things which do not work as they should. We also need to make sure that existing rules are applied correctly by the Member States and backed by a smart approach to enforcement and the development of a compliance culture. For example, we will promote an enhanced partnership with Member States through implementation plans for new legislation and yearly compliance dialogues with each Member State. We all have the same aims. We have the same broad vision of what we want to achieve: we all want improved single market legislation and better delivery. Let us work together – the Commission, Parliament and the Council – to do this.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: That concludes. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 12 April.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of Damian Drghici's report on the acquisition of knowledge about the EU in schools (2015/2138(INI)) (A8-0021/2016).

name: Damian Drăghici
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, currently, European citizens have limited knowledge about the EU and how its institutions work. According to a 2014 Eurobarometer opinion poll, 71% of European Union citizens feel that they are not very well informed about the EU and 44% feel that they have a limited understanding of how the EU works. Even more worryingly, 52% of Europeans believe that their voice does not count in the EU. Under these circumstances it is little wonder that citizens feel distant to or even increasingly estranged from the European project, become even more Eurosceptic, and perceive democratic deficits in the decision-making processes of the Union. Therefore, enhancing dialogue about the EU in our schools and other educational institutions is crucial in order to bridge the long-standing gap between the European Union and its citizens and to restore their faith in the merits and necessity of the European integration process. This is even more important in the current context of the ongoing refugee crisis and of serious threats to fundamental human rights and democracy due to the recent terrorist attacks. The Report ‘Learning EU at school’ highlights that the main role of education is to train fully aware and active citizens in an increasingly complex, multicultural and integrated Europe and should therefore equip all learners with solid knowledge about the EU and in-depth understanding of its functioning and concrete added-value. An EU dimension in education should also encourage learners to critically reflect on European matters and how these influence their country and their own activities. This will empower them to form well-informed and balanced opinions, exercise their democratic rights and responsibilities, value diversity, intercultural and interreligious dialogue and be active and responsible citizens. With this in mind, the report stresses that the EU should become more visible in teaching materials and extracurricular activities at all levels and in all forms of education, including non-formal and lifelong learning. Teaching about the EU should reflect both the role of Member States in the development of the EU and the influence of the EU on national developments. In this context I would like to stress the importance of a European approach to the teaching of history in developing a reflective awareness of the past and a critical ‘culture of remembering’ based on European values. Another important aspect the report focuses on is the strengthening of citizenship education with the aim of enabling learners to acquire the competences they need to live and actively engage in pluralistic democratic societies and make their concerns heard. Core elements to be taught include tolerance, awareness and understanding for other cultures as well as democratic values and human rights. Until now, a majority of Member States has progressively integrated an EU dimension into their curricula and into teacher training, but gaps and disparities between and within Member States continue to exist. Much more could be done, for example, with regard to curricula, teacher training, textbooks and teaching methods. Therefore the report strongly encourages Member States to review and update their education systems and all forms of EU-related curricula content, to support all possibilities of conveying more information about the EU to learners as well as to teachers and other educators through formal, non-formal and informal learning, and to fully exploit and complement EU financial instruments, programmes and initiatives in this regard. At the European level, existing possibilities offered by the EU programmes in the field of education and culture should be fully used to promote active citizenship, cultural awareness, intercultural understanding and other valuable key and transversal competences. In this regard, the report calls for adequate financial support for these programmes, a greater focus on their qualitative outcomes and wider access to mobility, paying special attention to teachers and other educators, young people with different socio-economic backgrounds and vulnerable and disadvantaged groups. In addition, platforms such as EU Twinning, the School Education Gateway and EPALE for adult learning can be used for the development and exchange of teaching materials and projects related to the EU and its institutions, as well as citizenship education. The report calls on the Commission to continue to support Member States in their efforts to develop and promote an EU dimension in education while respecting their competence in the field, also by providing a common framework and guidelines for learning about the EU and by actively conveying information to key stakeholders and citizens. I want to thank, first of all, the Committee and all the people that helped on this, and the shadow rapporteurs.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D).
text: – Mr President, education is the basis of society and I congratulate the rapporteur on his approach to the inclusion of the concept of a European dimension in school curricula and the exchange of best practices between educational institutions in the Member States. As a member of the Committee on Agriculture, I would like to reinforce an idea expressed in this report, namely that the Union must keep up with new societal and technological challenges, and that the Member States must ensure the continuous harmonisation of vocational and technical education programmes in order to meet the challenges. name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, many citizens still do not have sufficient knowledge about the values on which European integration is based, nor how the European Union and its institutions function and directly influence their countries and their own activities. To help citizens understand that the European Union benefits our everyday life we need to bring the European Union closer to its citizens, explaining in practical terms what the EU does for each of us. Enhancing dialogue about European Union in our schools, associations and public spaces is essential, especially in the current situation of an increasingly globalised world which faces unprecedented challenges. Teaching about the EU should reflect the complex relationship between the European Union and its Member States. It should be clear for all citizens that the EU has been shaped by its Member States with their unique histories and diverse cultures. I believe that an intercultural approach to education policy is highly needed.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – Mr President, teaching EU knowledge could be useful if young people were given a real picture of the Union, the opportunities of the future, rather than one-sided propaganda. This report was not drawn up in this way. I quote: "a lack of knowledge about the Union ... democratic deficit and lead to the spread of Euroscepticism [...]'. The lack of democracy is not only a feeling, but a fact, and EU skepticism is not a plague epidemic, but a summary name for trends that do not see a bright future in the United States of Europe. "One of the aims of education is to prepare individuals for creation in a multicultural society." No, education should strengthen national and common European identity, and the failed notion of a multicultural society should be permanently abandoned.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in order to truly feel European, I believe that citizens need to know the European Union. This means first of all that citizens must have at their disposal all the tools, materials and intellectuals necessary for this purpose. It means encouraging critical reflection on the history of integration and the current European order; it means teaching and promoting, especially with concrete and positive examples, shared fundamental values and rights; it still means explaining the institutional set-up, the decision-making processes of the European Union, which are certainly not simple, and the relative impact of European decisions on the daily lives of all citizens.  Only in this way can we train European citizens who are truly aware and try to reduce the democratic deficit, a democratic deficit, the existence of which is strongly and clearly recognised by the report itself. It is even explicitly emphasised that the growing gap between citizens and the European institutions must be addressed and resolved.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. I support the introduction of teaching about the European Union into school curricula. Knowledge of the causes and history of European integration, the functioning of the European institutions or the impact of the Union on the daily lives of its citizens can and should be part of history courses or knowledge of society, as in the case of my country, Polish. Certainly, such information adds value to school education and equips students with the knowledge necessary to understand the modern world. The citizens' education initiative is particularly important: the role of the school is not only education, but also education. Students should draw on and be encouraged to participate in active civic life. Given today's influx of refugees and the percentage increase in the share of people of non-European origin in the societies of the Member States, educational opportunities are important, and in particular attention to civic education in terms of their integration into our society. Mr Drăghici's report supports these initiatives, taking into account the Financial Support of the European Commission.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission welcomes the report on learning EU at school. Let me first of all congratulate Mr Drăghici on his excellent work. Recent developments have once more demonstrated the risks of a ‘disconnect’ between disaffected young people and society. Our answer has to be multifaceted and has to promote our values and foster inclusion through education. Every young person in Europe needs to understand and share our fundamental values. And we need to build a Europe where every young person is able to find their place in society and achieve their potential, regardless of their background or abilities. What does learning EU at school mean concretely? I fully agree with the broad approach taken by Mr Drăghici in his report. To me it comprises two core aspects: the teaching of European history, cultures and languages on the one hand, and citizenship education on the other. Indeed, these aspects are linked. Without knowing Europe it is impossible to understand the founding values of the EU. In turn, knowing the cultures and languages of our neighbours supports active European citizenship. All those elements together form the concept of a European dimension in education, as expressed in Mr Drăghici’s report. It is, of course, up to the Member States to integrate this concept into their national school curricula. The Commission is ready to support this through its policy cooperation with Member States and especially the Erasmus+ programme. Some years ago, the Council and Parliament agreed on the key competences every European needs. They include social and civic competences and cultural awareness and expression. Fostering these competences and encouraging intercultural and interreligious dialogue to help our children become responsible and active citizens has always been an important element of our initiatives at EU level. In the current context, it is more necessary than ever to better understand but, first and foremost, to better transmit our common values. One year ago, in March 2015, the EU education ministers adopted the Paris declaration in response to the Charlie Hebdo attacks, in order to better promote citizenship and the common values of freedom, tolerance and non-discrimination through education. It is also one of the priorities of Education and Training 2020, our policy cooperation framework with Member States. A working group is currently tackling the topic of preventing violent radicalisation with a focus on enhancing critical thinking and media literacy.  The Commission also welcomes the importance the report attaches to EU programmes such as Erasmus+, Europe for Citizens and Creative Europe when it comes to promoting active citizenship, language skills and cultural awareness. I can confirm that in 2016 the Commission remains fully committed to funding concrete projects under these programmes, which aim at fostering active and democratic citizenship. I am determined to continue developing our virtual education platforms under Erasmus+, such as e-training, a network of 300 000 teachers, the electronic platform for adult learning in Europe and a school education gateway. These are valid instruments for our teachers and educators, who are key players in the school context. These platforms give them access to relevant high-quality teaching materials, encourage them to network and help them to exchange best practices. The Commission will closely monitor the impact of all of these measures on actually developing more active and democratic participation among our citizens. I appreciate the commitment of the European Parliament to this essential agenda and I look forward to further cooperation with you on this important topic.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: That concludes. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 12 April. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report of initiative by my Socialist colleague raises some questions about respect for the pluralism of ideas and freedom of expression. Indeed, under the pretext of learning the European Union in school, it will now be forbidden to express Eurosceptic opinions, criticising the European edifice being described in this report as a dangerous virus to be eradicated thanks to the miracle vaccine that would be pro-EU propaganda.  This drug, which actually amounts to an extensive promotional marketing campaign with our children, you want to inoculate it at the expense of the sovereignty of the states that officially retain exclusive jurisdiction over education. But European nations, already being pushed to the limit by your suicidal policies, will be called upon to harmonize their school curricula and to fund measures touting multiculturalism, an objective which, for you, seems to be a priority over learning fundamental knowledge such as reading, writing, or mathematics.  Colleagues, if you really want to 'reconnect' the citizens of Member States with the EU, stop denying their freedom of expression, stop lying to them about the so-called benefits of European integration and put an end to your blindness and willingness to impose on the peoples of Europe a model of society they do not want.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. – First of all, I would like to thank Member Damian Draghici for his high-quality and comprehensive report, and I appreciate his work. Today, the European Union is facing new challenges, so it is more important than ever that there is a dialogue about the European Union and its values in schools and in public life, so that citizens know the benefits and systems of the European integration process. EU citizens currently have a lack of knowledge of the European Union and the functioning of its institutions, as shown by the Eurobarometer spring 2014 survey: 44% of EU citizens do not understand how the Union works. It is no wonder, then, that citizens do not feel close to the Union and are increasingly turning away from EU policy and project. We can improve this by providing citizens with better information at school age. One way to do this is to increase the EU dimension of school education, which can prepare citizens to live in an increasingly complex and globalised world. I am convinced that in today's Europe there is an even more need to know the pillars and values of the European Union, and that knowledge and understanding of the history and values of the Union and its Member States is key to further peaceful coexistence, mutual understanding, tolerance and solidarity. Thank you very much for your attention.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The report on the acquisition of EU knowledge in schools is a very important and topical topic. The figures speak for themselves: in the last Elections to the European Parliament, only 42.61% of citizens (27.8% of 18-24 year olds) voted. In the Eurobarometer 2014 poll, 44% of respondents disagreed with the statement 'I understand how the Union works'. In these circumstances, it is understandable that citizens feel distant from the European Union and feel a democratic deficit in its decision-making. Although EU knowledge is already included in the education systems of several Member States, there are significant differences in this respect, both between Member States and within Member States.  In general, EU knowledge is only a small part of the curriculum. Teaching EU knowledge is not just about transferring specific material knowledge. Personal experiences such as youth and volunteering, participation in Erasmus, visits to the EU institutions, contacts with EU officials, traineeships are just as important. The teaching of foreign languages also plays a key role in helping to develop intercultural awareness and supporting mobility between Member States. Although education alone does not eliminate citizens' possible reservations about the Union, it can strengthen a sense of belonging to the Union, a community spirit and a better understanding of the functioning of the EU institutions.

name: María Teresa Giménez Barbat (ALDE)
text: in writing. – This report shows that introducing a European dimension into the teaching of countries is not a luxury, but a necessity, if we aspire to build a shared European citizenship. I come from a country, Spain, which very positively values the European dimension of education, as the Commission's data show, according to which we are the country that receives the most students and the most students sends within the Erasmus programme. It is also clear that learning a common European citizenship does not mean forgetting the different cultural identities and traditions. I would like to stress that this 'intercultural approach' must be strongly articulated around common values and principles, because positive school integration is not possible where personal rights are subordinated by reason of religion, ideology or culture. The feeling of European belonging is a difficult journey, for europe's history is also a difficult journey of national selfishness. In this plurality of peoples, cultures and sensitivities, danger and salvation live at the same time. We must undertake this journey tactfully, when it comes to respecting the legitimate identities of Europeans, but also boldly, when it comes to orienting ourselves towards the common horizon that excited us.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. – I believe that the introduction of European civic education at school is extremely important because it will allow children from an early age to be aware of their rights and obligations as European citizens and to participate fully in the political life of Europe and their own country.  The decline in turnout among young people is a particularly worrying trend which, in my view, clearly demonstrates the need to teach civic education to introduce young people to European democratic institutions, principles and practices, as well as the opportunities that European integration gives them.  A misunderstanding of how the EU works and its core values and principles makes young European generations an easy target for disinformation campaigns aimed at undermining the foundations of a democratic Europe and weakening its institutions, reinforcing populist and nationalist attitudes. This is a european-worthy challenge that respects national competences and educational traditions.  The European dimension in education will help restore the weakened relationship between the European Union and its citizens by creating a sense of belonging to a community based on values and the rule of law. In this context, it is important to ensure that teachers are motivated to teach young people this knowledge and have all the resources they need.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – Education about the European Union is very important in the construction of the European project. European citizens, and especially young people, need to understand the benefits of the EU, to know the functioning mechanisms of the European institutions, but also to learn the techniques by which they can participate in the European decision-making process. Unfortunately, we do not know enough about each other at the moment, and our education system does not present young people with their rights as European citizens. With an added knowledge of the history of the entire European Union and more information about European topicality, young people will regain confidence in the European institutions built with so much difficulty to ensure the peace and development of our continent. That is why, as an academic, but also as the initiator of several debates about the need to have a common European-wide curriculum on the EU, I wholeheartedly support this report which I hope will generate clear solutions for the uniformity, but also the popularisation of education about the EU, from the European Commission and the Member States.

name: Ева Паунова (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Union faces more and more challenges – local, national, global, economic, political. In order to be able to stand up to them and continue even stronger, it is important to feel European, to know how the Union works, what it can do for us and what we can do for it. I therefore believe that knowledge and belonging to the EU must be built from an early age, and schools in all Member States need to promote the European dimension in education. The European Parliament's report on EU school learning provides excellent guidance on how knowledge of the Union's objectives and mechanisms can be given, as well as to encourage critical reflection on Europe's priorities and values. Only in this way will the younger generation be prepared to work and live as active citizens in an increasingly integrated Union and in a globalised world. Getting to know the EU at school also requires a new approach alongside teacher training, as mentioned in the report. I believe it is key to use interactive methods and examples of how the EU matters to the lives of each of us in the classroom.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of Ernest Maragall's report on "Erasmus+ and other instruments to promote mobility in vocational education and training – a lifelong learning approach" (2015/2257(INI)) (A8-0049/2016).

name: Ernest Maragall
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, this report is an initiative report by the Committee on Culture and Education and counts, as it could not be otherwise, with the supplementary vision of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, and it seems to me that the result is a sign of this positive complementarity. And the report aims to provide positive solution elements for an equation that is now unresolved: the equation between education, learning and incorporation into the work of so many young Europeans. In this area, Commissioner, we are a long way from the right path to achieve the objectives to which we committed ourselves, to which the European Union has at the time committed itself to the 2020 Strategy. Rather it seems that in some cases we are almost diverging. This evidence is also being answered by the proposal for reform and improvement of the Erasmus+ programme contained in this report, which is aimed in particular at the sector, reality, our vocational training and learning.  This is what this report is all about: it identifies the obstacles and circumstances that explain Erasmus+'s current inadequacy and inadequacy for this particular objective and formulates the main lines of reform and adaptation that should enable us to extend Erasmus+'s overall success, which does exist and is indisputable, to this new area of vocational training and learning. Let's put it plainly: mobility equals employability. If we are clear about it and respect this criterion, we will surely advance and win some battles. That is why this Parliament addresses the European Commission and also the Member States with a certain demand and with no less urgency, and we do so by diagnosing, difficulties, instruments, etc.  Some points to achieve this proposal, this reflection and this urgency: to expand and improve mobility options, starting with the creation of a truly European reference framework that clearly and simply offers the possibilities available; the adoption of complementary measures to this Erasmus programme with social programmes, the European Social Fund, the European Youth Initiative); the adequate increase of economic resources to meet the needs and complexities of the specific circumstances of this group that is the protagonist of vocational training and learning. Therefore, adequate programs to remove obstacles to the creation of successful environments for this issue, starting with language barriers and following the simplification of procedures and the proper accompaniment and mentoring of our students, etc. The definition, too, of the intermediate agents, who will have to star in new management models, new models of success, to give maximum power to the Erasmus+ programme in this field. And that is why we will have to think about the definition of regional and mixed-composition agencies or consortia. Education system and business system must work together, they must agree to give the right operational response.  We must also complete the process of recognition of studies and the skills acquired, and professional experience, not always recognised in terms of professional title, but which is essential to do so now, and for this we must complete Europass, WE must complete ECVET and we must already think of a statute of the European apprentice, as is also advocated in the report.  Finally, effort must be devoted due to the preparation and mobility of the teachers themselves, which are key instruments for the success of this operation. This clear position of the European Parliament is what it wants is to give vocational training its role within the Erasmus programme. The role that has been lost in part precisely by the integration into a single Erasmus+ programme.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: I have many requests to speak for the catch-the-eye procedure that follows. However, I will call two people each from the PPE and S&D, and one each from the other groups. I ask for your understanding. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank the reporter for the quality of the report, and I appreciate your work. Learning and training mobility is very important for personal development, the social integration of young people, competitiveness in the labour market and the development of skills to work in an intercultural environment. This is part of quality education and promotion of employability. Non-formal and informal learning, as well as vocational training, play an important role in the lifelong learning process and in addressing challenges such as early school leaving, the high number of NEET young people and unemployment.  Erasmus+ has been successful, but the results so far show that not all opportunities have been fully used and that this mobility in vocational training should continue to be encouraged. Greater mobility attracts more employability, and differences in the labour market mean that we need to act as soon as possible. There is a need for greater synergy between education systems and the world of work.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D).
text: – Madam President, education is and must remain a fundamental right of all European citizens, regardless of their background, and there must be no constraint to prevent participation in programmes and initiatives that subsequently allow access to the labour market for people of all ages. The Erasmus programme has been a success in terms of mobility and it is necessary for Member States, together with the Commission, to guarantee equal access to mobility actions under Erasmus+ for all categories of people, to respect gender equality for non-preferential access to all educational programmes, including technical ones. I believe that the Member States and the Commission must link their efforts to reduce language and cultural barriers, to better function mobility programmes for young people and teachers, for an optimal transfer of knowledge and experience.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, as early as January 2014, the Erasmus+ programme is the new education and vocational training programme, which, with a budget of EUR 15 billion, will offer four million students the opportunity to study or work in another Member State of the Union by 2020. At the same time, the aim of the programme is to improve career prospects and provide students with social connections.  However, the social and economic reality demonstrates the need for this programme to adapt to the economic needs of each country. In particular, in the countries of the Union, there are extreme imbalances in unemployment rates. Greece has an unemployment rate of 24% and a youth unemployment rate of 48.9%, as a result of the violent fiscal adjustment and austerity policies and memoranda imposed on Greece. It is therefore necessary for the European Union to allocate more funds to countries affected by high unemployment rates.

name: María Teresa Giménez Barbat (ALDE).
text: – Distinguished President, ladies and gentlemen, in the Committee on Culture and Education we welcomed Mr Maragall's report. We are therefore surprised that he himself proposes an amendment by insisting on a matter already rejected in the Commission. This amendment calls for Erasmus+ programme documents to be translated into the official vehicle languages of school systems, but the translation of documents does not pose a problem for citizens who are beneficiaries of the Erasmus+ programme. I find it contradictory that the rapporteur wishes to invest European economic resources in a frankly useless bureaucratic translation procedure. In addition, it is incoherent, because Erasmus was born to allow students to deal with other cultures and to learn the languages of others, not to lock themselves in comfortable spaces and in their own official or co-official languages.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the report has some positive aspects, but it runs counter to the timidity with which it is judged to be the failure of the instruments used by Europe to combat the scourge of youth unemployment which, in some countries, for example in the south of Europe, continues to remain at unacceptable levels.  The position on widening the gaps in socio-economic protections and youth work rights and on early school leaving is also weak. I believe that education must be protected in its dimension as a fundamental human right and must be seen as a common good to be made accessible to all, including disabled people, on an equal footing. In addition, it is essential to remove all social and economic obstacles that limit equal opportunities, including those relating to vocational education and training.  These results cannot be achieved with the austerity logic that has so far guided European choices, particularly by tortured the citizens of southern Europe. Some tools such as Youth Guarantee missed the goals for which they were designed. The European Union can and must do more for youth education.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF).
text: Madam President, this report on Erasmus is quite satisfactory, and I welcome the fact that my colleagues have incorporated realistic proposals that I had tried to bring to committee, including the need to rely on chambers of trades and crafts to promote vocational training. I'll make some reservations. I am not sure that simply increasing mobility will solve the problem of unemployment, especially among young people. It seems to me that several common-sense measures will have to be taken beforehand: to ensure that studies are adequacy with the needs of the labour market by refocusing guidance advice, and to focus on the acquisition of basic knowledge. I would remind you that, according to the latest joint report by the Council and the Commission on the monitoring of the 'Education and Training 2020' policy framework in the EU, 22% of people under the age of 15 have gaps in mathematics, and 18% in reading. Finally, while I welcome the success of programmes such as Erasmus, which are part of the framework of intelligent and efficient intergovernmental cooperation, I would like to remind you that education is, and must remain, a competence of the Member States. Despite these few shortcomings, I will support...  (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – I think we all agree that Erasmus plus is an essential tool for promoting our common objectives, i.e. reducing unemployment, reducing poverty, improving the chances for all children to have a quality education. Therefore, this report, which is actually at the beginning of the current term of office, is constructively critical, i.e. it points out that we must monitor the effectiveness of the proposed programmes and priorities.  The Commissioner, whom I respect very much, certainly knows that the key to quality education is the teacher and the motivation of the pupil. Therefore, these vocational education programmes need to monitor links with practice, entrepreneurial skills, language skills and to streamlin administration. I thank him for doing it.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I am very pleased to see this report, because much of my work prior to coming into politics was working with young people to foster exactly this kind of exchange, working with young people who did not have those kinds of opportunities through the more formal university higher education Erasmus+ programmes. I just wanted to tell a little story which I think is important. In the summer of 2014 I went to be with some young people from the UK, Russia, Ukraine and Romania who were all in the same space for two weeks, engaging with each other through the Erasmus programme. This was at a time when Ukraine and Russia were at war with each other, but these young people in the same space learning from each other were not at war and could learn to live in peace together. We need more projects and programmes like this that can demonstrate how we can progress better living together.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam President, Erasmus+ is an important programme as it enables citizens looking for new knowledge and skills and business opportunities to gain valuable experience in other environments. Getting to know different educational models and business habits and cultural specifics with the indispensable learning of foreign languages significantly contributes to competitiveness in the single market and the development of new creative ideas that are not limited to the narrow local or regional market. I agree that this programme needs to be made more accessible and application procedures simplified, as well as compatibility between different VET systems. On the other hand, I find it completely unnecessary that this programme, which is equally important to all Europeans eager for knowledge, is burdened with ideological recommendations as the rapporteur does in those parts where he propagates positive discrimination against various minority communities and promotes an artificially created European identity.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to point out that Erasmus+ is one of those excellent programmes that the European Union has, regardless of what we have heard that it has a number of difficulties in some parts of the implementation of this programme. How much this has helped young people, how much it has helped those people who have acquired new knowledge and new skills, should not be particularly emphasized.  What I want to point out is certainly that we need more compatibility among our programs, we need more mobility of those who give knowledge to young people, first of all means professors, teachers, and this detail needs to be incorporated. But on the other hand, unlike my colleague who just now was talking, I just think that this part of the programme that talks about minorities in Europe is very important for building what European identity means, for strengthening European identity, because European identity exists whether you like it or not.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission welcomes the report on Erasmus+ and other tools to foster mobility in VET – a lifelong learning approach. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Maragall, for his work. I fully share the view expressed in the report that the learning and training grants offered by the Erasmus+ programme are contributing to high-quality education, improved employability and better civic competences. For many trainees, especially from lower socio-economic backgrounds, their Erasmus+ experience is often their first occasion to leave their home countries and step into another reality. Mr Maragall’s report contains a rich analysis of both the advantages and the challenges of mobility. The advantages are many: when trainees and apprentices go abroad, they acquire new professional competences which contribute to their training at home. Moreover, they improve their motivation and self-confidence, their versatility and adaptability and their language, communication and intercultural skills. All of these competences and skills acquired abroad give them an advantage on the labour market. Challenges range from reduced access to mobility programmes, the lack of financial resources, linguistic and cultural barriers, poor compatibility with training programmes at home and cumbersome recognition of skills acquired abroad to legal obstacles. The Commission is aware of these challenges. I will try to respond to some of them in the little time I have here and now. The Commission has already created a logistical and organisational framework which strives to make VET mobility a success for everybody involved. The Erasmus+ VET Mobility Charter, for example, improves the strategic impact of VET mobility on VET organisations. Through the charter, the Commission rewards high-quality mobility initiatives and internationalisation strategies. It is through the networking of schools that possess the VET Mobility Charter and their links to their respective local labour markets that better placements can be found and suitable companies located. We also have a good body of intermediaries – such as chambers of commerce, associations or local authorities – which help improve the logistics and the quality of VET mobility. Regarding people with special needs, the Commission has always considered it a priority to make their participation in the programme possible. Additional funds are made available to persons with special needs, which cover their additional expenses during their stay abroad. As for simplified access to the programme, the Erasmus+ IT tools are constantly being adapted to meet the applicants’ requests, and efforts are being made to simplify application procedures. We have been working with the national agencies managing Erasmus+ at the national level to tailor IT tools and e—forms to the applicants’ needs and to simplify them. The Commission also works closely with the national agencies to ensure maximum visibility of the programme’s VET actions. Various promotion events and social media campaigns at national and European level have been organised, such as the ‘We Mean Business’ campaign that aimed to boost the number of companies getting involved in transnational traineeships. Finally, linguistic preparation. Knowing the language of your host country is a crucial success factor for training periods abroad, especially for young trainees, whose knowledge of a foreign language can be limited. The programme helps them get over the linguistic hurdle by offering language assessment tools, online language courses and other linguistic and intercultural preparation courses. The European Parliament also contributes to improving the quality and quantity of VET mobility. In concrete terms, the pilot projects of both Mr Maragall and Mr Arthuis will provide vital funds to overcome obstacles and improve transnational placements for the future. This is in line with our policy priorities to improve work-based learning and help the younger generation to have better chances on the job market. Let me conclude by saying that I greatly appreciate the commitment of the European Parliament to boosting the quality and quantity of mobility in vocational education and training. The Commission is working in the same direction, and I am looking forward to our cooperation on these issues.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: That concludes. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 12 April. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The underlying negative perception of VET as being an educational pathway of less worth needs to be addressed through a concerted and common approach. We can start by establishing common high standards in European VET to provide learners with training of a good standard and facilitate mobility and recognition of competences amongst diverse national systems. This means that we also need to address the use of VET by national systems as a way to show a decrease in the number of early school leavers by lowering the educational and training component of VET or else pushing learners towards VET from a very young age without ensuring that they gain basic skills. VET is not the stop plug to early school leavers. It is just one of the measures that may entice early school leavers to return to training, but other measures taking place earlier on in a learner´s life are needed. VET represents an important tool for re-skilling, widening and upgrading skills within a lifelong learning programme that can facilitate employment.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – Erasmus+ is a new programme for education and training and aims to reduce early leaving the education system and increase the number of highly educated people. Through the mobility program, individuals are offered the opportunity to get education and training abroad. Mobility is very popular with young people nowadays. It is supported by all EU institutions, as it recognises its positive impact on the development of young people taught tolerance, other cultures and customs.  Mobility increases the social inclusion of young people in society and promotes active citizenship. Among other things, one of the objectives of mobility is to reduce the number of unemployed young people. Practices abroad make contacts with employers and have been proven to be easier to recruit. However, mobility does not prevail in vocational education and training, notably due to the mismatch between higher education institutions where mobility programmes are implemented. At EU level, it is essential to enable better coordination and organisation of mobility programmes.  Furthermore, it is necessary to recognise and confirm the results of mobility programmes achieved by young people through formal and non-formal learning. These are language and other skills that young people acquire abroad. I believe that funding should continue and the amounts of support for mobility programmes should be increased. This would allow more people to participate in mobility programmes. National, regional and local levels should certainly better promote and support mobility.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – As a young MEP, I cannot fail to appreciate the fact that the Erasmus+ programme encourages the mobility and preparation of young Europeans for employment. Why is that? Because youth unemployment remains dangerously high at 22.1%. Because the requirements of employers in the labour market are not entirely correlated with a unitary system of skills acquisition. At the same time, after repeated attempts to persuade the European Commission to supplement the funds allocated to programmes to reduce youth unemployment, we have come to the conclusion that we have a difficulty understanding of the seriousness of the problems faced by young Europeans. I support the adoption of this report, including in the light of the fact that it asks exactly what I have asked of the Commission - a set of up-to-date statistics showing the effectiveness of Erasmus+ and other programmes that encourage labour mobility in the EU. Last but not least, I want to call on all political groups not to ignore multilingualism, so that the Erasmus+ programme becomes accessible in all the official languages of the EU, as is natural.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – According to statistics presented by Eurostat in February 2016, youth unemployment in the EU was 21.5% in the euro area and 19.5% for the European Union as a whole, respectively. Despite some positive developments in recent years, these figures are worrying.  The use of Erasmus+ and other mobility support tools in vocational education and training is one of the key initiatives for sustainable improvement. Increased mobility helps to increase young people's professional flexibility and promote the improvement of their competences and active job search. Currently, only 1% of young people in work-linked vocational training take part in mobility programmes.  I fully support any action taken to improve mobility programmes in vocational education and training. It is particularly important to facilitate the mutual recognition and accreditation of all such initiatives.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. – Dear Sirs, tomorrow we will vote on the use of erasmus+ and other instruments to promote mobility in vocational education and training. I am pleased that Parliament has drafted a resolution focusing on vocational education. As the EP's permanent rapporteur for Erasmus +, I also monitor activities related to the old Leonardo programme, which are now an integral part of Erasmus. Erasmus+ is of paramount importance for promoting mobility. Unfortunately, due to various socio-economic factors, only 1% of participants in vocational education participate in mobility programmes. For many of them, mobility is not as self-evident as for university students. That is why MEPs are calling on the European Commission, in cooperation with CEDEFOP, to come up with concrete measures to ensure that this share increases. Co-financing from related programmes and mechanisms such as Erasmus+, the European Social Fund, the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative should be facilitated. We call on the Commission and the Member States to better implement and coordinate the functioning of existing mechanisms such as The Europass, ECVET and the European Reference Framework for Quality Assurance of Vocational Education and to continue their efforts to mutually recognise study programmes, qualifications, non-formal and informal learning. Greater mobility in vocational education will help to address disparities between supply and demand for skills and to increase youth employment in the EU.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of Sylvie Goulard's report on the EU's tasks within the framework of international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies (2015/2060(INI)) (A8-0027/2016).

name: Sylvie Goulard
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I will speak in French. I am very pleased that we are coming to the vote on this report, which is a modest report of initiative on a subject that goes far beyond us.  There are two key words in this report if we want to understand the meaning of them. The first key word is "democratic control." We do have - and I believe that Europe, which is an open society, is particularly attached to it - the will to participate in the stabilisation of the international financial system. This stabilization requires agreements at the global level, with partners who may be in America, Asia and, perhaps tomorrow, around the world. However, the need to set rules at the global level runs up against the demands of democracy quite quickly and, in essence, we are no longer always able to give a very simple answer to an equally simple question, namely: who decides?  Therefore, the starting point of this report was that, in more and more areas, we cannot answer our constituents, the citizens, about the simple question: who decides? And it is quite important, even if expert committees intervene, that democratically elected entities can carry out their function. Secondly, the second important aspect is that of Europe's influence in this global negotiation. The report tries to be quite pragmatic and to start, in particular, from the areas in which we have legislative powers, that is, in which we legislate with the Council. On the face of it, all Member States are bound by this legislation. However, it sometimes appears that in committees, in international organisations, some States do not play the collective game, for example in the banking sector where, however, there is common legislation. On the method, we have observed what is being done in a number of international institutions that are sometimes full international organizations, such as the OECD or the IMF, more flexible bodies, which were created during the crisis or which strengthened during the crisis, such as the G20 or the Financial Stability Board, and then a number of other bodies such as the Basel Committee for Banking , IOSCO, IEIS, IOPS, or IASB - I'm sorry for the interpreters, that's a lot of acronyms - in which the industry is sometimes present, which can also pose problems of conflicts of interest, and sometimes very fragmentary representation of the countries of the world.  I would also like to thank Parliament's services, which have enabled us to obtain a number of reports on these different institutions, as well as my shadow rapporteurs. I see that Mady Delvaux is here, and so is Sirpa Pietik-inen. I don't know if there are others I forget, but I think we have worked really well together. I hope that we can have a large majority, because again, these are subjects that we are trying to anticipate, and we are trying to lift the veil on practices that have been necessary because of the crisis, but which we are no longer quite able to explain to the electorate. What I hope is that the Commission will be able to set up what we have called a financial dialogue, that is, a closer relationship between those who represent Europe and this House, so that we can, upstream, discuss the mandates and, downstream, look at what has been achieved. This is somewhat the basis of the monetary dialogue with the ECB, which was also created on the margins of the treaties.  It is no more, it is no less, it is a start and, again, thank you all for being there so many this evening for the adoption of this report. Thank you, Commissioner, for being with us as well.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE).
text: – Madam President, history has taught us that when we act together we are strong, and when we are divided, we are weak and unable to face challenges, whether these be the refugee crisis, the financial crisis or taxation issues. Actually, when it comes to global financial markets, the EU is belittling itself and reducing its powers by being so ineffective, so opaque and having so many intrigues between the Member States and competences – not only between the Member States but also between the different divisions in the Commission and between the Commission and the Member States – not to mention the opaqueness , which Sylvie Goulard has already mentioned, about openness to civil society and Parliament about what is actually going on in international fora. The latest big signal has been not only taxation but, after the financial crisis, the need to change the system. What we need is democratic scrutiny and the possibility for Parliament to give pre—guidance and afterwards scrutiny on these issues.

name: Mady Delvaux (S&D).
text: Madam President, the first merit of this report is to draw up an inventory of the different bodies in which Europe participates, illustrating their diversity in terms of how they operate, status and composition. I would like to thank Sylvie Goulard for taking the initiative of this report and I welcome the sense of compromise she has shown, which will, at least I hope, achieve a large majority in the vote. It is a matter of sending a strong message to the Commission, but above all to the Council and the Member States. We must improve coordination and ensure the cohesion of the Union in order to defend our legitimate interests, not to mention the less well-off countries. There needs to be maximum transparency so that we can trace the influences that are at the root of the decisions. There is also a need for democratic control, debate in national parliaments, but also with civil society, which must be given the resources and skills to conduct the discussions. Finally, the representatives of the Union must be held to account and ensure that the commitments made are respected.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, multilateral cooperation between the European Union and the various international economic organisations, as well as the separation of their tasks, must be implemented each time, and this is a real necessity in order to achieve financial stability and growth. In order to do this, however, the European Union will have to put its own house in order. In particular, it is necessary to redefine the supervisory tasks of the European Central Bank and its participation in the troika programmes. In Greece, the European Central Bank acts as the country's lender and not as an independent monetary authority, resulting in a conflict of interest.  This, of course, will stop when the European Central Bank leaves the troika. In addition, the ECB should abandon its "mercely" austerity strategy and make a real contribution to providing liquidity in order to raise interest rates and stimulate growth. Finally, the European Union should contribute to cooperation balanced in economic and financial matters, freeing the countries of the South from credit suffocation.

name: Sylvie Goulard
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to speak for a point of order. It would be nice if colleagues could talk about the subject of the report. It would be more interesting than coming over and doing the same number you hear on other subjects. The subject of this report is the European Union's place in global international for a.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, I am referring to the Rules of Procedure, because according to the Rules of Procedure, the rapporteur has no right to make suggestions to speakers on what to say. Secondly, what I said is directly related to the report and the rapporteur should have said that the European Central Bank is currently in breach of the Treaties by participating in the troika. The European Court of Justice has also said this, so bring it back to order.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Mr Marias, I would like to thank Mr Marias for his That was not really a point of order. Both you have the right to say what you think, which is right, and to the rapporteur, to hope and to argue that the speakers refer to their text.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, global challenges require coordination on a large scale, and I fully agree with that; What I disagree with, however, is the answer that we want to give because I do not believe that the 'more Europe' solution is credible.  The answer cannot be to force everyone to align themselves with a single model, the elimination of all forms of dissent or the continuan transfer of sovereignty to a European Union that is not in a position today to provide solutions to the problems of its citizens. We do not want Europe to speak with one voice. What we are asking for is greater cooperation and respect, and to achieve this we do not need a technocratic superstructure such as the EU. The federalist utopia of the United States of Europe, which extols the role of crises as necessary evils in persuading citizens to cede more sovereignty to structures far away and outside democratic control, is sheer unfeasible madness. If Europe, the real One, wants to survive, it must abandon this failed project and turn to a model of functional integration for individual objectives that will protection and respect the differences of the States.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – I would address the part that the rapporteur referred to. We are supposed to anticipate, we are supposed to be a little foresighted, and at the same time to apply the procedures that we defend in front of the citizens.  I agree with this, as my colleague said, but I am also calling for more communication with the Member States. There is no doubt that the global financial market and the role of the European Union in international financial institutions is a very serious issue. But an equally serious question is how the European Union and its institutions communicate their policies with the Member States and their citizens. Here I think we have really significant reserves.  The Czech Republic has financial markets and set rules in these financial markets at a very good level. We paid a very high price for this precisely in the form of having to bail out banks in the 1990s. I would very much like the European Union to learn from this follow-up and communication with citizens, even from us.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Indeed, when we talk about these issues, we can think not only about our activities in the various financial institutions, I mean the European Union, but also about how well they serve our foreign policy objectives. I am convinced that it is in Europe's express interest that peace processes in the world move forward that could otherwise lead to ugly conflicts.  That is why I think I am suggesting that, in the following, we place much greater emphasis on foreign policy advocacy, i.e. not only to support Europe in general, but also to its specific interests.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like first of all to congratulate Ms Sylvie Goulard for taking the initiative to present this report. Last October the Commission released a communication aiming at a more unified external representation of our economic and monetary union in international financial institutions. We can no longer accept that the euro area, which has the second largest currency in the world and which represents one of the world’s key market actors and economic powerhouses, does not speak with one voice on economic and financial matters in international financial institutions. This especially holds for the International Monetary Fund. The International Monetary Fund is a key pillar of the international monetary system in charge of global crisis prevention and crisis response. It is of strong relevance for the euro area. A more unified representation will allow the euro area to effectively shape its future role in the global financial architecture and more effectively promote euro area interests at a global level. Our proposal consists of two elements: streamlining euro area representation in the short term and moving to a unified representation by the year 2025. We are aware that the road ahead is not easy. We are currently discussing the proposals with the Member States. The decision-making process will take some time: agreement is not imminent, but we believe that an agreement can be reached. We welcome an early discussion with Parliament on this important subject and we take note of your recommendations. We appreciate that the report stresses the need for a stronger European voice. As regards international standard-setting bodies for financial regulation, the situation is very diverse from the Financial Stability Board to the Basel Committee and others. Each body has its own particular governance arrangements, and the extent to which the EU is represented varies – often with only certain Member States represented. We agree with Parliament that the European position should be better coordinated, as we all understand that when we are united we are stronger on the international scene, and we set out in our October communication what the Commission will do to get there. The Commission also takes note of the proposals in the report to involve European supervisory authorities more in international fora. A core interest of the European Parliament is to be more involved in discussions leading up to the development of new international rules concerning the financial sector. Since the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, the Commission has been steadily building up strong relations with the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON). This work is not finished, and we stand ready to provide timely updates on salient developments in international financial regulation. To conclude, a point on the G20: we should bear in mind that the G20 is an informal forum where leaders make commitments to address global challenges, putting their personal credibility at stake. It does not adopt binding decisions or replace regular decision-making processes.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: That concludes. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 12 April.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of the report by Rua Tomasic on innovation and diversification of small-scale coastal fishing in fishing-dependent areas (2015/2090(INI)) (A8-0044/2016).

name: Ruža Tomašić
text: Rapporteur. – Madam Chairman, Mr. Commissioner Vella, esteemed colleagues and fellow Members, the slogan of this community of ours is "United in Diversity". However, so far the rules have been more or less universal and did not recognise this so much-emphasized diversity, and some provisions of the Common Fisheries Policy and the Mediterranean Regulation specifically concerning small-scale coastal fishing are the best example of this.  The Mediterranean and the northern seas were one and the same to the legislator and the bureaucratic apparatus, and the consequence of such an approach is a legislative framework that stifles the development of fishing communities in both the south and north of the continent. The first step in building a new framework is to adopt a definition of coastal, small-scale coastal and traditional fishing at EU level, while taking into account the specifics of the different fishing regions.  In this process, we call on the Commission to take into account a number of different criteria such as vessel size, fishing gear used, selectivity of fishing techniques, duration of fishing, but also socio-economic indicators, such as the impact of traditional fisheries on the well-being of local communities. We consider it necessary to review the possibility of small-scale coastal fishing in island communities that traditionally depend on fisheries and participate in fishing activities throughout the year due to livelihoods.  Such a decision would be fully in line with the new initiative for islands, which aims to develop comprehensive solutions to the problems of economic and demographic die-off of the island and the preservation of island communities. Taking into account the negative effects of the administrative burden to be significantly reduced in the future, we ask the Commission and the Member States to ensure through the competent authorities that small-scale coastal fishing receives adequate funding from the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund. Traditional fishing is an important segment of the cultural and historical heritage of coastal communities and as such should be the basis for the development of fishing tourism.
