We therefore call on the Commission to support investments in promoting fishing heritage and diversifying fisheries in the fields of culture and the arts. However, in order not to leave everything on tradition and to ensure the sustainability of island communities in the future, Parliament strongly supports the diversification of the fisheries sector through the development of complementary activities and investment in vessels, safety equipment, training and innovation, with the key objective being to finance activities that are socially, environmentally and economically sustainable. These objectives can only be achieved with the participation of all local stakeholders, entrepreneurial associations, research institutes, universities, technology centres and local and regional institutions, so we call on the Commission to provide sufficient support to meet the conditions set out in the European Fisheries Fund and to take more decisive steps to improve their funding opportunities.  Finally, I would like to thank everyone who contributed to the drafting of this report. First of all, I would like to thank my fellow shadow rapporteurs and all the members of the Fisheries Committee who have created a very constructive and positive atmosphere around this report through their proposals and discussions. However, as rapporteur, I would especially like to thank the experts and fishermen from Croatia who recognized the moment and decided to influence the processes in politics with their knowledge and experience. Such open and sincere cooperation between politics and the interested public restores faith in democratic processes and raises hopes that together with citizens we can fix all that is wrong with the European Union today.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I welcome the Tomaca report. Artisanal coastal fishing is very important: in Spain it represents 66% of the fleet and in Galicia, where I come from, it accounts for 85% of ships, i.e. more than 3,800 vessels, including the activity of the seafood from boat. Recently a delegation from the Committee on Fisheries visited precisely this land and was able to see the importance of artisanal fishing. These are, for the most part, small vessels, family-owned enterprises. They use selective arts, have little environmental impact and consume less fuel. We need to help this fleet, which is very important in the local communities from which it comes. The European Maritime and Fisheries Fund states that it is necessary to establish an action, development, competitiveness and sustainability plan for the artisanal fishing fleet. In Galicia, this plan is being finalized, which includes, among other things, priority for the artisanal fleet in all the measures provided for by the Fund, employment plan to ensure generational revo and measures to ensure the commercialization of its products and also to improve the energy efficiency of the vessels.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I think it is important to recognise that there is a very interesting defence of fisheries in the most remote areas in this report, that is, in the outermost areas of Europe. In fact, in the Azores, where I come from, there are particularities that have to be defended, ensuring the protection of smaller fleets and the implementation of real alternative projects of the blue economy. This approach must be based on scientific research and regulated by consistency of economic opportunities and identification of environmental constraints. The result should be based on topics such as diversification of the use of the sea, dignification and increased training of fishing professionals and the enhancement of biological resources. That is also why I would like to highlight the possibility highlighted in the own-initiative report of expanding the action of the European Fund for Sea and Fisheries Affairs to include systems similar to the late POSEI Fisheries.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, coastal fisheries are a socially sustainable form of fisheries which, according to the Common Fisheries Policy, can increase competitiveness and entrepreneurship in the fisheries sector. However, in many Member States of the Union, coastal and island regions are experiencing a significant economic downturn resulting in a decline in population and the flight of inhabitants.  Moreover, in countries such as Greece affected by austerity measures and the memorandum, fishermen are experiencing the consequences of the troika's agricultural memorandum, resulting in a much more pronounced economic downturn.  It is therefore necessary for the European Union to take immediate measures to rebuild the primary sector, to emphasise the blue economy, to boost employment in coastal and island regions and to increase European Union funding in the fisheries sector. While, in relation to Greece, there must finally be a barrier to tax looting and anti-insurance resalto to the meager incomes of fishermen.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the common fisheries policy needs a rational definition of coastal and traditional fisheries and more flexible formulas to support a critical sector, for the maintenance of traditional activity, population, culture and lifestyles on European shores. The definition on the basis of the size and power of the ships does not work; we propose criteria linked to the diversity of this fisheries sector and to the relationship of small-scale fisheries with the maintenance of activity and traditional stocks in coastal societies.  We want a more rigorous regulation of recreational fishing and more imagination and value in income diversification measures in this sector. It depends on us still retaining in Europe lifestyles that are part of the European heritage and that will also offer unique experiences to future customers of the European quality tourism brand. Listen more, please, to the cry of the saltpeter societies.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the reform of the common fisheries policy has not helped to address, as was required, the serious problems facing small-scale coastal fishing, artisanal fishing and the most dependent regions of them. On the contrary, many problems have worsened.  On this occasion we want to insist on long-a-long proposals, the need of which is confirmed by the evolution of reality. The development of a specific Community programme to support small-scale fishing, the defence of differentiated treatment with management schemes and models adapted to the specific characteristics and problems of this segment, support for fleet renewal and modernisation, improvement of the sector's income, if necessary intervening in its value chain in order to enhance the prices paid to production , the consecration and extension of exclusive access reserve areas in order to better protect local fleets and communities by giving them priority over access to resources. Lofty proclamations are not enough in defence of small-scale fishing. These proclamations need to be translated into concrete commitment and concrete measures, far beyond what has been done.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I congratulate my colleague Tomašić on an excellent report that will certainly contribute to the quality of life of small fishermen.  The reform of the Common Fishing Policy started in January 2014 aims to introduce innovation, create new markets and improve the quality of life in coastal areas. Improvement of the quality of life in coastal areas is not possible while the so-called "quality of life" is in force. 2006 Mediterranean Regulation due to an indiscriminate approach to banning the use of traditional tools and techniques in the Mediterranean. Prohibitions of this type lead to abandonment of traditional ways of harvesting and displacement of the population, especially from the island, due to the inability to achieve basic existential needs.  I therefore agree that coastal, small coastal and traditional fishing should be defined in accordance with socio-economic characteristics, biodiversity protection and specificities of different regions, not only in line with the dimensions and power of fishing vessels, given the fact that existing EU rules are not satisfactory.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, we will all agree that an effort must be made from the European Union to protect artisanal fisheries. We are talking about a way of life that we must maintain but also of an economic and social activity that can remain viable and profitable if we make the right decisions. Specific rules for specific fishing. That's what we need.  And this being important, it is fundamentally important for some regions, as Mr Serrcao said, such as the outermost regions, which need special protection to ensure the survival of fishermen who use traditional techniques and who are also characterized by being very environmentally friendly. Coastal fishing in these territories is substantial to their economic development due to their geographical characteristics and their great estrangement from the continent.  It is therefore important that we take measures to protect their activity, return to a POSEI for fisheries and work to strengthen development and innovation to ensure that these boats will be able to continue fishing.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission must strive to support innovative projects and legal provisions that facilitate the development of regions dependent on fishing.  In particular, priority must be given to projects focusing on job creation and maintenance and on the promotion of pescaturismo and gastronomy linked to small-scale fisheries products. The Commission must actively support investment in the diversification of fisheries both in the marketing and processing of local fish products and in stimulating the development of local distribution channels and in the promotion of products through the creation of distinctive signs and local brands.  It is also essential that both the Commission and the Member States progressively increase the quotas allocated to small-scale fishermen in order to promote this type of socially and ecologically sustainable fishing, just as it is important to give priority to small-scale coastal fishing in allocating funding from the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, the common fishing policy seems to be the expression of a bureaucrat from an office on the 12th floor, I don't know exactly which street in Brussels. That's roughly what the insensibility of what we have in this report looks like, as something that is a really great result of hard work, agreement, and that's why I want to express my strong support for the ambition to finally put traditional small fisheries in the place it deserves within European policies.  Of course this is extremely important for the survival of many island communities, of course this is important for the promotion of tourism and of course it is essential for the enogastronomy of the island, but also for coastal regions. That is why I want to express strong support and I will promote this report in Croatia and in other island or coastal regions of Europe.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I support this report and congratulate my colleague Tomašić on the proposal to amend the Mediterranean Regulation and the existing regulation on the selection of tools and techniques.  Small coastal fishing is extremely important from a socioeconomic and traditional-cultural point of view for the island and coastal population of the Republic of Croatia. Therefore, I started an initiative on declaring small fishing an intangible cultural heritage of the Republic of Croatia. Namely, the abolition of small-scale fishing in Croatia has further aggravated the lives of residents in coastal and island areas, which are already facing severe depopulation of the population. Small coastal fishing with traditional techniques and tools represents a centuries-old tradition in Croatia and an essential component of the identity of the Croatian coastal area.  I therefore consider it necessary to apply a regional approach to marine resource management across all geographical, biological, sociological and economic specificities in order to address the existing negative trends adopted by the old common fishing policy.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate Mrs Tomaca because she has done a great job, she has been very receptive to all the proposals, and I believe that in general there has been a more than adequate report.  I would like to stress, Commissioner, that virtually all Members have referred to the need for a new definition of artisanal coastal fisheries. It is something on which there is a great coincidence in this report. It cannot be the twelve meters in the long that identifies what is artisanal coastal fishing. We have to make a new definition. But this new definition is not enough; explicit support is needed. So far it hasn't happened. National operational programmes have not had such positive discrimination.  We must also take advantage of – and so it is reflected in this report – to create a fishing tourism segment in which this sector participates without being excluded. I therefore conclude as I began: congratulating Mrs Tomaca and clearly supporting this report.

name: Werner Kuhn (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner Vella, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Vella, for the work he has I think it is very important that we have included small- and coastal and small-scale fishing in the basic regulation and have also given it appropriate support in the related financial instrument – the EMFF, the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund.  That was a very important signal. 70% of all fisheries in Europe belong, so to speak, to small-scale and coastal fishing, and that is why regionalisation plays a crucial role in this. I think it is a good thing that Commissioner Vella is also giving the Member States some freedom and is therefore not saying that one size fits all, but that we will develop multiannual, multi-species management plans, which will then also be geared towards these fishing areas and to the fishing establishments. Fortunately, for my home region – the Baltic Sea – we have now completed the Baltic Sea plan, which also brings many benefits for fisheries: that they have abolished the one-network rule, that there are no need for more days at sea, that social benefits can also be paid in special decommissioning phases, these are all important signals to the small fisheries that make us authentic together with tourism. , and we can also invest in the Juncker Plan, and then that will also go in a positive direction.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I welcome the European Parliament’s own-initiative report on innovation and diversification of small-scale coastal fishing in fisheries-dependent regions, and I would like to thank rapporteur Tomašić for the report. The European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF), which as you know is the structural support tool for the common fisheries policy for the period 2014-2020, was the fruit of intense negotiations between the European Parliament and the Council. Thanks to the fund, Member States can and probably will implement most of what is requested or proposed in the report. The fund permits a higher intensity of aid – 80% – for all operations related to small-scale coastal fishing. Some examples are: young fishermen starting out in the sector; health and safety; diversification; partnerships between scientists and fishermen for the purposes of training; lifelong learning; marketing and processing; and innovation. However, it is the responsibility of Member States to decide, under the respective operational programmes approved in late 2015, how to translate their strategic preferences into concrete support to their small-scale coastal fishing fleet. The figures for small-scale coastal fishing fleets are telling. They account for only 8% of gross tonnage yet they represent nearly three quarters – almost 75% – of active fishing vessels. They account for only 12% of the value of landings and 16% of the gross value added, yet they represent 48% of the total number of jobs and 36% of the full-time equivalents, which means that a significant proportion of the jobs are part-time. This last element implies that fishing is not the only, or even the main, source of income for many small-scale coastal fishing fishermen and families. In any event, it is a fact that small-scale coastal fishing vessels are fundamental for the viability and resilience of coastal communities dependent on them, and I fully agree with that view. However, it is also a fact that industrial or large-scale fishing fleets are also based in coastal areas and that they represent most of the value of landings, gross value added and full-time equivalent jobs within the EU. Thus, these are at least as fundamental for the viability and the resilience of coastal communities as small-scale coastal fishing fleets. Furthermore, the simple fact that some 36 stocks in the Atlantic are now operating at maximum sustainable yield shows that large-scale fleets can also fish in a sustainable way whilst producing a lot of added value and social benefits. In view of the above, we need to support all fishing fleets and avoid instituting an asymmetric fishing policy, even though we do recognise the equal importance of this small-scale coastal fishing. Regarding control requirements, let me recall that small-scale coastal fishing can already benefit from preferential conditions of support from the EMFF for the installation of control equipment on board. As to the proposal to relax control requirements for the fund during the review of the Control Regulation, we have to be particularly careful in ensuring that this does not jeopardise fishing resources in the coastal band. The coastal band is a strip about 12 nautical miles wide where most small-scale coastal fishing occurs and where most Member States grant preferential access rights to vessels. In particular, there is a serious risk that further relaxing regulatory requirements on small-scale coastal fishing could encourage fishing by additional vessels and worsen crowding in the coastal band, especially in areas where there is already a lot of pressure on regulated and unregulated stocks. I am convinced that such a further relaxation would backfire both in terms of economic viability and environmental protection. Regarding the definition of small-scale coastal fleets, according to the EMFF Regulation, Article 3(14) covers fishing vessels of an overall length of less than 12 metres and not using towed fishing gear. It was subject to intense discussions during the trilogues on the EMFF regulations. Many alternatives, including the criteria proposed on point one of the report, were proposed, analysed and discussed, but in the end it was not possible to come to an agreement on any new definition, and the existing one was proposed. A regionalised approach to the definition could have some merit but would also risk creating an uneven playing field. In conclusion, all fleets, including the small-scale coastal fishing fleet, are fundamental for the continued viability of coastal areas. A successful CFP is the best possible way to ensure the environmental, economic and social sustainability of EU fisheries and coastal areas. There is a lot of public support for that. Finally, be aware that relaxing further control requirements and allowing over-capacity to develop or increase in the 12-nautical-mile zone would clearly threaten the resilience of these communities. I have no doubt that the co-legislators will get back to us on these issues as part of the planned revision of the control regulation. Thank you for your valuable comments.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: That concludes. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 12 April. Written declarations (Article 162 CRP)

name: Jørn Dohrmann (ECR)
text: Written. – Inshore fishing is essential for the employment, tourism, attractiveness and retention of settlements in the outlying areas. At the same time, inshore fishing accounts for a large proportion of the total fisheries in many European countries. Direct employment in inshore fishing is a cornerstone of the economy of many communities, and at the same time the derived employment in the fishing industry, retail trade and a number of other industries is of great importance, particularly to the outlying regions of the countries inn with coastal fishing. Tourism benefits from coastal fishing as a cultural factor and is often the cause of tourists' fascination with a given area. Fish prepared and treated locally and in an area peculiar way also help to boost tourism. That is why inshore fishing is a crucial factor in settling and maintaining settlement in coastal areas, so it is important that inshore fishing has the best possible conditions in European countries.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. – Existing provisions on small-scale fishing not only abolish centuries-old practices and traditions, but can further fuel the advanced problem of depopulation of islands by endangering the identity and livelihoods of islanders. Adapting legislation is necessary to preserve the unique cultural heritage of small fishermen.  That is why I am extremely pleased that the most important amendment has been adopted, calling on the Commission to allow small-scale coastal fishing in island communities traditionally dependent on fisheries for their own livelihood. In addition to it, an amendment has entered asking for an appropriate definition of coastal and small-scale coastal or traditional fishing for non-commercial purposes, which will be based more on the socioeconom and cultural characteristics of a particular area rather than on the dimensions and strength of fishing boats.  I am particularly pleased that an amendment has been adopted indicating concerns about the loss of traditional fishing skills and knowledge due to unfavourable regulations for coastal communities. As an MEP who was born on an island and raised by the sea, aware of the importance and gravity of life on the islands, I call for european legislation to be adapted to preserve the unique cultural heritage of small fishermen. This would indeed confirm Europe's unification in its diversity.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of Norica Nicolai's report on fisheries aspects under the International Convention on Marine Biodiversity in Areas outside national jurisdiction (United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea) (2015/2109(INI)) (A8-0042/2016).

name: Norica Nicolai
text: rapporteur – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to thank my colleagues on the committee and in particular the shadow rapporteurs for the way we have worked together in drawing up this report, which I see as a clear message of support for the European Commission, while stressing what our committee's priorities are in relation to the negotiations on the new international agreement. As you know, almost 64% of the planet's waters remain outside the regulatory scope of the Convention on the Law of the Sea, as such the protection of the environment, marine biodiversity and sustainable exploitation of resources are not covered by this Convention, which is more than thirty-five years old, which applies the principle of freedom of the seas in a world where things have changed, where the economy is diversified , the need for food and resources of the population is quite different. As such, this Convention is to be subject, we hope, in the near future, to amendments that bring it to a present reality. With regard to subsequent agreements, the most important agreement we wish to signal is the one on fish stocks, an agreement reached in 1995. This agreement is specifically addressed to fish stocks with high migration and those outside national jurisdiction. The agreement is in force, it is a good agreement, there are certainly still issues that can be discussed about the effects of this agreement, but our committee recommends that the provisions of this agreement be strongly supported and maintained unchanged in the future legal instrument. In 2004, the UN General Assembly decided to start the first forms of negotiation of this convention. Subsequently, on 6 June 2015, the UN General Assembly decided to open debates and negotiations in preliminary committees. The committees will start work in 2016 and we hope that a first report will be in 2017. The aim of these committees will be to prepare substantive negotiations on the development of a legal international instrument, subordinate to the Convention on the Law of the Sea, to fill gaps and complement the agreements currently in force. I would particularly like to highlight the important role that the European Commission has played, being one of the voices that have taken this initiative in terms of the working group, but in this context I would like you to know that there are states that want to exclude from this agreement certain types of activities that take place outside national jurisdiction and in particular fishing , which puts us in difficulty, the European Commission and Parliament disagree with this exclusion. In short, the inclusion of fisheries in this new international, legal instrument is a priority for us for the reasons expressed earlier, but, with a very firm amendment, that this will not lead to the renegotiation of the 1995 agreement on fish stocks, but will ensure its inclusion in a new international framework. We also recommended the use, expansion and enhancement of the importance of regional organisations for fisheries management. They are part of the 1995 agreement, some of which have worked less well, but in general the work of these regional organisations is meritorious. We suggest that the United Nations find a way to motivate the less involved States in this agreement. As regards protected maritime areas, they cannot be successful unless there is coordination and collaboration between all areas of activity and if they are not established in an overall logic on the protection of biodiversity. We hope that the new international instrument will include an institutional decision-making structure.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on this report, and I wanted to say that today we are here to discuss a new international instrument to regulate our seas, but the first thing to say is that no further regulation is necessary: the framework we have is sufficient and what is important is that all parties comply because not by adding more international laws we will be better preserving our seas and oceans.  So far, it is clear that we have not done very well and are making inefficient use of the governance framework at our we have. Regional fisheries organizations are competent and should manage fisheries resources, and they need to continue to do so as they are, so let us focus on strengthening and improving coordination between international and regional organizations and put them all to work together to properly regulate global fisheries.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I also greet the rapporteur. Fishing resources are a component of marine biodiversity and fisheries have the greatest impact on this biodiversity. I therefore consider the need for an integrated legal and scientific approach to be inescapable.  I would therefore like to highlight in this report the mention of vulnerable marine ecosystems and ecologically and biologically significant areas. The first reflects the recognition of the environmental sensitivity made by FAO, closer to the maintenance of resources, and the second reflects the recognition of the Convention for Biological Diversity, usually closer to concerns regarding biodiversity and the functioning of ecosystems.  It seems to me that the integration of both approaches in this report could contribute to giving political consistency in support of the implementation of a global network of marine protected areas in areas beyond national jurisdiction, in my fundamental opinion for the conservation of the oceans and their resources.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Nikolai, on her suggestion, because it really covers the issues that concern us. Within the framework of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, the United Nations General Assembly has decided to establish an internationally legally binding instrument for the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity.  In particular, it was tended that this objective should be achieved and that the European Union's fishing industry and market should therefore be sustainability-oriented. This UN Convention must, of course, be applied by all countries, not only the countries of the European Union, but also the countries which are candidates for accession to the European Union and the rest.  At the same time, in addition to protecting resources, I think I should once again point out that the European Union must finally take serious care in supporting fishermen in all member states, and in particular in my own country, Greece.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the conservation of marine biodiversity, particularly in international waters, undoubtedly requires an effort of cooperation and concertation at international level. The United Nations is the appropriate forum to establish and deepen, as necessary and the evolution of reality requires, these bonds of cooperation and concertation, with a view to the good conservation of marine resources and their sustainable exploitation, according to criteria of justice and equity.  The Convention on the Law of the Sea is, inter beside mis, an appropriate instrument for pursuing these purposes. The measures to be implemented should be based on sound scientific knowledge and a comprehensive impact assessment of the various activities carried out in the marine environment. The European Union has a role here that has not always been assumed with the coherence and means that were justified. Quite the contrary. The example of deep-sea fisheries is enlightening. Why is it harmful to be done in European Union waters to be acceptable in international waters?

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – I would, of course, like to support all the initiatives that will lead to what is the subject of today's negotiations in this report, i.e. achieving sustainable development of the level of fisheries and, of course, biological diversity within the seas and the marine environment.  On the other hand, however, we must admit that, even in the European Union, we are faced with influences that are reflected in the loss of biodiversity. I have chosen, I have allowed myself, a few that are really related to our European space. This is the increase in the human population and urbanisation in coastal areas; excessive supply of nitrogen and phosphorus, which can just cause eutrophication; of course, fishing effort, which threatens the very existence of fish and other living organisms, and undoubtedly pollution from ships by rinsing fuel and oil tanks.  Here we still have a number of shortcomings in our own field, and I welcome this activity, which draws attention to these question marks.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I think it is right and very appropriate, perhaps only a little late, for the United Nations to intervene in the conservation and sustainable use of marine biological diversity in areas not subject to national jurisdiction.  The increase in maritime activities and the increased pressure on marine sustainability make protective action no longer delayed. The development of a legally binding international instrument that wants to be truly effective and well coordinated in the field of marine biology must necessarily also cover fishing activity, just as it is necessary to include in the new international agreement the principle of responsibility through the recognition of ecological damage at sea and the establishment of the chain of responsibility for this damage.  The new international agreement provides for the development of an institutional mechanism to carry out a preliminary environmental impact assessment for activities that can have a significant impact on the marine environment, with a solid scientific basis and accompanying this activity with environmental and socio-economic monitoring.

name: Werner Kuhn (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I simply love this parliamentary debate, where you can hear different opinions and opinions and perhaps make one or the other argument. The enforcement of these international agreements is the key to this. We have enough laws – as Gabriel Mato said earlier – but we, as the European Union, must make a strong stand out from our market position. 70% of the fish and fish products consumed in Europe are imports, only 30% can be brought from our own resources, from our own fishing areas as fresh fish or from aquaculture. The South-East Asians, the Chinese and the Russians are importing their fish into the market, and everywhere we want to check that quality and sustainability in fisheries are also enforced. That is why we also make our common demand: we need a European eco-label. And according to this eco-label, all imports must then also be assessed. They cannot simply enter our market, but they must also comply with the conditions. That would also be fair for our own fisheries.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all allow me to welcome this own-initiative report on fisheries issues within the international agreement on the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea on the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity in areas beyond national jurisdiction, better known as BBNJ. I am happy to say that the report rightly focuses on this important development, which should bring international maritime law up to date with developments in the last 30 years. We have been promoting this new agreement since the first meeting of the BBNJ Working Group in 2006. This report by Mrs Nicolai, whom I would like to thank very much, is very timely, as the first preparatory committee, which opens the negotiations on this international instrument, has just taken place in the last two weeks, between 28 March and 8 April. It will be followed by a second meeting at the end of August, between 26 August and 12 September. The report rightly points out that the new legal instrument will address a package of elements. These will include marine genetic resources, including questions on the sharing of benefits, area-based management tools including marine protected areas, environmental impact assessments, capacity-building and the transfer of marine technology. One of the main aims of this new agreement will be to establish a mechanism which will enable the creation and management of marine protected areas. This will help the global community meet the commitment it made at the third Rio Conference on Sustainable Development to protect 10% of oceans in this manner by 2020. The European Union would also like this agreement to make the UNCLOS provisions on environmental impact assessments operational. This is necessary to prevent or to mitigate activities which have a negative impact on marine biodiversity. All activities in the high seas that could have an impact on marine biodiversity, including fisheries, should be covered by the new agreement without, however, undermining existing international fisheries law and bodies. This agreement should also help achieve the biodiversity protection provisions in the UN fish stocks agreement (FSA). We agree with the report that the UN FSA continues to function well and should not be renegotiated, only implemented better. Similarly, we continue to support the work of regional fisheries management organisations. I am committed to ensuring that these organisations become more effective in delivering their aims of managing highly migratory and straddling stocks. I want to reassure you that the Commission and the European Union will continue to play a leading role in the UN negotiations and to defend the need for better protection of marine biodiversity, in line with our international commitments. We will also continue to support the work of the regional fisheries management organisations in managing fisheries. The right balance will have to be struck between conservation and sustainable use, similarly to what we have done with the latest reform of the common fisheries policy. In addition, we will not allow these negotiations to upset the balance of rights and obligations established by the UNCLOS. We consider this to be the legal framework under which all human activities in the oceans should be undertaken. I would like to conclude by thanking you for the support in our fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. This remains one of our priorities, and we will continue to work with our international partners to tackle this serious environmental, social and economic problem.

name: Linnéa Engström
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their excellent cooperation in this report. A special thanks also to the Long-Distance Advisory Council, which was very timely in organising a conference in Las Palmas on the issue so that we could take their input into account in the drafting of the report. I am very happy that we all share the ambition of promoting sustainable fishing, keeping fish stocks above levels that can produce maximum sustainable yield, not only inside the EU waters but also outside the EU. Historically there have been very good reasons to be critical of fisheries agreements – they used to be very unsustainable. The great achievement of the new common fisheries policy is the inclusion of rules on fishing activities outside of the EU. The EU is now bound to respect human rights and only fish from surplus stocks. The transparency provisions in the new protocol on Mauritania that will soon be voted on at Parliament should work as a guideline, and I want to thank the Commission here. I know that the negotiations with Mauritania were very hard, and the Commission should be praised for doing a great job. Now we need to make sure that the conditions are met, and we will follow proceedings very closely to make sure that Mauritania lives up to its commitments and publishes all its agreements with other states and private companies. There are many good ambitions that we share in this report – the establishment of regulatory framework for joint ventures, for instance. Since the CFP is to be a vehicle to provide technical, scientific and financial assistance to third countries, the EU must promote the harmonisation of conditions of access to African waters for all foreign fleets. The regional management of fisheries should be encouraged, including control programmes, and the network of fisheries agreements is to be used to ensure that other distant fishing fleets also respect the same standards of sustainability. The EU should encourage third countries to develop a regulatory framework for joint ventures from the EU and other interests as the best way of ensuring that such joint ventures are sustainable and transparent. Over party lines, I am happy that the European Parliament shares the objective of using the influence of the EU on the international stage in order to improve fisheries management and transparency standards. The EU should encourage a race to the top, instead of a race to the bottom, in international fisheries. I hope that we can cooperate in the same great spirit on the Commission’s new proposal on the Fishing Authorisation Regulation, for which I am rapporteur. We will start at the next Strasbourg part-session, as I understand.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the first thing I would like to do is congratulate the rapporteur, who has been able to reconcile the birth of her baby with the preparation of this good report.  The external dimension of the common fisheries policy is an area of fundamental importance for Europe, given the inadequacy of fishery resources in Community waters. The agreements we close with third countries mean, and that is a part that we now want to strengthen in particular, a benefit not only economic but also social for the inhabitants of those areas and for the development of their own fishing industry.  Moreover, its role is fundamental in creating jobs, both in the European Union and in the countries in whose fishing grounds we operate. The European Union has managed in recent years to significantly improve the quality of fisheries agreements, and we can boast that European fishing fleets meet higher social and environmental standards globally.  We must, in any event, move forward on the line of closing more transparent and sustainable fisheries conventions and we need to ensure that they meet minimum conditions for both those countries in which our fleet will work and for our fishermen.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Linnéa Engström. The formation of a preliminary working document and the permanent openness to suggestions from the different shadow rapporteurs seemed to me to be a particularly appropriate way of drawing up reports on Parliament's initiative. This is an important document, as I have already said and I endorse what Mr Mato said, but nevertheless I think it sins only because of the lack of recognition that marine biodiversity is under pressure, with fisheries being among the most immediate threats. I'm sorry this wasn't in the joint. By the positive there would be many aspects to highlight, and these are the ones that will lead me to vote positively on this document of which I was shadow rapporteur for the Socialists and Democrats. Among them it seems to me particularly important to mention a single register for vessels circulating in international waters. It is necessary to end with the permanent changes of flag, this expedient so used by the predatory shipowners.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the conflicts caused in the fisheries sector no longer have ethnic characteristics, because the ones that collide are the poor, from the economic crisis and the tax policies of austerity, fishermen of the European Union, with the European Commission which is taking measures to protect marine resources. This crisis, of course, adds to the ever-increasing pressure exerted by emerging fishing forces from Asia, as well as the lack of respect for the fundamental principles that the common fisheries policy has established. A reasonable external dimension of the common fisheries policy must safeguard the interests of European fishermen, especially smaller ones, and require sustainability, food safety and the fight against illegal fishing outside the European Union, because the impact on marine ecosystems knows no bounds. However, this will be pointless if the common fisheries policy does not respond, at the same time, to the fair request for the reconstruction of Europe's primary sector, particularly in those countries affected by the Memorandums, such as Greece.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, thank you to the rapporteur for the work she has done. I would like to say that the European fleet, European fisheries professionals are, according to the estimates of all international bodies, the most respectful in the world in the exploitation of fishery resources, those who best collaborate through their agreements with the development of the third-country sector and those leading the fight against undeclared and unregulated fisheries.  We can, and we are at it, by extreme control and transparency and by promoting the role of regional fisheries regulatory organizations, but we must maintain a policy of agreements that has worked well so far.  Abandoning negotiations without exhausting the chances of agreement to the maximum only benefits fleets in other areas of the world that immediately occupy our place with much worse standards for our former partners and to protect the medium. That is why I ask here for trust, respect and support for a sector, for the most part exemplary; that is the objective that guides the amendments I have tabled to this report.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the external dimension of the common fisheries policy is akin to many of the problems, shortcomings, limitations and contradictions of the CFP itself in its various internal dimensions. We have been very critical of this policy and its practical results. Under the fisheries agreements, called partnership, but which have very little, all or almost everything comes down to financial transfers, always sparse, to developing countries, in exchange for the right to exploit their fisheries resources. In many cases this has been so for decades. These countries are continuously deprived of the capital gains they would obtain if they were themselves exploiting their resources, thus compromising the possibility of creating wealth and employment, their development, sovereignty and independence. It is necessary to recognise the failure of the European Union's cooperation policy in this area and to make profound changes involving the countries concerned and by linking more effectively the external dimension of the CFP with the development cooperation policy, which is wanted more genuine and effective.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – I would just like to point out that the Czech Republic can also draw funds from the fisheries fund during this programming period, this is the first time.  However, on the subject, I would like to say that the last Parliament also addressed this crucial issue, namely fisheries and fisheries agreements, and in 2012 adopted its report in which it stated in paragraph 11 that it recalls that the main objective of the external fisheries policy must be to maintain the fisheries agreements in force and to find new opportunities for fishing in third countries. In doing so, Parliament recognises that, where an EU fleet ceases to operate in the fisheries of a third country, the relevant fishing opportunities are generally allocated to other fleets applying much lower standards of management and sustainability than those laid down and protected by the EU.  I think that is a question that we really should answer. To what extent do others occupy such hunting grounds when clearing out our positions?

name: Werner Kuhn (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I believe that the European Union's partnership agreements with third countries, most of which are also developing countries, are also of great importance to the States themselves. They usually have a relatively underdeveloped – small-scale – fishery, and from the financial contributions that we, as the European Union, make from the fishing yields there as a development aid, they can improve their fleets, they can also try to build up processing there – whether we are looking at Mauritania or Morocco, these are eloquent examples of this – and they are fished according to the rules of the European Union's common fisheries policy. There, scientific surveys can also be made about the stocks – whether that is in the Indian Ocean via bluefin tuna, whether it is up to the Pacific or off Africa and also in the Atlantic. It is very important that we also combat illegal fishing there and draw attention to which countries are not complying with the rules of the United Nations. You can only get this on the spot when our fleets are on the way there. That is why a good start has been made here, which can be combined very well with development policy, and the fact that quality can then also be introduced here is of the utmost importance to my terms. Fish is common good. Only the sea must be fished, which the country in question also grants us. There are very clear treaties on this, and this can be monitored, including through our own navigation and satellite system, Galileo. The ships all have their automatic identification systems. In this respect, I do not see the great concerns that some members have. Mrs Engström, I must compliment you very much. That is a good report that you have delivered.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first all we greatly appreciate this timely report on the external dimension of the fisheries policy prepared by the rapporteur, Ms Engström, and I would also like to thank the rapporteur. The report’s recommendations are very much in the same direction as the Commission’s policy. It recognises that sustainable fishing partnership agreements contribute to sustainable fishing and to the development of the fisheries sector in partner countries. I fully agree that these agreements play a key role in the global governance of the oceans. As you know, my ambition is to set a benchmark at international level through these agreements. Sustainable fisheries partnership agreements (SFPAs) contribute to the achievement of development goals, in particular food security. We need to help developing countries to manage their resources in a sustainable way, and this is key for the supply of healthy food and for the livelihood of coastal populations. I welcome the report’s finding that SFPAs are a very successful tool that integrate the partnership component and commercial aspects of the SFPAs, and that they promote transparency, sustainability and accountability. I also share your objective that we should ensure even better consistency between fisheries, environmental and trade policy, as well as development cooperation. I agree that, as pointed out in the Court of Auditors’ report, there is room for further improvement. This is the case, for example, for our sectoral support policy. This is already a highly effective tool, supporting our third-country partners in developing their fisheries sector in a sustainable way and in fighting illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. We will continue to work to rally the sector’s support and ensure better coherence with our policies and our regional cooperation. Some of the report’s recommendations have already been included in my recent proposal on the sustainable management of the external fleet. I want to improve the current legal framework and extend its scope to tackle any situation where a Union vessel is fishing outside EU waters, including under the so-called private licences. I also want to prevent abusive reflagging, which is not addressed in the current rules. These measures should definitely improve transparency and represent an additional step in reinforcing the governance of oceans where the EU is playing a key role. I am therefore looking forward to Parliament’s support on this proposal. Finally, a few words on regional fisheries management organisations. We have a key interest in creating such bodies where stocks are shared, and in ensuring that they work well when they already exist. We have been working hard to increase the performance of these bodies in recent years, including through financial contributions. We will also continue to improve scientific compliance and to ensure science—based decision-making. Geographical gaps, such as in the central Arctic Ocean, should be closed by setting up an adequate management framework. Existing advisory bodies, such as the Fishery Committee for the Eastern Central Atlantic, should be made into fully-fledged decision-making bodies. But we cannot achieve this alone. Therefore, since the beginning of my mandate, I have reached out to a number of key players to move better fisheries governance forward. Regarding the rapporteur’s support for our stronger and clearer provisions on joint ventures, the Commission has proposed this through specific conditions in its new proposal for the regulation of the external fleet – FAR – which is now under negotiation. This will increase transparency and reduce opportunities for abuse. I would like to take the opportunity to assure you that the Commission is fully committed to improving global fisheries governance as an essential component of ocean governance. We will continue to act globally at the level of the UN and FAO to have the legal framework we need, regionally to have efficient fisheries management bodies in place, and bilaterally in the framework of sustainable fisheries partnership agreements and dialogues with key partners to make sure fish stocks are managed in the best possible way and in a transparent manner. I would like to thank this House for its support and I am looking forward to continuing our work in a good spirit of cooperation.
