name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Madam President, in my speech I would like to focus on the marine environment and the significant potential it has to benefit and support rural communities. It should be promoted to benefit those communities. In tonight’s debate we have focused on fishing and also the benefits for those communities, but I wish to emphasise these, and I know the Commissioner will agree with me because I met him last year at a very significant conference in Cork on the potential of the blue economy and the strong growth figures that we have seen in Ireland in the blue economy. It has continued to outperform the national economy, with rates of about 8% up to the year 2014, which exceeds growth in the national economy, and for every EUR 100 turnover created from the ocean economy there is EUR 75 to 80 interlinking in the surrounding economy. So it is of enormous potential both in terms of tourism, energy creation, fishing and fish processing, and research and innovation, and I would urge the Commissioner, who I know is committed to this, to promote the blue economy and its very valuable potential for supporting the rural regions in our communities.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the Panama dossiers have shown that there are no global control mechanisms capable of ensuring equal treatment for all citizens and companies. The market does not provide equal opportunities for all, but only for those who are strong. Beyond the deeply immoral behavior of those who hid their money in tax havens, far from paying taxes in countries where they make profits, the worse is that the world has lost what could have been done with these funds. According to information in the Romanian press, the hidden amounts are equivalent to the Romanian health budget and higher than the youth budget. I am sure that similar situations exist in many European countries. Restructuring tax havens, paying tax instead of obtaining profit and supporting the economic environment can be mechanisms by which we can resolve this situation. I recall that the tax on financial transactions has been supported by more than half a million citizens and that it can block this kind of happening from reproducing in the future. The European Commission must react and we are waiting for firm proposals.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the first-instance panel of The Hague tribunal handed down the acquittal of Vojislav Seselj, a Serbian warmonger and mastermind and commander of a criminal militia during the war in Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. A verdict like this is scandalous in itself, but some parts of it are particularly shocking.  The Council, for example, characterised Greater Serbia as a "political rather than a criminal project" which is at risk of some previous rulings by the same court. It is clear to anyone iole who is familiar with political and war events in the former Yugoslavia in the 1990s that Greater Serbia could not have been formed in any other way than by crime, so such characterization is completely absurd. With this ruling, the ICTY violated not only the reconciliation process in the former Yugoslavia, but also trust in international law. After this, many countries will in the future refrain from cooperating with international courts, which will negatively affect world peace and stability.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, on 26 April there will be the thirtieth anniversary of the disaster at the Chernobyl nuclear power station in Ukraine. Among others, some 5 000 people were forcibly sent from Estonia to Chernobyl for the elimination of the effects of the nuclear disaster. Recorded diseases to workers in the Chernobyl recovery operations were significant. Rates of cancers and other health problems were much higher among recovery workers than in the rest of the population. After Estonia regained independence, former recovery workers were entitled to various social benefits, but the regulations changed in 2003. Nowadays they are entitled to some benefits only if they are recognised as unlawfully repressed persons. In Estonia an oppressed person must have been an Estonian citizen at the time of repression. Most representatives of ethnic minorities do not meet this criterion. Therefore, they cannot obtain benefits. This limitation concerns almost exclusively people of ethnic minority origin, and it leads to indirect ethnic discrimination. Indirect discrimination of people suffering from the Chernobyl disaster on the grounds of ethnicity or origin should be abolished without delay.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the Domecq family, to which Commissioner Miguel Arias Cañete's wife belongs, has received EUR 36.6 million in CAP subsidies from the common agricultural policy since 2008. It is the second Spanish family to receive the most money from Europe. This alone would be reason enough for Mr Cañete to appear in this Parliament, because his family was lining up with money from Europeans and Europeans while he was Minister of Agriculture and has continued to do so now that he is Commissioner of the European Union. But add to this that Mrs Micaela Domecq is one of the alleged tax evasors who appears on Panama papers. Mr. Cañete, come here and face it or, better yet, leave office and go home!

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, on 10 December 1991, the vast majority of the population of Nagorno-Karabakh voted for independence in a referendum. The response to this democratic process was a military offensive by Azerbaijan, with more than 30 000 dead. Subsequently a ceasefire between Azerbaijan, Nagorno-Karabakh and Armenia was signed. The creation of the Minsk Group in 1992 was a breakthrough, but Azerbaijan has refused to implement a true international mechanism for monitoring violations of the ceasefire. Nagorno-Karabakh has fully democratic institutions, an exemplary judicial system and low levels of corruption. For this reason we request the inclusion of representatives of Nagorno-Karabakh in the negotiations of the Minsk Group, precisely because they decide the future of the country’s inhabitants. Once the military conflict is resolved it will be necessary to agree a procedure to properly recognise the new independent state at international level.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am here to say that, thanks to the Italian judiciary, a new scandal has come to light concerning the illegal disposal of waste related to oil extraction activities in Basilicata, in southern Italy. Mayors, regional councillors, regional presidents, undersecretaries, ministers and also Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi were involved. Yet, on 13 November 2014, I asked the Commission, which is represented here, whether the Tempa Rossa, Tecnoparco and Centro Olio di Viggiano plants complied with European directives; on January 7, 2015 I reported the harmful effects on the health of mining activities in the Val d'Agri; on March 5, 2015, I asked about the environmental compatibility of an ENI well, which was damaged for the fifth time; on March 12, 2015 I reported the practice of illegal disposal of industrial sludge in Tempa Rossa; on June 21, 2015 I reported contamination by heavy metals and hydrocarbons of the aquifer near the Oli di Viggiano center; I would add: a written declaration, ten speeches in plenary, more than twenty speeches in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy. So I want to know what the European institutions are doing if, in the face of all these reports, no measures have been taken to defend the health of citizens.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I denounce to the Presidency a very serious violation of the rights and prerogatives of Parliament and of the Member of Parliament, in this case myself, who is being prosecuted before the Court of Milan for express opinions.  Although the Court of First Instance was informed that the matter was sub judice to the JURI Committee, the court refused to stay the proceedings, not only that, but unexpectedly decided to refer the matter to court. Now, I believe that we are facing an unusual and very serious violation of prerogative and also a violation of what is the result of the constant jurisprudence of the Courts of Justice. That is why I will be handing over to President Schulz tomorrow an appeal in which I call on the President of Parliament to defend the aforementioned prerogative before the Court of Justice. We cannot allow a principle of freedom, because this prerogative also defends, it is the prerogative of Parliament as well as of the Member of Parliament, to be violated in an unexpected way against the constant jurisprudence of the Courts of Justice.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Corina Crețu, a member of the Juncker Commission, has been accused by collaborators and journalists at Politico of not fulfilling her mandate. Don't just go to the office. She spends her time in her home country or converts official visits to private stays. Colleagues at the CONT asked Mr. Italianer to account, but the answers were not convincing. Apparently, the Commission wishes to hide these serious breaches of professional ethics under the mat. Cretu reacted in a very personal style. Also journalists of Politico have written about the brochure she printed with money from the European Commission. It's not a defense, it's a cult of personality for which Ceaușescu would have been envious. Published in Romanian, the brochure explains that Europe exists only because Cretu works. I have today asked the Commission for explanations in a written question, and I look forward to finding out whether Mr Juncker agrees to spend European money on the strictly private interest of a Commissioner.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D).
text: – Madam President, my first words are today in memory of Eloy Palacio, a firefighter who died this last weekend fighting a hard fire in my city in Oviedo; therefore, a hug for the family and for the whole Oviedo fire brigade.  But today I wanted to talk about an insufferable situation that the dairy sector is experiencing in Asturias: more than two thousand families are living with concern the possible end of their way of living in the absence of clear measures by the European Commission and the Member States to ensure reasonable prices.  We need market measures that allow the consumer to differentiate between the different dairy products and their origin, and we also need to end the dumping that is leading the sector to a dead end. Therefore, Asturian milk needs a future in the interests of farmers and all consumers.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Politicians in my region have been warning for years about Russia's neo-imperial policy. Georgia and Ukraine should provide warning lights. Now that we are aware of russia's propaganda war against the West, are we looking at how it might have influenced the outcome of the Dutch referendum? Have the societies, the politicians of the Countries of the European Union, supported the public of the Presidency in fulfilling the common security and defence policy towards our partners and in the face of such threats as come from Russia. Are we aware that the same propaganda can be used in all Member States of the European Union without exception.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadžić has been convicted in the Hague Tribunal for genocide, among other things. The judgment, despite its shortcomings, will be important for the establishment of the truth about the war and the reconciliation process in Bosnia, one of the EU's candidate countries that is still marked by problems. A few days later, however, the extremist Vojislav Šešelj has been completely acquitted, mainly because the Tribunal has not been able to substantiate the link between Šešelj's hateful rhetoric and the war crimes that have been committed. They may find it legally difficult to prove links between saying, as Šešelj, that you want to "get out of the eyes of every Croat" and the crimes that have been committed. Morally, however, it is not the least bit difficult. If the Court cannot condemn these statements, we politicians must do so. The release of Šešelj will have major consequences for reconciliation and eu enlargement. European politicians must therefore support both reconciliation and the enlargement process by more clearly condemning the atrocities committed, thereby creating the moral justice that the Court has failed to create.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, last week we received in the European Parliament the visit of the neighbouring neighbours of Muskiz, Abanto and Alumbres, who live every day next to , glued to , two chemical plants for the treatment of unconventional fuels such as coke. These two Petronor and Repsol plants openly breach legality. One is built on maritime territory. The other threatens to expand on land protected by the Natura 2000 Network.  In common, both areas record irregular data on lung conditions, cancer and premature death, and their emissions are not properly monitored. In common, too, the permissiveness they receive directly from public representatives who turn on the revolving doors well oiled by multinationals.  Who should defend citizenship is bought. Town halls like Zierbena's have preferred to spend public money defending multinationals than defending the health of their inhabitants.  That is why we will ask for what we believe is more than justifiable: that the European Union be mobilized to study and justify the dangers of these facilities to the health of the inhabitants, so that this situation is not repeated either in the Spanish State or in any other country of the European Union.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, in many Member States, and here I particularly point out the Croatia from which I come, there are missing measures for the energy renovation of multi-residential buildings, especially those measures that focus on vulnerable and socially vulnerable consumer groups. Unfortunately, measures to combat energy poverty and measures to improve housing standards that would allow a greater share of the use of renewable energy sources, domestic energy sources and reduce unemployment have been completely absent.  Under the pretext of achieving savings in heat consumption, the Government of the Republic of Croatia, by irresponsibly introducing a legal obligation for citizens to install heat dividers and threatening financial sanctions, and without previously implemented renovation of buildings, violated one of the basic objectives of the Energy Efficiency Directive, strengthening consumers' right to accurate information about the amount and time of energy consumption and charging the amount of energy actually consumed.  I call on the Government of the Republic of Croatia to amend the unjust law and regulations and warn the Commission to act in a timely and timely way in protecting consumers and the rights of citizens of the European Union.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: – Let me introduce you to what the Czech Republic thinks of the European Union's agreement with Turkey.  The Czech Parliament has adopted the following resolution: 1) The Chamber of Deputies strongly rejects the introduction of a mandatory redistribution mechanism for refugees; 2) The Chamber of Deputies rejects the agreement of the Heads of Government of the EU member states on the abolition of visas for Turkish citizens.  But does brussels even care about anyone who thinks one democratically elected parliament? I'm afraid not. The European Council and the Commission deliberately baked an agreement with Turkey that does not have the requirements of the Treaty so that it cannot be discussed by this or any other parliament in the Member State.  Shame on the European Council for bypassing democratic institutions and foringing an agreement with Turkey that no parliament has even negotiated. This is a democratic deficit in practice, that is why the European institutions are losing the trust of citizens.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: Madam President, on 6 April, the Dutch decided in a referendum to reject the European Association Agreement with Ukraine. Ukraine was just a pretext. The real objective of the 480,000 citizens who triggered the referendum was to disavow the European Union and its leaders, the European Union and its bankruptcy in the face of the migration crisis - its leaders, who are accumulating scandals: LuxLeaks for Jean-Claude Juncker and Panama papers for the Energy Commissioner, Miguel Arias Caete. But the Union does not want to understand the message sent by 64% of voters. Instead of making amends, it is increasingly tightening the technocratic links that are strangling Member States. The latest example is the ongoing creation of a super-Frontex agency to save Schengen. The Eu's union will have its currency, with Brexit on June 23, pending Marine Le Pen's breakthrough in France in 2017.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Madam President, not for the first time I want to talk about trade here in the Chamber and, in particular, the issue of a trade agreement with Mercosur. I know that voices were raised in the Agriculture Council today in Luxembourg. 23 Member States are really concerned about the tactics of the Commission – about their potential opening offer to Mercosur, particularly regarding sensitive products, including beef, but also applying to poultry and, indeed, pig meat. There are real concerns at this time, when agriculture across Europe is in a very difficult position, that the Commission would be so willing to open the gates to importation of beef and cause real problems for rural parts of the European Union, and farmers in particular. As voices were raised around the Agriculture Council meeting this morning, I wanted to add my voice. I know other colleagues on the Agriculture Committee would share concerns here and once again warn the Commission not to sacrifice agriculture for other sectors of the economy.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it is a long-debated issue whether Member States should sell citizenship and residence permits or not. States have of course full sovereignty to decide to whom, and how, to grant their respective nationality, but of course it is EU nationality. However, recent global developments put this question into another perspective. The serious risk represented by terrorists, the worrying scale of tax evasion, and the refugee crisis, force us to revise the issue. Economic citizenship programmes run by Member States are just like harmful tax competition. Conditions vary greatly. However, they all lack transparency and therefore represent a breeding ground for fraud, corruption and even terrorism. Some countries are openly offering rich individuals and companies the opportunity for tax planning, thus assisting tax evasion, or even potential money laundering by terrorist organisations on EU territory. The fact that these schemes make it so easy for the rich to gain rights within the EU while others literally risk their lives to get here also sends a wrong message. Therefore, the question arises: do we want to support tax evasion, make things easy for terrorists and maintain unequal treatment of migrants based on their financial background, or finally create a common system with strict rules and monitoring to prevent all this?

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab If this passage of the introduction to the Treaty on European Union, which speaks of inspiration from Europe's religious heritage, is to have a real meaning and not just a diplomatic ornament, we should remember together the anniversaries such as the 1050th anniversary of the baptism of Polish. It is a pity that today the President of our Parliament has not sent any message to our society on this occasion. All the more so because 50 years ago the celebration of the millennium of baptism Polish was a milestone on the road to the freedom of our people, and therefore also on the road that brought freedom to the other peoples of Europe and the security of all. These events show that Christian civilization is not only our heritage, but in modern times it has also been the backing of our freedom. It is still our hope.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the refugee crisis is blowing up the seams of this European Union which is unable to provide security or resettle these thousands and thousands of people who are particularly protected. More importantly, rescue devices are dismantled and a military solution is given through the NATO group, security with Frontex or a purely repressive solution. We've seen it: the sticks and the gases that offend.  We're repeating the same mistakes. In the war on terror what we did was outsource torture, and now we outsource mass deportation. That is, we dynamit international law, the Geneva Convention or our own laws.  It is an aberration to say that Turkey is a safe country, because neither journalists nor intellectuals are safe there. Turkey is also tolerant of the destabilized Syrian extremists who have produced this situation, and uses refugees as a weapon to blackmail us. And we accept their blackmail and outsource the killing men to do the dirty work for us.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Almost exactly one year ago, on 17 March, the Education Ministers met in Paris and adopted a declaration on promoting citizenship and the common values of freedom, tolerance and non-discrimination in the education process in response to the attacks on Charlie Hebdo. After a year, we can look back and say that the situation has not improved and terrorist attacks threaten to continue. Of course, we do not expect all measures to produce concrete and rapid results within a year, but we must say that the way in which integration has been conceived in some countries does not have sufficient results.  I therefore agree that teachers need to be supported in the first place. To support them in their preparation for how to teach pupils and lead them to tolerance, but also to account, to solidarity, but above all to the perception of human and also European values.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Zika virus is an international danger. A recent study shows that this virus can cause a wider range of brain disorders than previously thought. We are already experiencing an increased number of cases of microcephaly, Guillain-Barré syndrome and other neurological disorders potentially associated with this virus. There are too many questions about these connections and, in this respect, it is necessary to strengthen surveillance of the Zika virus and, at the same time, to improve research methods. Time is precious to have a quick diagnosis, adequate treatment, but also to find vaccines for pregnant women. The World Health Organisation, whose anniversary just took place last week, has already taken a number of steps to support the affected countries. Significant cases of Zika virus infection have been reported in several European countries and we must bear in mind that we are also at risk of an outbreak in Europe. We must be prepared to deal with such a situation. It is very important that medical staff are vigilant, but also that the population is aware of the risks.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Madam President, honourable Members, I would like to draw your attention to the creeping Islamisation in gypsy neighbourhoods in Bulgaria, such as the one in Pazardzhik, for example, which poses a serious danger to our national security and to the national security of the other Member States of the European Union. The result of these processes we have seen recently in Paris and Brussels. This radicalization and Islamization is organized and conducted by the government in the Republic of Turkey, which continues its aggression and invasion on the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria through the formation of a new pro-Turkish Islamist political organization and party, a conduit for Erdogan's aggressive policy. That's what happened yesterday. It is high time for the leaders of European countries to realize the real threat posed by today's new Turkish neo-Oosmanist policy, to identify and occupy their country in this real war taking place on the territory of the European continent. There is no more time for politically correct talk and no more time to bury heads in the sand.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Terrorism knows no borders and threatens our freedom, threatens people's trust in public power, in ensuring their true safety.  I think that we should obtain legal instruments for resolute settlement with the perpetrators in terms of the personal harm that should be done to them as a result of committing an act of terrorism. I therefore think it is important to put into our legal order the fact that the courts will be able to deprive them of their citizenship or restrict civil rights for those persons, EU citizens who have committed or participated in a terrorist act, provided that, of course, they are convicted by an independent and impartial court in a final manner.  Furthermore, in my opinion, it is no longer permissible for EU citizens who commit terrorist acts to benefit from this citizenship, but it must be done to ensure that their state-citizen relationship with another Member State of the European Union is established.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Madam President, more and more allegations of sexual abuse perpetrated by UN peacekeepers have continued to surface over the past weeks. The UN Security Council last month passed a resolution but, given that some countries attempted to water down the text, it is unlikely to be implemented vigorously. It is an outrage that the most vulnerable in this world – women and children who have lost everything – are preyed upon by those supposed to offer them protection. I am shocked to the core about allegations that girls in the Central African Republic were forced by a military commander to take part in acts of bestiality, or that soldiers were asking starving children for sex in exchange for food. These are members of the military from all over the world, including from Europe. Acting collectively, Europe has the muscle to help end this sickening abuse. I call on High Representative Mogherini to make this a priority for coordinated EU action at the UN, to ensure that all perpetrators are tried under criminal proceedings and to provide effective training that raises awareness that such abuse cannot be tolerated.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D).
text: – Madam President, steelworkers and their families in Port Talbot and across the country are desperately worried about the uncertainty currently facing the UK steel industry. It is welcome news that Tata has found a buyer for their Scunthorpe steelworks. However, uncertainty remains about the future of steel-making in Britain, putting thousands of jobs at risk and threatening an industry which is vital to the UK’s defence and security. Faced with this crisis, the UK Government’s response has been totally inadequate both in the EU and back at home. Labour has put forward a clear four-point plan for the steel industry, including stabilising the industry and providing security for steelworkers, initiating a review into lowering costs like business and energy rates, fast-tracking infrastructure projects requiring large amounts of steel and engaging with the sector to lay out a long-term strategy for the future of the UK steel industry. I urge the UK Government to act now to set out a long-term plan for the steel industry in Britain and to back EU action against the importation of cheap Chinese steel.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I welcome the news today that Greybull Capital has bought Tata Steel’s Long Products Division, in a difficult deal brokered by local management and the unions in Scunthorpe. It is good news for an industry in an existential crisis due to the massive dumping of cheap steel. Contrary to the Europhobes’ lies, the EU is not the cause of this crisis, but it is a crucial means for fixing it through strong trade defence measures. MEPs, the Commission and governments representing 72% of Europe's population are in favour of action, but it is our government – the British Government – which is blocking that crucial EU action. Stronger trade defence tools could be finalised in a matter of weeks, on 13 May at the EU Trade Council, and it is up to the UK Government and David Cameron to decide if they are really willing to save our steel communities and our vital industry.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, every state has the right to defend its inhabitants, independence, territorial integrity and interests by whatever means deemed necessary, without, however, breaking the law or violating the inherent rights of its own people. Of these rights, freedom of speech and self-expression rank among the most important. Two years ago, the Latvian Maxim Koptelov published a survey on the possibility of Latvia joining the Russian Federation. He himself described the whole idea as a joke. Nonetheless, in February of this year he was sentenced to six months in prison. Interestingly, the authorities had ignored similar surveys on the subject of Latvia joining the United States of America. What is more, a month ago the Latvian Parliament introduced an amendment to its criminal law, according to which essentially any statement, even a joke, deemed to have improper content could now lead to actual imprisonment. My home country has disgraced itself in a shameful manner.
